OUTCOMES/DELIVERABLES - MCINTIRE STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH O MAXIMIZE THE CAPACITY OF MANAGED ENVIRONMENTS TO PROVIDE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES SUCH AS NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT, WATER QUALITY AND HABITAT. O UNDERSTAND HOW THE COUPLING BETWEEN HUMAN AND NATURAL SYSTEMS CAN ENHANCE AND PRESERVE BIODIVERSITY, ENHANCE RESILIENCE, IMPROVE THE MANAGEMENT OF AQUACULTURE, FISHERIES, AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITATS, AND PROMOTE A VIBRANT, SUSTAINABLE ENVIRONMENT. O UNDERSTAND AND ADDRESS THE DISTRIBUTION AND IMPACTS OF HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHALLENGES ACROSS COMMUNITIES, WHICH HAVE IMPLICATIONS FOR SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY. O INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF PLANNERS TO IMPROVE URBAN, FARM, PARK, COASTAL AND OPEN SPACEDEVELOPMENT BY ADDRESSING COMMUNITY NEEDS WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF CLIMATE CHANGE.

ABSTRACT THE UMES MCINTIRE?STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM FOCUSES ON CARRYING OUT RESEARCH, AND DEVELOPING THE FUTURE WORKFORCE TO CARRYOUT RELEVANT WORK IN FORESTRY. WORK AT UMES SPECIFICALLY FOCUSES ON FORESTS IN MARYLAND, ESPECIALLY ON THE DELMARVA PENINSULA. THE SPECIFIC FOCUS OF WORK AT UMES FALLS INTO THE FOLLOWING CATEGORIES: REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST,  MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION, AND  MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION; UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS. AMONG THE SPECIFIC PROJECTS TO BE CARRIED OUT WILL INCLUDE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF FOREST GROUND PLOTS TO MAP THE DISTRIBUTION OF FOREST TYPES ACROSS THE UMES FARM AND THE REST OF THE MANOKIN WATERSHED AS WELL AS ESTIMATE CARBON STOCKS IN ABOVE GROUND TREE AND UNDERSTORY BIOMASS, DEADWOOD, LITTER, AND IN THE SOIL OVER SEVERAL YEARS TO EVALUATE CHANGES IN CARBON STORAGE AND PREDICT POTENTIAL CAPTURE OF CARBON DIOXIDE EMISSIONS. THESE PLOTS WILL SERVE AS IMPORTANT OUTDOOR LEARNING LABS AND DEMONSTRATIONS FOR UMES? STUDENTS ESPECIALLY ON FOREST DISTRIBUTION AND RESILIENCE, CARBON SEQUESTRATION, AND THE IMPORTANCE OF FORESTS TO MITIGATE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THE RESEARCH WILL: 1) GENERATE FINE SCALE BASE DATASET OF FOREST TYPES FOR STEWART NECK FARM, 2) ESTIMATE AND EVALUATE THE CARBON SEQUESTRATION POTENTIAL OF FOREST EXPERIMENTS AND DEMONSTRATION PLOTS DEVELOPED, 3) IMPROVE ABILITY TO CLASSIFY FOREST TYPES FROM IMAGERY, 4) ESTIMATE CARBON SEQUESTRATION POTENTIAL FOR MANOKIN WATERSHED, AND 5) PROPOSE THEDEVELOPMENT OF A CARBON SEQUESTRATION DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM SERVING FOREST RESILIENCE, CARBON SEQUESTRATION, AND CLIMATE CHANGE OBJECTIVES.

UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS FY23 MCINTIRE-STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM PROJECT ABSTRACT ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE QUANTIFYING IMPACTS OF FOREST COVER ON HEALTHCARE EXPENDITURES IN THE CONTINENTAL U.S., INVESTIGATING URBAN FORESTS TO IDENTIFY WAYS TO SUPPORT HEALTHY BAT POPULATIONS, IDENTIFYING SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS FOR REFORESTATION AND FOREST MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES WILL INVESTIGATE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE EFFICACY OF FIRE-BASED MANAGEMENT REGIMES FOR MAINTAINING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN FORESTS STRESSED BY NONNATIVE PLANT INVASIONS. FURTHER RESEARCH WILL EXPLORE FORESTRY ISSUES ILLINOIS IS FACING LOOKING AT INVASIVE SPECIES, REVIEWING MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AND APPLICABILITY OF AGROFORESTRY PRACTICES. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES QUANTIFY IMPACT OF FORESTED LAND AND HEALTHCARE EXPENDITURES. DELIVER RECOMMENDED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO ENHANCE FOREST STRUCTURES TO STAKEHOLDERS. WE SEEK TO IMPROVE FLOODPLAIN REFORESTATION EFFORTS, WHICH ARE UNDERTAKEN TO INCREASE THE DELIVERY OF KEY ECOSYSTEM SERVICES FOR RURAL LANDOWNERS, INCLUDING PRODUCTION OF FOREST PRODUCTS, PROVISION OF FLOODWATER STORAGE AND EROSION CONTROL SERVICES, AND RESTORATION OF WILDLIFE HABITAT. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION REGARDING THE NATIVE SEED SUPPLY CHAIN. THIS RESEARCH ADDRESSES THE GOAL OF THE USDA-SUPPORTED NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY TO IDENTIFY SEED NEEDS AND ENSURE THE RELIABLE AVAILABILITY SEED FOR RESTORATION AND REVEGETATION. PROVIDE AN INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF BENEFITS AND TRADEOFFS OF FIRE-BASED FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS. INCREASE OUR OVERALL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT FORESTS AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT AND UTILIZATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES TARGET AUDIENCES FOR MCINTIRE-STENNIS RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE POLICY MAKERS AND RESEARCHERS CONCERNED WITH PUBLIC HEALTH, HEALTH CARE EXPENDITURES, AND THE MANAGEMENT OF FORESTED LANDS, ACADEMIC ECOLOGISTS, LAND MANAGERS, RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS, GOVERNMENT AGENCY PERSONNEL INVOLVED IN PLANNING, IMPLEMENTING, AND REGULATING ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION, AFFORESTATION AND CONSERVATION PROGRAMS, USDA FOREST SERVICE RESOURCE MANAGERS AT THE SHAWNEE NATIONAL FOREST, STATE AND LOCAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, SCIENTISTS STUDYING INVASIVE SPECIES, AND THE BROADER PUBLIC. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS DOES NOT EXPECT ANY SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS (M-S) COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM IN THE WARNELL SCHOOL OF FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA (UGA) IS TO ASSIST THE STATE IN CARRYING OUT AN APPLIED RESEARCH PROGRAM WHOSE OUTCOMES SUPPORT THE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF OUR FOREST LANDS TO PROVIDE MULTIPLE BENEFITS FOR PEOPLE AND NATURE. IN DOING SO, AN ADDITIONAL PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP A POOL OF WELL-TRAINED FOREST SCIENTISTS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH AND PRACTICE. THE M-S PROGRAM AT UGA SUPPORTS RESEARCH IN ALL THE FEDERAL PROGRAM'S FOCUS AREAS. IN THE AREA OF (1) REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR TIMBER PRODUCTION AND OTHER RELATED FOREST PRODUCTS, ONE SUB-PROJECT WILL EVALUATE GENETICALLY IMPROVED PLANTATIONS RELATIVE TO UNIMPROVED PLANTATIONS IN TERMS OF STAND DYNAMICS, WOOD QUALITY, AND GROWTH AND YIELD. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE FORESTLAND MANAGERS, FOREST INDUSTRY PLANNERS, AND PRIVATE FORESTLAND OWNERS. A SECOND SUBPROJECT IN THIS AREA ADVANCESOPERATIONS RESEARCH METHODOLOGY THAT CAN IMPROVE FOREST PLANNING PROCESSES, LEADING TO FOREST PLANS THAT ARE FEASIBLE, EFFICIENT, AND SUSTAINABLE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW MODEL FOR HARVEST SCHEDULING. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE FOREST MANAGERS, ANALYSTS, LANDOWNERS AND LAND MANAGEMENT PLANNERS. FINALLY, A THIRD SUBPROJECT EVALUATES HOW WATER USE EFFICIENCY AND SOIL ORGANIC CARBON RESPOND TO ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, DISTURBANCES, AND SILVICULTURAL TECHNIQUES OVER TIME PERIODS RELEVANT TO FOREST ROTATIONS. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE OF LANDOWNERS, LAND MANAGERS, STUDENTS, AND SCIENTISTS FROM A VARIETY OF DISCIPLINES INTERESTED IN THE SUSTAINABILITY OF FOREST PRODUCTION. IN THE AREA OF (2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION, A SUBPROJECT IS FOCUSED ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF ENHANCED FORESTRY BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (EBMPS) THAT HELP TO ENSURE THAT PRIVATE AND INDUSTRIAL FORESTLANDS IN THE SOUTHEAST PROVIDE A WIDE RANGE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN ADDITION TO WOOD PRODUCTS, INCLUDING TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC HABITATS FOR NATIVE SPECIES, RECREATION, CLEAN AIR AND WATER, AND MITIGATION AGAINST FLOODS AND DROUGHTS. THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE THE WATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY BENEFITS OF EBMPS AND DEVELOP STRATEGIES TO COMPENSATE AND ENCOURAGE FOREST LANDHOLDERS TO IMPLEMENT THESE PRACTICES. TASKS INCLUDE EVALUATION OF EBMP EFFECTIVENESS, ESTABLISHMENT OF A MULTISTAKEHOLDER COLLABORATION FOR OUTREACH/EDUCATION PROGRAMMING, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO SHOW THE VALUE OF IMPROVED FOREST MANAGEMENT TO WATER SUPPLY AND QUALITY. IN THE AREA OF (3) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE, SEVERAL SUBPROJECTS INVESTIGATE HOW FOREST LANDS CAN BE BEST MANAGED TO SUPPORT DIVERSE WILDLIFE AND FISHERY RESOURCES. BY MONITORING DEER, COYOTES, REPTILES, AMPHIBIANS, BIRDS, AND FISH, AND MODELING THEIR RESPONSES TO FOREST MANAGEMENT AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, THESE PROJECTS WILL BE ABLE TO MAKE SPECIFIC RECOMMENDATIONS TO LAND MANAGERS TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR NATIVE SPECIES, ENSURE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES SUCH AS HUNTING, FISHING, AND BIRD WATCHING, AND PROJECT HOW ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE MAY IMPACT INDIVIDUAL SPECIES AND COMMUNITIES. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES AND OTHER LAND MANAGERS, INCLUDING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND NGO PARTNERS. IN THE AREA OF (4) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION, ONE SUBPROJECT SEEKS TO ASSESS VISITATION TO TENNESSEE VALLEY AUTHORITY'S (TVA'S) STREAM ACCESS SITES, THE RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED ON-SITE BY VISITORS, AND THE ASSOCIATED ECONOMIC IMPACTS THAT VISITORS TO THESE STREAM ACCESS SITES HAVE ON LOCAL COMMUNITIES ACROSS TWO DIFFERENT REGIONS OF THE TENNESSEE VALLEY. THE PRIMARY METHODS INCLUDE RANDOM STRATIFIED EXIT SURVEYS AT STREAM ACCESS POINTS. USING SURVEY RESULTS COMBINED WITH VISITATION ESTIMATES, IT WILL BE POSSIBLE TO CALCULATE THE DIRECT, INDIRECT, AND INDUCED ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF THE STREAM ACCESS SITES, THUS RESULTING IN AN ESTIMATE OF THE TOTAL ECONOMIC IMPACT OF ALL TVA STREAM ACCESS SITES IN GEORGIA AND NORTH CAROLINA. THE INTENDED AUDIENCES WILL INCLUDE TVA OFFICIALS AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AT THE FEDERAL AND STATE LEVEL. IN THE AREA OF (5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS, ONE SUBPROJECT IS FOCUSED ON PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF NORTH AMERICAN ASH SPECIES WHICH ARE UNDER THREAT OF EXTIRPATION FROM THEIR NATIVE RANGES BY THE EMERALD ASH BORER (EAB). THE PROJECT WILL INITIATE EMBRYOGENIC CULTURES FROM A VARIETY OF SPECIES AND SOURCES, PRODUCE SEEDLINGS FROM EMBRYOGENIC CULTURES, AND OPTIMIZE RECOVERY AND STORAGE PROTOCOLS FOR CONSERVATION PURPOSES. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE OTHER EAB RESEARCHERS, USDA FOREST SERVICE, STATE FORESTRY AGENCIES, AND NGOS SUCH AS TREES ATLANTA. A SECOND SUBPROJECT IN THIS AREA INVESTIGATES THE BIOLOGY AND ECOLOGY OF NATIVE AND EXOTIC BARK AND WOODBORING INSECTS AND EVALUATES BEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO ACHIEVE SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT UNDER VARYING THREAT FROM THESE PESTS. A VARIETY OF EXPERIMENTAL AND OBSERVATIONAL APPROACHES WILL BE USED TO ASSESS THE EFFECTS OF FOREST MANAGEMENT FOREST CONDITION ON SUSCEPTIBILITY TO OUTBREAKS OF BARK AND WOODBORING INSECTS. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE PRIVATE, STATE, AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, LANDOWNERS, AND FORESTERS. IN THE AREA OF (6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS, ONE SUBPROJECT ADDRESSES THE STRUCTURE, PROFITABILITY, AND EFFICIENCY OF SMALL, INDEPENDENT LOGGING BUSINESSES, AND TO HELP THESE BUSINESSES BE MORE EFFICIENT AND PROFITABLE. THE SOUTHERN FOREST INDUSTRY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR $230 BILLION IN ECONOMIC OUTPUT OVER 1 MILLION JOBS. THE FOREST INDUSTRY DEPENDS ON THOUSANDS OF SMALL, INDEPENDENT LOGGING BUSINESSES TO HARVEST AND DELIVER TIMBERTO THEIR MILLS. VERY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE STRUCTURE, PROFITABILITY, AND EFFICIENCY OF THESE BUSINESSES. THIS STUDY WILL CONDUCT A SURVEY OF GEORGIA AND SOUTH CAROLINA LOGGERS TO DETERMINE THEIR BUSINESS STRUCTURE, CAPITAL INVESTMENT, AND CHALLENGES FACED. THE STUDY WILL ALSO INVESTIGATE TRANSPORTATION SAFETY AND COST OF HARVESTING WOOD FOR ENERGY. RESULTS WILL ENABLE LOGGING BUSINESS OWNERS TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS THAT HELP THEM OPERATE MORE PROFITABLY AND DELIVER THE TIMBER NECESSARY TO SUPPORT THE FOREST PRODUCTS INDUSTRY. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE FORESTERS, FOREST PRODUCTS INDUSTRY REPRESENTATIVES, AND RESEARCHERS. FINALLY, IN THE AREA OF (7) DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND THE HARVESTING AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS, ONE SUBPROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE ROLE OF FARM REAL ESTATE IN A MIXED ASSET PORTFOLIO AND INVESTIGATE RISKS FOR TIMBERLAND INVESTMENTS. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE FOREST LANDOWNERS, INVESTORS, TIMBERLAND INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT ORGANIZATIONS, REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUSTS, AND OTHER RESEARCHERS. ANOTHER SUBPROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE NEED FOR A TIMELY ASSESSMENT OF FACTORS AFFECTING FOREST RESOURCES, MARKETS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL VALUES. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE PROVISION OF FOREST ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION, DEVELOPMENT OF INVESTMENT OPPORTUNITIES, AND NEEDS OF FAMILY FOREST OWNERS. A FINAL SUBPROJECT WILL USE IN-DEPTH CASE STUDIES, REPURPOSING OF EXISTING PERFORMANCE DATA, AND REMOTELY SENSED LAND COVER DATA TO EVALUATE THE DYNAMICS AND LANDSCAPE OUTCOMES OF COLLABORATIVE, CROSS-BOUNDARY FOREST MANAGEMENT POLICIES. COLLECTIVELY, THESE OUTCOMES WILL HELP TO IMPROVE THE DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION, AND MONITORING OF POLICIES AND PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO BETTER MANAGE FORESTS FOR ECOLOGICAL, ECONOMIC, AND SOCIAL GOALS.

THE UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA'S INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES (UF/IFAS) HAS FACILITIES LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE - 14 ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS AND TWO SCHOOLS BASED AT THE MAIN CAMPUS IN GAINESVILLE, 18 OFF?CAMPUS FACILITIES, AND AN EXTENSION OFFICE IN EACH OF FLORIDA'S 67 COUNTIES. FLORIDA IS THE THIRD MOST POPULOUS STATE IN THE COUNTRY WITH AN ESTIMATED POPULATION OF 21.9 MILLION IN 2021. THE STATE'S POPULATION IS ESTIMATED TO REACH 27.9 MILLION BY 2050.3 DESPITE THIS POPULATION SIZE, THE STATE OF FLORIDA STILL MAINTAINS A SIGNIFICANT AREA OF FORESTLAND, 17.16 MILLION ACRES (26,807 SQUARE MILES), COMPRISING 50% OF THE STATE'S TOTAL LAND AREA4 WITH MOST OF THE TIMBERLANDS LOCATED NORTH OF ORLANDO5. THE STATE HAS EXTENSIVE NATURAL AND PLANTED PINE AND HARDWOOD FORESTS THAT ARE OFTEN UTILIZED FOR THE COMMERCIAL PRODUCTION OF A WIDE VARIETY OF WOOD BUILDING MATERIALS, CONSUMER PAPER AND PACKAGING PRODUCTS, CHEMICALS, AND RENEWABLE BIOMASS FUELS. NEARLY TWO?THIRDS OF FLORIDA'S FORESTLANDS ARE PRIVATELY OWNED BY INDUSTRY, CORPORATIONS, FAMILIES OR INDIVIDUALS4 WHILE THE REST ARE OWNED BY STATE LOCAL AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENTS5. CONCURRENTLY MAINTAINING THIS TREMENDOUS POPULATION GROWTH AND SIGNIFICANT AREA OF FORESTED LAND INCREASES THE NEED FOR NEW INFORMATION AND TECHNOLOGY RELATED TO FOOD AND FIBER PRODUCTION, WATER CONSERVATION, NATURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION, ALTERNATIVE ENERGY AND CONSERVATION, COMMUNITY RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT, AND INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY WELL?BEING. UF/IFAS RESEARCH SUPPORTS FLORIDA'S AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND RELATED FOOD INDUSTRIES. THESE INDUSTRIES ARE AN ECONOMIC POWERHOUSE IN FLORIDA, DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTING A TOTAL OF $182.6 BILLION IN OUTPUT (REVENUES). AFTER ACCOUNTING FOR MULTIPLIER EFFECTS, THESE INDUSTRIES SUPPORT $159.7 BILLION IN VALUE ADDED CONTRIBUTIONS (14.8% OF GROSS STATE PRODUCT) AND MORE THAN 2.5 MILLION JOBS THROUGHOUT FLORIDA'S ECONOMY IN 2019.1 ACCORDING TO AN EXTENSIVE ANALYSIS PUBLISHED IN 2010 BY A TEAM OF AGRICULTURAL ECONOMISTS, FOR EVERY $1 INVESTED IN U.S. AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT THERE IS A RETURN OF $20 IN BENEFITS FROM INCREASED AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY.2 THE FLORIDA STUDY IS CONDUCTED ANNUALLY BY THE UF/IFAS FOOD AND RESOURCE ECONOMIC DEPARTMENT'S ECONOMIC IMPACT ANALYSIS PROGRAM AND PROVIDES USEFUL DATA AT THE COUNTY AND COMMODITY LEVEL THAT IS DISTRIBUTED TO OUR UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATORS, COMMUNICATORS, LEGISLATORS, AND FUNDING PARTNERS THROUGH INFOGRAPHICS AND BROCHURES AT HTTPS://IFAS.UFL.EDU/EXTENSION?ECONOMIC?CONTRIBUTION?REPORTS/. THE PURPOSE OF THE MCINTIRE?STENNIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE FORESTRY RESEARCH IN THE PRODUCTION, UTILIZATION, AND PROTECTION OF FORESTLAND, TO TRAIN FUTURE FORESTRY SCIENTISTS, AND TO INVOLVE OTHER DISCIPLINES IN FORESTRY RESEARCH. THIS PROGRAM IS USED TO CARRY OUT FORESTRY RESEARCH AT STATE FORESTRY SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES AND TO DEVELOP A TRAINED POOL OF FOREST SCIENTISTS CAPABLE OF CONDUCTING NEEDED FORESTRY RESEARCH UNDER THE FOLLOWING LEGISLATIVELY MANDATED RESEARCH TOPICS6: 1) REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST. 2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION. 3) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE. 4) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION. 5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS. 6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS. 7) DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND THE HARVESTING AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS.  AS OF OCTOBER 2022, UF/IFAS HAS 44 ACTIVE MCINTIRE?STENNIS CAPACITY PROJECTS. HIGHLIGHTS OF SOME OF THOSE PROJECTS AND THEIR LEGISLATIVELY MANDATED RESEARCH TOPICS ARE NOTED BELOW: FOREST DYNAMICS ? BRIDGING SCALES AND IMPROVING MANAGEMENT. LEGISLATIVELY MANDATED FORESTRY RESEARCH TOPICS: 1) REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST. 5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS. 6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS. 7) DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND THE HARVESTING AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS. FORESTS ARE A RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCE THAT PROVIDES JOBS AND NATIONAL SECURITY. THREATS TO THIS RESOURCE INCLUDE DISEASES, PESTS AND DISTURBANCE LIKE NATURAL DISASTERS. THIS RESEARCH AIMS TO DEEPEN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW FOREST CHANGE AND RESPOND TO THOSE THREATS THROUGH THE USE OF OBSERVATIONAL AND MANIPULATIVE EXPERIMENTS TO EXAMINE FOREST RESPONSES THROUGH DATA COLLECTED BY HAND IN THE FOREST. WE ANALYZE THE COLLECTED DATA TO ANSWER THE QUESTIONS ABOUT HOW FORESTS CHANGE IN RESPONSE TO THREATS. SCIENCE TENDS TO BE AN ITERATIVE PROCESS WHERE WE WILL TAKE THE RESULTS FROM OUR EXPERIMENTS AND REPORT THEM, DISCUSS THEM WITH OTHER SCIENTISTS AND FOREST MANAGERS AND ASK FOLLOW?UP QUESTIONS TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE PROCESSES THAT SHAPE FORESTS. ULTIMATELY, WE HOPE TO DERIVE A SET OF PRACTICES THAT MINIMIZE THE RISK OF THREATS TO FOREST SUSTAINABILITY WHILE MAXIMIZING THE PRODUCTIVITY OF FORESTS FOR THE CONTINUED BENEFIT TO SOCIETY. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IT TO EXAMINE FOREST DYNAMICS AT SCALES RELEVANT TO PROCESSES AND DETERMINE HOW THESE PROCESSES MAY BE MANIPULATED TO IMPROVE FOREST MANAGEMENT. 1. ESTABLISH, MONITOR AND ANALYZE LARGE?AREA LONG?TERM RESEARCH PLOTS IN US 2. IDENTIFY MECHANISMS INFLUENCING TREE REGENERATION WITH MANAGEMENT AND DISTURBANCE 3. ENHANCE FOREST PRODUCTIVITY THROUGH EXPERIMENTAL MANAGEMENT AND SPECIES DIVERSITY. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS INTENDED TO BENEFIT FOREST LANDOWNERS, THE PUBLIC AT LARGE AND GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TRAINED AT THE UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA BY PROVIDING ADVANCES IN FOREST SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT. THESE AUDIENCES WILL BE REACHED THROUGH WORKING WITH EXTENSION FACULTY, PRIVATE LAND MANAGERS, ATTENDING LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL CONFERENCES TO DISSEMINATE OUR FINDINGS. UNDERGRADUATES BEING TRAINED AT UF WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE RESEARCH EFFORT TO INCREASE EXPOSURE AND TECHNICAL SKILLS OF FOREST MENSURATION AND MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS. SCHOLARLY WORKS WILL BE GENERATED FROM THIS PROJECT AND RESULTS PRESENTED AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES. THEY WILL ALSO BE DISSEMINATED TO THE BROADEST AUDIENCE INCLUDING THE PUBLIC AT LARGE AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. IT IS EXPECTED THE RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL REVOLUTIONIZE HOW FORESTS ARE MANAGED IN THE TWENTY?FIRST CENTURY. IMPACT OF EMERGING AND BIO? AND NANOTECHNOLOGIES ON WATER RESOURCES. LEGISLATIVELY MANDATED FORESTRY RESEARCH TOPICS: 2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION 6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES MAY PRESENT A DOUBLE?EDGED SWORD TO THE WATER RESOURCES. ON ONE HAND, EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS NANOTECHNOLOGY, BIOTECHNOLOGY, AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY HOLD GREAT PROMISE FOR END?OF?PIPE TREATMENT, IN?SITU REMEDIATION, POLLUTION CONTROL, AND POLLUTANT DETECTION. ON THE OTHER HAND, SOME OF THE TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS NANOTECHNOLOGY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY MAY PRESENT HEALTH AND CONTAMINATION RISKS TO THE WATER RESOURCES AND ECOSYSTEMS BECAUSE THEY INTRODUCE NEW MATERIALS TO THE ENVIRONMENT. THE STATE OF FLORIDA IS FACING MANY WATER ISSUES THAT CAN BE SOLVED WITH THE EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES. HOWEVER, THERE ARE STILL KNOWLEDGE GAPS IN HOW TO PROPERLY APPLY THESE TECHNOLOGIES TO WATER BODIES WITHOUT DAMAGING THE AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS AND NATURAL ENVIRONMENT. THESE KNOWLEDGE GAPS HAVE IMPEDED THE APPLICATIONS OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW SOLUTIONS TO FLORIDA AND GLOBAL WATER PROBLEMS. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED AS A CRITICAL STEP TOWARDS FILLING THE KNOWLEDGE GAPS BY INFORMING THE DEVELOPMENT OF SCIENCE?BASED STRATEGIES TO BEST UTILIZE THE EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES TO SOLVE WATER PROBLEMS. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP NEW METHODS AND TECHNOLOGIES TO SOLVE FLORIDA AND GLOBAL WATER PROBLEMS. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF SCIENCE?BASED STRATEGIES TO BEST UTILIZE THE EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES TO SOLVE WATER PROBLEMS. THE OVERARCHING GOAL/OBJECTIVE IS TO IMPROVE CURRENT UNDERSTANDING OF THE BENEFITS AS WELL AS RISKS OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES TO THE WATER RESOURCES. TO ACCOMPLISH THE OVERALL GOAL/OBJECTIVE, WE PLAN TO PURSUE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES TO: 1. APPLY EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES (E.G., NANOTECHNOLOGY AND COMPUTING TECHNOLOGY) TO ADVANCE CURRENT KNOWLEDGE OF WATER QUALITY MODELING AND MONITORING. 2. DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE LOW?COST MATERIALS FOR WATER TREATMENT/REMEDIATION USING EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES (E.G., NANOTECHNOLOGY AND BIOCHAR TECHNOLOGY), PARTICULARLY WITH RESPECT TO BIOCHAR/AGRICHAR/CHARCOALBASED ADSORBENTS. 3. APPLY EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES (E.G., BIOTECHNOLOGY AND NANOTECHNOLOGY) TO DEVELOP NEW METHODS TO RECLAIM BIOMASS RESIDUES AND WASTEWATER, PARTICULARLY WITH RESPECT TO AGRICULTURAL RESIDUALS. 4. INVESTIGATE THE FATE AND TRANSPORT OF BYPRODUCTS OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES (E.G., ENGINEERED NANOMATERIALS AND CHEMICALS OF EMERGING CONCERNS) IN HYDROLOGIC PATHWAYS. 5. INVESTIGATE THE FATE AND TRANSPORT OF FINE PARTICLES (E.G., PATHOGENS, NATURAL NANOPARTICLES, AND COLLOIDAL PARTICLES) AND PARTICLE?CONTAMINANT COMPLEXES (E.G., HEAVY METALS, NUTRIENTS, AND ORGANIC POLLUTANTS) IN HYDROLOGIC PATHWAYS. BASED ON THE OBJECTIVES, THE PROJECT EXPECTS TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES: 1. THE APPLICATIONS AND BENEFITS OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES TO WATER POLLUTION CONTROL WILL BE BETTER UNDERSTOOD. 2. WATER QUALITY MODELS AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING METHODS WILL BE IMPROVED. 3. LOW?COST WATER TREATMENT AND REMEDIATION TECHNOLOGY (E.G., MODIFIED BIOCHAR) WILL BE DEVELOPED. 4. NEW METHODS TO RECLAIM BIOMASS RESIDUES AND WASTEWATER WILL BE DESIGNED. 5. NEW STRATEGIES OF SUSTAINABLE BIOFUEL PRODUCTION AND CARBON SEQUESTRATION (E.G. BIOCHAR LAND APPLICATION) WILL BE EVALUATED. 6. THE RISKS OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES TO WATER RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT WILL BE BETTER UNDERSTOOD. 7. THE CAPACITY TO PREDICT AND MONITOR THE FATE AND TRANSPORT OF CONTAMINANTS IN WATER BODIES WILL BE ENHANCED. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE FINDINGS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP NEW METHODS AND TECHNOLOGIES TO SOLVE FLORIDA AND GLOBAL WATER PROBLEMS. ASIDE FROM THE INTELLECTUAL CONTRIBUTION OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH TO THE DISCIPLINE AND THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES TO INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS INCLUDING UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS. PROPAGATION, PRODUCTION AND LANDSCAPE ESTABLISHMENT OF COASTAL NATIVE SPECIES FOR ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION. LEGISLATIVELY MANDATED FORESTRY RESEARCH TOPICS: 2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION. 3) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE. 4) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION. 5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS. 6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS. GUIDELINES AND PROTOCOLS FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF COASTAL NATIVE SPECIES FOR USE IN RESTORATION AND IN THE URBAN ENVIRONMENT, WHICH ARE BASED ON PEER?REVIEWED RESEARCH, FOR LAND MANAGERS AND CONSUMERS REMAINS LIMITED. THE RESULTS FROM THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO IMPROVE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF NATIVE SPECIES AVAILABLE FOR COASTAL RESTORATION AND IMPROVE THE SURVIVAL OF PLANTS USED IN RESTORATION PROJECTS ON THE GULF COAST. ADDITIONALLY, PROPOSED OUTPLANTING RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE A RESTORATION CONTEXT AND INTEGRATE DUNE RESTORATION STRATEGIES IN AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT APPROACH TO ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION. GUIDELINES AND PROTOCOLS FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF COASTAL NATIVE SPECIES FOR USE IN RESTORATION AND IN THE URBAN ENVIRONMENT, WHICH ARE BASED ON PEER?REVIEWED RESEARCH, FOR LAND MANAGERS AND CONSUMERS REMAINS LIMITED. THE RESULTS FROM THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO IMPROVE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF NATIVE SPECIES AVAILABLE FOR COASTAL RESTORATION AND IMPROVE THE SURVIVAL OF PLANTS USED IN RESTORATION PROJECTS ON THE GULF COAST. ADDITIONALLY, PROPOSED OUTPLANTING RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE A RESTORATION CONTEXT AND INTEGRATE DUNE RESTORATION STRATEGIES IN AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT APPROACH TO ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION. THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CHARACTERIZE THE PHENOLOGY OF NATIVE COASTAL HERBACEOUS AND WOODY PLANT SPECIES, DEVELOP PROPAGATION, PRODUCTION AND TRANSPLANTING TECHNIQUES FOR THOSE SPECIES THAT HAVE POTENTIAL USE IN HABITAT RESTORATION AND TEST EFFECTS OF PRODUCTION SYSTEMS WITHIN A RESTORATION CONTEXT. THIS CAN BE FURTHER DEFINED AS (1) CHARACTERIZE THE PHENOLOGY OF COASTAL PLANT SPECIES, DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS OF APPROPRIATE TIMING FOR SEED AND CUTTING COLLECTION, AND DETERMINE IN WHAT COMMUNITY POSITIONS (FOREDUNE, SWALE, BACKDUNE, ETC.) THEY NATURALLY OCCUR WITHIN THE COASTAL ISLAND PLANT COMMUNITY; (2) TEST VIABILITY AND STORAGE CAPACITY OF SELECTED COASTAL NATIVE SPECIES SEEDS AND DETERMINE WHICH PREGERMINATIVE TREATMENTS ARE MOST SUCCESSFUL IN INITIATING GERMINATION; (3) IDENTIFY VEGETATIVE PROPAGATION METHODS FOR NATIVE SPECIES AND QUANTIFY THE EFFECTS OF ROOTING HORMONES (IBA, NAA) STOCK TYPE (WILD COLLECTED OR NURSERY CONTAINER GROWN), CUTTING TYPES (DORMANT OR ACTIVELY GROWING, SOFTWOOD OR HARDWOOD, ROOT CUTTINGS OR STEM CUTTINGS), ETC. ON PROPAGATION SUCCESS; (4) QUANTIFY THE EFFECTS OF CONTAINER PRODUCTION PRACTICES (CONTAINER SIZE, DIMENSION, DEPTH) ON THE TRANSPLANT SUCCESS AND SUBSEQUENT GROWTH OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES WITHIN AN ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT RESTORATION CONTEXT; (5) QUANTIFY THE EFFECTS OF POST?PRODUCTION APPLICATION OF MINERAL NUTRITION, IRRIGATION, ROOT?DIPS OR HYDROGELS ON THE SURVIVAL AND GROWTH OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES; AND (6) QUANTIFY EFFECTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL GRADIENTS ON THE GERMINATION OR TRANSPLANT ESTABLISHMENT OF COASTAL NATIVE PLANT SPECIES AND CORRELATE SURVIVAL AND GROWTH OBSERVATIONS WITH PHYSIOLOGICAL VARIABLES THAT INDICATE ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE FLORIDA RESIDENTS WITH OVER 60% OF FLORIDA'S POPULATION LIVING WITHIN 5 MILES OF THE COAST. MUCH OF THE NATURAL AREAS THAT WILL BENEFIT FROM THE IMPACT OF THIS PROJECT ARE PUBLIC LANDS REPRESENTING THE COASTAL DUNE COMMUNITY WHICH IS CONSIDERED ONE OF THE MOST THREATENED NATURAL COMMUNITIES IN FLORIDA. INFORMATION FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE DELIVERED TO THE PUBLIC VIA ADDITIONAL EXTENSION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES SUCH AS THEDUNE RESTORATION MANUAL (MILLER ET AL 2018), PROPAGATION AND PRODUCTION PROTOCOLS, AND RESEARCH PUBLICATIONS. UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS EMPLOYED THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT WILL HAVE OPPORTUNITIES TO PRESENT RESEARCH RESULTS AS PART OF FORMAL CLASSROOM INSTRUCTION, INTERNSHIPS, WORKSHOPS AND PUBLICATION OF ADDITIONAL EXTENSION AND OUTREACH MATERIAL. RESEARCH RESULTS ARE CONTINUALLY INTEGRATED IN THE TEACHING PROGRAM AND WILL BE INTRODUCED INTO CLASSES SUCH AS PLANT PROPAGATION AND SAMPLING TECHNIQUES. METHODS AND TECHNIQUES WILL BE PUBLISHED IN MULTIPLE MEDIA SUCH AS RESEARCH JOURNALS, RESEARCH SYMPOSIA PRESENTATIONS AND POSTERS, AND EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS. IN THE SHORTER TERM, THIS RESEARCH WILL IMPACT THE POTENTIAL TO DESIGN AND ESTABLISH COASTAL DUNE RESTORATION PROJECTS WITH A BROADER RANGE OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES WHICH CONTRIBUTE NOT ONLY TO DUNE STABILIZATION BUT ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO DUNE BUILDING, HABITAT RESTORATION, AND ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION. DEVELOPING GUIDELINES FOR PROPAGATION, PRODUCTION AND WHEN, HOW, AND WHERE COASTAL NATIVE SPECIES CAN BE PLANTED INTO THE REDEVELOPING DUNE SYSTEM WILL INCREASE THE EFFICIENCY AND COST EFFECTIVENESS OF RESTORATION PROJECTS AND POTENTIALLY IDENTIFY NATIVE PLANTS USEFUL FOR COASTAL AND URBAN LANDSCAPES. DOCUMENTING PHENOLOGICAL DATA FOR COASTAL DUNE SPECIES WILL ASSIST IN ESTABLISHING TIMELINES FOR SEED OR CUTTING COLLECTION ESSENTIAL TO PRODUCTION OF THESE COASTAL DUNE SPECIES. THESE DATA WILL ASSIST PARK MANAGERS IN SCHEDULING OF MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PRESCRIBED FIRE OR MOWING WHICH MAY IMPACT SEED PRODUCTION, DISPERSAL, OR SUCCESSFUL RECRUITMENT OF SEEDLINGS. THIS DATA WILL ALSO PROVIDE INFORMATION NECESSARY FOR DESIGNING MEANINGFUL EXPERIMENTS WHICH MAY LEAD TO AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE RANGE OF ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSES THE TEST SPECIES MAY OR WILL NOT WITHSTAND. 1 ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTIONS OF AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND FOOD INDUSTRIES IN FLORIDA COUNTIES, 2019. THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION HAS A LONG TRADITION OF FOREST MANAGEMENT, WHICH IS IMPORTANT TO THE LOCAL CULTURE. FOREST PRODUCT RELATED EXPENDITURES ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO THE SIGNIFICANTLY TO THE ECONOMY. THESE FORESTS ALSO SUPPORT POPULATIONS OF WILDLIFE, WHICH ARE IMPORTANT GAME SPECIES, FOREST HEALTH INDICATOR SPECIES, AND SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN. EXAMPLES OF THESE SPECIES ARE THE BOBCAT, WILD TURKEY, WHITE-TAILED DEER, AND SIKA DEER. UNDERSTANDING THE IMPORTANCE OF FOREST MANAGEMENT TO THE ECOLOGY OF EACH OF THESE SPECIES IS INTEGRAL TO EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THEIR POPULATIONS AND CAN DIRECT FOREST MANAGEMENT TO IMPROVE HABITAT FOR THESE SPECIES. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL ESTIMATE SURVIVAL AND SPATIAL ECOLOGY OF FOREST WILDLIFE IN THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL INVESTIGATE METHODS TO ESTIMATE FOREST WILDLIFE POPULATION ABUNDANCE. WE PUBLISHED OUR RESULTS IN PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS AND IN POPULAR ARTICLES ACCESSIBLE TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. WE PRESENTED OUR DATA AT LOCAL, REGIONAL AND NATIONAL WILDLIFE CONFERENCES TO INFORM FELLOW RESEARCHERS, BIOLOGISTS, AND WILDLIFE MANAGERS ABOUT OUR RESULTS. OUR TARGET AUDIENCE IS WILDLIFE BIOLOGIST, FORESTERS, HUNTERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE WILDLIFE BIOLOGIST IN STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES SEE THE IMMEDIATE BENEFIT OF SOUND DATA TO USE FOR SCIENCE-BASED DECISION MAKING. FORESTERS SEE THE IMMEDIATE BENEFITS OF SOUND DATA TO SET POPULATION GOALS SUCH THAT DEER DO NOT NEGATIVELY IMPACT FOREST REGENERATION. HUNTERS HAVE A STRONG INTEREST IN THE MORE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THE RESOURCE THEY UTILIZE. THE GENERAL PUBLIC BENEFITS FROM REDUCED HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTS VIA MORE EFFECTIVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT BY RESOURCE AGENCIES.

DR. PAUL M. LUKACS, MCINTIRE-STENNIS ADMINISTRATIVE-TECHNICAL REPRESENTATIVE (A-TR) W.A. FRANKE COLLEGE OF FORESTRY AND CONSERVATION, UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA, MISSOULA, MT 59812 THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA'S PROGRAM OF RESEARCH IN FY2023 CONSISTS OF SIX CONTINUING PROJECTS AND ONE NEW TRANSDISCIPLINARY PROJECT - THAT ADVANCE SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE ACROSS THE RANGE OF TOPICAL AREAS TARGETED BY THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY PROGRAM. FORESTS IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES SERVE MULTIPLE ROLES ON THE LANDSCAPE. FORESTS STORE CARBON, PRODUCE TIMBER, SUPPORT BIODIVERSITY, PROVIDE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, AND SERVE AS RANGE FOR LIVESTOCK. BALANCING ALL THESE OPPORTUNITIES REQUIRES AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE PROCESSES SUPPORTING EACH AND, PERHAPS MORE IMPORTANTLY, THE INTERACTIONS AMONG THE VARIOUS USES. OUR RESEARCH PROJECTS AIM TO UNDERSTAND THE INTERCONNECTED PROCESSES PROVIDING FOR MULTIPLE ROLES OF FORESTS ON THE LANDSCAPE. WE SEEK TO UNDERSTAND HOW CHANGES IN ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS POTENTIALLY IMPACT EACH FOREST USE. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL INVESTIGATE 1) CAPACITY TO STORE CARBON AND OUR ABILITY TO MEASURE AND PREDICT STORAGE, 2) SEED BANK COMPOSITION AND POTENTIAL FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE RESTORATION OF FOREST AND RANGE IN THE EVENT OF A CHANGE IN STRUCTURE, 3) WILDLIFE RESPONSES TO TIMBER, RANGE, AND RECREATIONAL USE, AND 4) SOCIAL RESPONSES TO FORESTS INCLUDING RECREATION AND VALUES. OUR RESEARCH ALIGNS WITH THE MANDATED RESEARCH AREAS OF THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS ACT AND IT ALSO ALIGNS WITH THE USDA STRATEGIC PLAN GOALS 1 AND 2. WE WILL LEVERAGE THE UM LUBRECHT EXPERIMENTAL FOREST IN ADDITION TO OTHER SITES AROUND THE WESTERN UNITED STATES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE INTERCONNECTEDNESS OF FOREST SYSTEMS. WE WILL CONTINUE THE FIRE AND FIRE SURROGATE STUDY AS A LONG-TERM LONGITUDINAL STUDY TO UNDERSTAND FIRE AND THINNING PRACTICES. WE WILL EXAMINE CARBON STORAGE MEASUREMENT AND PREDICTION TOOLS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW TO PLAN FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT AS A CARBON STORAGE SYSTEM. FURTHERMORE, WE WILL EXAMINE SEED BANK RESILIENCY AND WATER RESOURCES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW FORESTS CAN BE RESTORED AFTER STRUCTURAL CHANGES SUCH AS WILDFIRE AND TIMBER HARVEST. FOREST RESOURCES EXTEND BEYOND VEGETATION TO WILDLIFE AND PEOPLE WHO USE THEM. WE WILL FURTHER CONSIDER HOW MANAGEMENT FOR CARBON STORAGE CAN BE LINKED TO MANAGEMENT FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT AND RECREATION. WE WILL EXPAND METHODS FOR MEASURING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS USING REMOTELY TRIGGERED CAMERAS TO ESTIMATE WILDLIFE ABUNDANCE, DIVERSITY, AND USE. CAMERAS REPRESENT A METHOD THAT COULD BE EMPLOYED ACROSS A WIDE RANGE OF FOREST MANAGERS FROM SMALL PRIVATE FORESTS TO LARGE-SCALE FEDERAL LANDS. THE RESULTS OF OUR RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE FOR LAND MANAGERS SEEKING TO BALANCE MULTIPLE OBJECTIVES IN THEIR FORESTS. WE WILL DEVELOP METHODS FOR MEASURING KEY FEATURES SUCH AS SEED BANK RESOURCES AND WILDLIFE. WE WILL ALSO DEVELOP INSIGHTS FOR MANAGING FOREST STANDS WITH FIRE AND THINNING AS THEY GROW WITH AN EYE TOWARD CARBON STORAGE CAPACITY.

THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION MAINTAINS A SMALL BUT IMPORTANT FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM FINANCED BY MCINTIRE-STENNIS FUNDS. THESE FUNDS SUPPORT RESEARCH ON USEFUL TECHNOLOGIES FOR REFORESTATION PROJECTS AND FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF WATERSHEDS RELATED TO FORESTS, ON THE ECONOMIC VIABILITY OF DEVELOPING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN FORESTS, AND ON ESTABLISHING USEFUL BASELINE DATA FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT PLANS OF SELECTED FORESTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF RESEARCH ACTIVITIES INCLUDE LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES SUCH AS THE DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES, THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND THE PUERTO RICO PLANNING BOARD; RESIDENTS LIVING IN AREAS SURROUNDING THE FORESTS SELECTED FOR RESEARCH ACTIVITIES; THE SCIENTIFIC AND ACADEMIC COMMUNITY; AND PRIVATE AND PUBLIC ENTITIES INTERESTED IN REFORESTATION PROJECTS IN AREAS WITH LIMITED WATER SUPPLY. ACTIVITIES PLANNED INCLUDE: EXPERIMENTS WITH TECHNOLOGIES FOR OVERCOMING DROUGHT MORTALITY OF JUVENILE TREES IN REFORESTATION PROJECTSNALYSES OF SEDIMENT IN THREE RESERVOIRS CONSTRUCTED PRIOR TO 1950 TO RECONSTRUCT THE ECOLOGICAL EVOLUTION (>70 YR) OF THEIR WATERSHEDS AND ULTIMATELY USE THE INFORMATION TO DEVELOP A LOCAL FRAMEWORK FOR THE PLANNING OF SUSTAINABLE MULTIFUNCTIONAL LANDSCAPES IN PUERTO RICO.  CHOICE EXPERIMENTS TO EXAMINE RESIDENTS' WILLINGNESS TO PAY FOR RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN SELECTED FORESTS AND COST-BENEFIT ANALYSES OF DEVELOPING THE INTENDED RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A LONG-TERM, ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH STATION FOR THE STUDY OF LAND COVER CHANGE, CARBON AND BIODIVERSITY LINKAGES ON SERPENTINE SOILS, AS WELL AS THE BENEFITS NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES MAY GAIN FROM THEIR INVOLVEMENT IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE STATION. DELIVERABLES FROM PROJECTS' ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PUBLICATION IN PEER REVIEWED JOURNALS AND POPULAR MEDIA OUTLETS (NEWSPAPERS, PODCASTS, SOCIAL MEDIA), POSTERS AND ORAL PRESENTATIONS ATSCIENTIFIC MEETINGS DEPICTING PROJECT RESULTS; AN UPDATED GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEM CONTAINING LAND COVER, SOIL, AND GEOLOGICAL INFORMATION LAYERS OF THE THREE MAJOR WATERSHEDS OF PUERTO RICO; PROOF OF- CONCEPT OF UPSCALED EARTH-WATER DISTILLATION TECHNOLOGY FOR JUVENILE TREE IRRIGATION AND HUMAN CONSUMPTION IN REMOTE ARID AND SEMIARID ENVIRONMENTS; AND INCREASED DOCUMENTATION OF INTERACTIONS BETWEEN LAND COVER CHANGE, CARBON STORAGE CAPACITY AND BIODIVERSITY OF SERPENTINE SOILS IN THE CARIBBEAN. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE AN INCREASED AWARENESS OF THE VALUE OF FORESTS ON THE ISLAND; THE INCORPORATION OF ECOLOGICAL TRADE-OFFS AS PART OF THE PLANNING PROCESS FOR SUSTAINABLE MULTIFUNCTIONAL LANDSCAPES IN PUERTO RICO; INCREASED PUBLIC AWARENESS AND USE OF SMALL COMMERCIALLY AVAILABLE WATER-VAPOR CONDENSATION DEVICES FOR MORE EFFECTIVE REFORESTATION IN ARID ENVIRONMENTS; AND INCREASED INFORMATION ON THE BENEFITS FROM CONSERVATION AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THAT FOREST LANDS CAN PROVIDE TONEIGHBORING RESIDENTS AND ACADEMIC COMMUNITIES.

MCINTIRE-STENNIS FUNDS FORESTRY RESEARCH UNDER THE FOLLOWING RESEARCH TOPICS: 1) REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST; 2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION; 3) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE; 4) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION; 5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS; 6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS; 7) DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND THE HARVESTING AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS. STATE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (SAES) FUNDED MCINTIRE-STENNIS ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PRACTICAL RESEARCH PROJECTS FOCUSED ON FORESTS AND FORESTRY ACROSS URBAN TO RURAL AREAS.RESEARCH ACTIVITIES INCLUDE OBSERVATIONAL AND EXPERIMENTAL FORESTRY AND FOREST ECOSYSTEM STUDIES, ASSESSMENTS OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICE PROVISIONING AND THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND POLICIES, AND ASSESSMENT OF THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF FOREST MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, AND POLICY-MAKING. SAES PROJECTS RESULT IN PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH AND PUBLICATIONS, OUTREACH AND EXTENSION-FOCUSED MATERIALS FOR FORESTRY AND OTHER LAND MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS AND STAKEHOLDERS BASED ON THOSE RESEARCH OUTCOMES, TRAINING OF GRADUATE STUDENTS IN FORESTRY AND RELATED FIELDS, AND PUBLIC AND PROFESSIONAL-FACING MEDIA ON PROJECT RESULTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES FOR OUR MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECTS INCLUDE WOODLAND OWNERS AND PUBLIC BENEFICIARIES OF FOREST ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, FORESTRY AND OTHER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS, LOCAL AND REGIONAL FORESTRY AND LAND MANAGEMENT/CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, AS WELL AS STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES.

UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS SYSTEM DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE (DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE) FACULTY, STAFF AND FACILITIES ARE LOCATED ON SEVEN U NIVERSITY CAMPUSES, FOUR RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CENTERS, SIX RESEARCH STATIONS, TWO EXTENSION CENTERS, AND IN ALL 75 COUNTIES. A FIFTH REGIONAL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CENTER IS CURRENTLY UNDER CONSTRUCTION. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE REMAINS COMMITTED TO THIS STATEWIDE INFRASTRUCTURE WITH A PRESENCE IN ALL 75 ARKANSAS COUNTIES, ENSURING THAT RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION EDUCATORS ARE READILY AVAILABLE TO ADDRESS THE SCIENCE AND BUSINESS OF AGRICULTURE AND THE BROADER NEEDS OF FAMILIES AND THE COMMUNITIES WE SERVE. CONSISTENT WITH THE LAND GRANT MISSION, DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION FACULTY HAVE A LONG HISTORY OF PROVIDING LEADERSHIP IN THE DEVELOPMENT, DISSEMINATION AND DELIVERY OF INNOVATIVE PRACTICES AND EMERGING TECHNOLOGY. DIVISION RESEARCHERS CONDUCT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH FOR ARKANSAS PRODUCERS, BUSINESSES, COMMUNITIES, AND FAMILIES. COUNTY AGENTS AND SPECIALISTS STRIVE TO PROVIDE THE BEST SCIENCE?BASED RECOMMENDATIONS AVAILABLE. ALTHOUGH STAKEHOLDERS ARE EXPOSED TO MULTIPLE SOURCES AND COPIOUS AMOUNTS OF INFORMATION AND DATA, THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE REMAINS A RELIABLE SOURCE OF IMPARTIAL AND SCIENCE?BASED RECOMMENDATIONS, INDEPENDENT OF FINANCIAL OR PHILOSOPHICAL INTERESTS. ALTHOUGH MOST IN?PERSON EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES HAVE RESUMED, THE DIVISION WILL CONTINUE TO DELIVER TIMELY AND RESPONSIVE DISTANCE ED UCATION WEBINARS AND RESOURCES IN 2023 TO ENSURE WIDE?SPREAD ACCESS TO EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS BY ARKANSANS. THIS INCLUDES MONTHLY WEBINARS THROUGH THE NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL LAW CENTER ON CURRENT AND EMERGING IMPORTANT AGRICULTURAL, ENVIRONMENTAL AND FOOD LAW TOPICS. ONLINE COURSES ARE AVAILABLE 24/7/365 THROUGH THE DIVISION'S WEBSITE (HTTP://COURSES.UADA.EDU). DIVISION FACULTY ALSO ADDRESS TIMELY TOPICS OF INTEREST TO ARKANSANS THROUGH VIRTUAL EVENTS AND OTHER WEB?BASED PROGRAMMING. THE FOCUS OF WORK CONDUCTED BY THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE CONTINUES TO BE GUIDED ANNUALLY BY GRASSROOTS, COMMUNITY?BASED INPUT FROM A DIVERSE RANGE OF ARKANSAS CITIZENS; MAINLY THROUGH THE USE OF COUNTY EXTENSION COUNCILS AND OTHER LOCAL AND PROGRAM ADVISORY GROUPS. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE FORMALLY ENGAGED A LARGE POOL OF STAKEHOLDERS (INCLUDING INDIVIDUAL CLIENTELE, PRODUCERS, SCHOOLS, PARTNER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS, STATE GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, UNDERSERVED GROUPS, AND LEGISLATORS) IN THE DESIGN AND DE VELOPMENT OF THE 2017?2023 STRATEGIC PLAN. BASED ON BROAD STAKEHOLDER FEEDBACK, THE DIVISION IDENTIFIED FIVE AREAS TO FOCUS OUR EFFORTS: AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING, ACCESS TO SAFE AND NUTRITIOUS FOOD, STRENGTHENING ARKANSAS FAMILIES, BUILDING COMMUNITIES AND STRENGTHENING ECONOMIES, AND NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT. THESE FIVE EMPHASIS AREAS HELP TO PROVIDE STRATEGIC LOCAL GUIDANCE FOR DIVISION RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AND HELP TO SUPPORT INTEGRATED RESEARCH/EXTENSION EFFORTS THAT ALIGN WITH THE NIFA SCIENCE EMPHASIS AREAS. AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING A CRITICAL NEED IN ARKANSAS, AND NATIONWIDE, IS TO ENSURE FARM AND FOREST ENTERPRISES ARE PROFITABLE AND SUSTAINABLE TO MEET THE DEMANDS FOR SAFE FOOD, FIBER, AND FUEL. THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY MUST CONTEND WITH MORE REGULATIONS, HIGHER INPUT COSTS, FLUCTUATING COMMODITY PRICES, CLIMATE EXTREMES, AND GLOBAL TRADE POLICIES. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL FOCUS ON INCREASING PRODUCTIVITY IN A HUMANE AND SUSTAINABLE MANNER WHILE DECREASING COSTS THROUGH EFFICIENT USE OF RESOURCES. PLANT SYSTEMS EMPHASIZE ECONOMICS, ENVIRONMENT, GENETICS AND BREEDING, WEEDS, DISEASE, PEST MANAGEMENT, SAFE HANDLING AND STORAGE, FOOD PROCESSING, CULTURAL PRACTICES, AND SOIL FERTILITY.  ANIMAL SYSTEMS EMPHASIZE GENETICS, REPRODUCTION, ECONOMICS, NUTRITION, WASTE MANAGEMENT, PHYSIOLOGY, ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS, HEALTH, AND ANIMAL WELLBEING. COMMON TO BOTH PLANT AND ANIMAL SYSTEMS IS THE APPROPRIATE USE OF NEW PRODUCTS AND TECHNOLOGY. ACCESS TO SAFE AND NUTRITIOUS FOODS THE AVAILABILITY OF SAFE AND NUTRITIOUS FOOD IS VITAL TO FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS IN ALL COMMUNITIES. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE WORKS TO PROMOTE HEALTHY DIETS THROUGH RESEARCH AND PUBLIC EDUCATION EFFORTS THAT TARGET OBESITY AND ENCOURAGE BETTER CONSUMER HABITS THROUGH PROGRAMS SUCH AS THE EXPANDED FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAM (EFNEP) AND SNAP?ED. EFNEP EMPOWERS INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN, WITH LIMITED INCOME, TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, ATTITUDE, AND BEHAVIOR CHANGES NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN NUTRITIONALLY SOUND DIETS AND ENHANCE PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT. SNAP?ED PROVIDES NUTRITION EDUCATION TO FOOD STAMP RECIPIENTS AND THOSE INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WHO ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE NUTRITION ASSISTANCE TO HELP CONSUMERS MAKE BETTER CHOICES ABOUT WHAT TO EAT TO STAY ACTIVE AND LIVE BETTER. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE SEEKS TO STRENGTHEN FOOD SYSTEMS THROUGH RESEARCH AND INNOVATION. THE LONGTERM GROWTH OF THE FOOD INDUSTRY IN ARKANSAS IS DEPENDENT UPON THE INDUSTRY'S ABILITY TO INNOVATE, TO RESPOND TO CONSUMERS' TASTE AND EXPECTATIONS, TO EMPLOY A QUALITY WORKFORCE AND TO MINIMIZE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS AND THE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES WHILE MAINTAINING ECONOMIC VIABILITY. PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY LEADERS AND AGENCIES ARE PURSUED TO INCREASE ACCESS TO NUTRITIOUS FOODS. EXTENSION PROGRAMS HELP PEOPLE FROM MANY BACKGROUNDS UNDERSTAND HOW TO MAKE WISE NUTRITIONAL CHOICES AND STRETCH FOOD DOLLARS BY COOKING FOR THEMSELVES AND UTILIZE A WIDER VARIETY OF FOODS. THE DIVISION ALSO STRIVES TO ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY THROUGH RESEARCH AND TEACHING BEST PRACTICES TO ALL WHO HANDLE FOOD, FROM FIELD TO TABLE. THIS INCLUDES EDUCATION RELATED TO FEDERAL AND STATE LAWS, SUCH AS HOW TO ADHERE TO THE FDA'S PRODUCE SAFETY RULE AND MEETING CERTIFICATION REQUIREMENTS OF THE ARKANSAS DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH THROUGH SERVSAFE, A FOOD SAFETY CERTIFICATION PROGRAM FOR INDIVIDUALS WHO WORK IN FOOD HANDLING OR FOOD SERVICE AND RELATED INDUSTRIES. EXTENSION EDUCATORS PROVIDE EVIDENCE?BASED INFORMATION TO ENSURE THAT ARKANSANS ARE EQUIPPED WITH THE BEST FOOD SAFETY INFORMATION TO KEEP THEIR FAMILIES SAFE FROM FOODBORNE ILLNESSES AND OTHER FOOD?RELATED SAFETY ISSUES. STRENGTHENING ARKANSAS FAMILIES IT IS CRITICAL TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES THAT AFFECT FAMILIES, CONSUMERS, AND THE COMMUNITIES IN WHICH THEY LIVE. THE MENTAL, PHYSICAL, AND FINANCIAL WELL?BEING OF FAMILIES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF YOUTH ARE ESSENTIAL TO BUILDING PROSPERITY FOR ARKANSANS. THE DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE IS RESPONDING TO THESE NEEDS BY DELIVERING RESEARCH?BASED PROGRAMS TO REDUCE STRESS, IMPROVE MENTAL HEALTH, STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS, INCREASE FINANCIAL STABILITY, AND IMPROVE WELL?BEING FOR ARKANSANS. 4?H CLUBS, ACTIVITIES AND EVENTS ACROSS ARKANSAS INVOLVE YOUNG PEOPLE IN HANDS?ON EDUCATION AND SERVICE?LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES THAT ENHANCED THEIR LIFE SKILLS, INCLUDING DECISION MAKING, PROBLEM SOLVING, CRITICAL THINKING, COMMUNICATIONS, AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES. 4?H CONVEYS TO THE PUBLIC THAT ALL YOUTH HAVE VALUE. STRIVING TO REACH A DIVERSE POPULATION IS KEY TO DEVELOPING CURRICULUM, OFFERING RECOGNITION, AND TEACHING STRONG LEADERSHIP SKILLS TO REPRESENT OUR STATE'S CURRENT DEMOGRAPHICS. BUILDING COMMUNITIES AND STRENGTHENING ECONOMIES CHANGES IN THE ECONOMY, TECHNOLOGY AND POPULATION ARE TRANSFORMING HOW ARKANSANS LIVE AND WORK. THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED FOR BUSINESSES TO UNDERSTAND THEIR CHANGING ECONOMIC ENVIRONMENT AND EFFECTIVELY EMPLOY TOOLS AND RESOURCES. AT THE SAME TIME, THE LABOR FORCE REQUIRES ENHANCED SKILLS AND TRAINING TO SUCCEED IN TODAY'S GLOBAL ECONOMY. AT A TIME WHEN MANY RURAL AREAS ARE LOSING POPULATION, COMMUNITIES MUST TAKE A PROACTIVE APPROACH TO CREATE A HIGH QUALITY OF LIFE AND PLACE IF THEY WANT TO SURVIVE. EFFECTIVE AND INCLUSIVE LEADERS WORKING WITH ENGAGED CITIZENS ARE KEY TO THIS EFFORT. TO ADDRESS THESE CRITICAL NEEDS, PROGRAMS FOCUS ON FOUR AREAS: ECONOMIC VIABILITY AND SUSTAINABILITY; ENTREPRENEURSHIP IN EVOLVING ECONOMIES; LEADERSHIP AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT; AND QUALITY OF LIFE AND PLACE. NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT ARKANSAS FACES CRITICAL NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES INCLUDING GROUNDWATER DECLINE IN EASTERN ARKANSAS FROM IRRIGATION, WATER QUALITY CONCERNS FROM ANIMAL MANURES, SEDIMENT LOSS FROM CROPLAND AND URBAN STORMWATER. WE ALL SHARE CONCERNS FOR SOIL HEALTH, AIR QUALITY, PROTECTION OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES OF FORESTS AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, BUT AGRICULTURE IS UNDER SCRUTINY TO REDUCE IMPACT ON NATURAL RESOURCES. WE FOCUS ON UNBIASED RESEARCH AND SCIENCE?BASED EXTENSION EFFORTS TO BALANCE CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES. PROGRAMS, SUCH AS ARKANSAS DISCOVERY FARMS AND THE CENTER FOR AGRICULTURAL AND RURAL SUSTAINABILITY, WILL COLLABORATE WITH FARMERS, LANDOWNERS, AND INDUSTRY TO DELIVER INNOVATIVE, SUSTAINABLE PROGRAMS TO ENSURE PROPER CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES. IN ADDITION TO ANNUAL STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT ACTIVITIES TO INFORM RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS, THE DIVISION WILL LAUNCH A FORMAL AND COMPREHENSIVE EFFORT IN 2023 TO IDENTIFY PRIORITIES FOR THE ORGANIZATION'S NEW STRATEGIC PLAN WITH INPUT FROM STAKEHOLDERS THAT REPRESENT THE DIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS FEDERAL AWARD IS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES ALIGNED WITH THE BROAD GOALS OF THE USDA AND STAKEHOLDER GROUPS IN ARIZONA. ACTIVITIES ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING CRITICAL ISSUES: ENSURING A SUSTAINABLE, PROFITABLE, AND COMPETITIVE FOOD AND FIBER SYSTEM IN ARIZONA; ENHANCING NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT; IMPROVING THE HEALTH, SAFETY, AND ECONOMIC SECURITY OF ARIZONA FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES; PREPARING ARIZONA YOUTH TO BE PRODUCTIVE CITIZENS; AND PREPARING ARIZONA'S AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY FOR SOLUTIONS OF THE FUTURE. PROJECTS ARE IDENTIFIED THROUGH A COMPETITIVE PROCESS, ARE ADMINISTERED IN ALIGNMENT WITH THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE HATCH, HATCH MULTISTATE, ANIMAL HEALTH AND SMITH-LEVER PROGRAMS, AND CONTINUE THE LONG-STANDING INTEGRATION BETWEEN RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WITH STRONG STAKEHOLDER INPUT. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE NEW KNOWLEDGE LEADING TO PEER REVIEWED AND GENERAL PUBLICATIONS, IMPROVEMENTS IN THE FUNCTIONING, PRODUCTIVITY AND LONG-TERM HEALTH OF ARIZONA'S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM, IMPROVED HEALTH, AND WELLBEING OF THE CITIZENS OF ARIZONA, INCLUDING RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES, AND ENHANCED ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ACROSS THE STATE. BENEFICIARIES EXTEND ACROSS THE STATE WITH EMPHASIS ON RURAL AND TRIBAL AREAS.

ALASKA IS RECOGNIZED FOR ITS IMMENSE SIZE, DISPERSED POPULATION AND ITS CULTURAL, GEOGRAPHIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL DIVERSITY. THE STATE REPRESENTS A MAJOR REGION OF RENEWABLE AND NONRENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES IN THE UNITED STATES. ITS 365 MILLION ACRES INCLUDE THE NATION'S LARGEST OIL RESERVES, COAL DEPOSITS AND THE TWO LARGEST NATIONAL FORESTS. THE STATE CONTAINS THE LARGEST TERRESTRIAL BIOME ON EARTH - THE BOREAL FOREST - THAT IT SHARES WITH OTHER NORTHERN LOCATIONS. ALASKA HAS A VARIED GEOGRAPHY THAT OFFERS SOILS FOR PRODUCTION OF FOOD, FIBER AND BIOMASS FUELS AS WELL AS FOR A MULTITUDE OF RECREATIONAL AND TOURISM ACTIVITIES. ALASKA'S NATURAL RESOURCES HAVE HISTORICALLY BEEN THE FOUNDATION OF THE STATE'S ECONOMY, THOUGH RESOURCE INDUSTRIES HAVE BEEN MOSTLY EXTRACTIVE IN NATURE. ALASKA'S ECONOMY HAS BECOME DEPENDENT UPON REVENUES RELATED TO PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT. TO DIVERSIFY ITS ECONOMY, THE STATE IS EXPANDING AND EXAMINING POTENTIAL IN MOVING TOWARD NON-PETROLEUM NATURAL RESOURCES FOR ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES THAT ARE COST-EFFECTIVE AND SUSTAINABLE. THE USE AND MANAGEMENT OF THESE RESOURCES IS A PREDOMINANT FORCE IN THE PLANNING AND DELIVERY OF ANY TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND ENGAGEMENT PROGRAMS. THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS (UAF) IN GENERAL AND AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY EXPERIMENT STATION (AFES), IN PARTICULAR, MEET THE CHALLENGES OF INCREASING DEMANDS FOR RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT THAT ARE RELEVANT TO SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF ALASKA'S RESOURCES AND BRING COMMUNITY IDEAS TO THE UNIVERSITY FOR FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE STATE'S RESOURCES. WHILE ALASKA IMPORTS A HIGH PERCENTAGE OF FOODS AND OTHER AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS, GROWERS IN THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR PRODUCE FRESH MARKET POTATOES, VEGETABLES AND HERBS; FORAGES, GRAINS AND MANUFACTURED LIVESTOCK FEEDS; CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT PRODUCTS, WHICH INCLUDE BEDDING PLANTS, FLORALS, LANDSCAPE ORNAMENTALS AND SHORT SEASON VEGETABLES; AND A VARIETY OF NICHE MARKET CROPS. LIVESTOCK ENTERPRISES IN ALASKA ARE VARIED IN SIZE AND SPECIES OF ANIMAL IN PRODUCTION. PRODUCERS NEED INFORMATION SPECIFIC TO NORTHERN LATITUDES THAT WILL PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT AND ENSURE AN ABUNDANT AND SAFE FOOD SUPPLY. AS THE POPULATION GROWS, MORE LOCALLY AND REGIONALLY PRODUCED FOOD WILL BE NEEDED TO PROVIDE GREATER FOOD SECURITY. MANY ALASKANS LIVE A SUBSISTENCE LIFESTYLE OR SUPPLEMENT THEIR DIETS WITH FISH AND GAME MEAT. HIGH ENERGY COSTS REMAIN A CRITICAL ISSUE, PARTICULARLY IN RURAL ALASKA, WHERE FUEL OIL CAN COST DOUBLE AND GASOLINE CAN COST TRIPLE THE AVERAGE PRICE PER GALLON COMPARED TO URBAN AREAS. RESEARCH WILL CONTINUE TO FOCUS ON NEW AND ALTERNATIVE SOURCES OF ENERGY, WOOD AND BIOMASS AND ENERGY CONSERVATION. AFES WILL WORK TO PROVIDE NEW INFORMATION TO MANAGE RENEWABLE RESOURCES AND TO IMPROVE TECHNOLOGY FOR ENHANCING THE ECONOMIC WELL-BEING AND QUALITY OF LIFE AT HIGH LATITUDES. RESEARCH WILL ALSO FOCUS ON THE HEALTH OF OUR LARGEST FOREST BIOME, INCLUDING UNDERSTANDING THE IMPACTS OF A CHANGING CLIMATE, INSECT INFESTATION, AND LAND USE. ECOLOGICAL DROUGHT IS IMPACTING FOREST FIRE THREAT AND BARK BEETLE INFESTATION, WHICH IS DAMAGING FOREST NATURAL RESOURCES THAT ARE CRITICAL FOR TOURISM, FIREWOOD AVAILABILITY, AND INCREASED FIRE RISK. WHILE FORESTERS, FARMERS AND LAND MANAGERS USE RESEARCH RESULTS, ALL ALASKANS BENEFIT FROM THE WISE USE OF LAND RESOURCES.  RESEARCH PROJECTS WILL BE IN RESPONSE TO REQUESTS FROM PRODUCERS, INDUSTRIES, AND STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES FOR INFORMATION ON PLANT, ANIMAL AND SOIL SCIENCES, FOREST SCIENCES AND RESOURCES MANAGEMENT. AFES PRIORITIES, LIKE NATIONAL PRIORITIES, ARE TO ENHANCE SUSTAINABILITY OF FOOD, FOREST, AND AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; ADAPT TO AND MITIGATE THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE; SUPPORT ENERGY SECURITY THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES; ENSURE A SAFE, SECURE AND ABUNDANT FOOD SUPPLY; STRENGTHEN ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES; AND SUPPORT INDIVIDUAL, FAMILY ANDCOMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND RESILIENCE. EXPERIMENT STATION RESEARCHERS WILL CONTINUE TO PUBLISH RESEARCH IN SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS, CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS, BOOKS, AND IN EXPERIMENT STATION BULLETINS, CIRCULARS, NEWSLETTERS, RESEARCH PROGRESS REPORTS AND MISCELLANEOUS PUBLICATIONS. SCIENTISTS WILL ALSO DISSEMINATE THEIR FINDINGS THROUGH CONFERENCES, PUBLIC PRESENTATIONS, WORKSHOPS AND OTHER PUBLIC INFORMATION PROGRAMS LIKE WEBSITES AND BLOGS. NATURAL RESOURCES, ECOSYSTEMS <(>&<)> FORESTRY: RESEARCH WILL ADDRESS STAKEHOLDER NEEDS FOR UNBIASED, SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION ABOUT NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ISSUES IN FORESTRY, MINING, WATER, RECREATION AND ALTERNATIVE, SUSTAINABLE ENERGY SOURCES. ALASKA'S FOREST AND AGRICULTURAL RESOURCE POTENTIAL FOR BIOENERGY PRODUCTION IS IMMENSE BUT REQUIRES MORE RESEARCH. THE ECONOMIC POTENTIAL OF ALASKA'S FORESTS IS UNDER-REALIZED IN TIMBER AND NON-TIMBER PRODUCTS. THE FOREST ECOSYSTEM AND AGRICULTURAL LANDS CAN PLAY A ROLE IN DIVERSIFYING THE ECONOMY OF ALASKA. CONCERN FOR THE HEALTH AND SURVIVAL OF RESOURCE BIODIVERSITY WILL CONTINUE TO BE A CENTRAL ISSUE IN RESOURCES MANAGEMENT IN ALASKA AND ELSEWHERE. AS ENERGY CONTINUES TO BECOME A GROWING CONCERN THROUGHOUT THE WORLD, THE BOREAL FOREST HAS THE POTENTIAL TO PROVIDE PRODUCTS NECESSARY FOR FUEL ALTERNATIVES TO PETROLEUM AND COAL. THE FOREST ECOSYSTEM ALSO PLAYS A CRITICAL ROLE IN THE CULTURE AND QUALITY OF LIFE OF ALASKAN CITIZENS. THE BOREAL FOREST IS EXPERIENCING ECOLOGICAL DROUGHT AND THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AT A HIGHER RATE THAN MANY OTHER ECOSYSTEMS. HOW THE FOREST RESPONDS TO CLIMATE CHANGE WILL HAVE CONSEQUENCES FOR WILDFIRE VULNERABILITY, INSECT INFESTATION, AND CLIMATE-INDUCED STRESS THAT IMPACTS TREE GROWTH, WOOD PRODUCTION, WATER USE, AND WILDLIFE HABITAT. MORE RESEARCH IS NEEDED THAT FOCUSES ON THESE CRITICAL FOREST ISSUES. ALL NEW AND REVISED MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECT PROPOSALS UNDERGO PEER REVIEW. THE BLIND PEER REVIEW PANEL IS COMPOSED OF A MINIMUM OF THREE MEMBERSAND CONSISTS OF COMPETENT AUTHORITIES FROM THE DISCIPLINE OF THE PROPOSAL/PUBLICATION OR RELATED DISCIPLINES, GENERALLY AT OTHER LANDGRANT UNIVERSITIES. EACH REVIEWER COMPLETES A PEER REVIEW FORM THAT INCLUDES SPECIFIC CRITERIA, PROVIDES FOR OTHER COMMENTS AND SUGGESTIONS, AND MAKES A RECOMMENDATION TO THE DIRECTOR. REVIEWS ARE RETURNED TO THE AUTHOR(S) FOR REVISION IF NEEDED. THE DIRECTOR REVIEWS ALL COMMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE REVIEWERS ALONG WITH THE REVISED PROPOSAL/PUBLICATION BEFORE IT IS SENT TO USDA. FOR MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECTS, THE DIRECTOR CONFIRMS THAT PROPOSALS ARE SENT OUT TO THREE RELATED CONTENT EXPERTS. PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS (PIS) ARE ASKED TO SUBMIT NAMES OF REVIEWERS WHO ARE EXPERTS IN THE APPLICABLE FIELD, PREFERABLY FROM ANOTHER LAND GRANT. THE DIRECTOR RESERVES THE RIGHT TO SELECT REVIEWERS THAT ARE NOT ON THE LIST. EITHER THE DIRECTOR OR A REVIEWER MAY REQUEST A REREVIEW AFTER MODIFICATION. THEN THE PI IS CLEARED TO WORK WITH THE SITE ADMINISTRATOR TOSUBMIT THE PROPOSAL TO NIFA FOR APPROVAL. AFES WILL MEET WITH AUDIENCES ON DEMAND THROUGHOUT THE STATE IN BOTH FORMAL AND INFORMAL SETTINGS EACH YEAR. EXAMPLES OF THESE AUDIENCES INCLUDE FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE ASSOCIATIONS, ALASKA NATIVE VILLAGES, TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS AND REGIONAL CORPORATIONS, BOROUGH AND CITY GOVERNMENTS AND MUNICIPALITIES, GROWER GROUPS MEETING AT REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE CONFERENCES, INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDERS INVOLVED IN FUEL/ENERGY PRODUCTION, TRIBAL SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICTS (TSWCDS) AND SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICTS (SWCDS), AND STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (INCLUDING THE DIVISION OF FORESTRY), USDA, NRCS, AND THE NATIONAL FOREST SERVICE. AFES PLAN TO ENGAGE WITH ADVISORY COMMITTEES, FOCUS GROUPS AND PARTICIPANTS IN LISTENING SESSIONS AS WELL AS CONTINUE TO CONDUCT NEEDS ASSESSMENTS AND STAKEHOLDER SURVEYS AS METHODS TO IDENTIFY GROUPS AND INDIVIDUALS FROM WHOM TO COLLECT INPUT. FACULTY AND STAFF WILL UTILIZE U.S. CENSUS BUREAU DATA TO DETERMINE POTENTIAL AUDIENCES AND PARITY GOALS. AFES RELIES ON STAKEHOLDER INPUT FROM AGRICULTURAL ADVISORY GROUPS, COLLABORATORS, FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES, COLLEAGUES, FACULTY AND STUDENTS FOR ASSISTANCE IN ESTABLISHING PRIORITIES AND DEVELOPING PROJECT DIRECTIONS. AFES WILL CONTINUE GENERATING A FEEDBACK LOOP THAT PROVIDES INFORMATION TO RESEARCH AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND FROM RESEARCH AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS TO STAKEHOLDERS AND INDIVIDUALS. CONFERENCES, MEETINGS AND WORKSHOPS ARE SCHEDULED AROUND THEMES RELEVANT TO STAKEHOLDER CONCERNS. POST-ACTIVITY SURVEYS AND DEBRIEFING OPPORTUNITIES WILL ESTABLISH HOW WELL INFORMATION NEEDS ARE ADDRESSED. MEETING MINUTES, VIDEOCONFERENCE ARCHIVES AND OTHER RECORDS OF STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AND INPUT WILL BE USED IN PLANNING OF RESEARCH. STAKEHOLDER INPUT WILL BE CONSIDERED IN PROGRAM PLANNING TO: IDENTIFY EMERGING ISSUES; REDIRECT EXTENSION AND RESEARCH PROGRAMS; GUIDE STAFF HIRING AND ACTION PLANS; SET DISTRICT AND UNIT-WIDE PRIORITIES; AND IDENTIFY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. AFES WILL CONTINUE TO SERVE THE NEEDS OF THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF ALASKA. INPUT WILL REFLECT IDEAS AND ADVICE GIVEN BY CLIENT USER GROUPS, STUDENTS, EXPERT ADVISORS, STATE AND NATIONAL PEERS AND COLLABORATORS AND UAF ADMINISTRATION. NEEDS ASSESSMENTS WILL CONTINUE TO HELP AFES FACULTY AND STAFF IDENTIFY EMERGING ISSUES. STAKEHOLDER NEEDS WILL CONTINUE TO BE A DRIVING FACTOR IN DETERMINING AFES PRIORITIES FOR RESEARCH.

PROJECT ABSTRACT - TEXAS A<(>&<)>M AGRILIFE RESEARCH - MCINTIRE?STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM THE PURPOSE OF THESE FUNDS IS TO CONDUCT FORESTRY RESEARCH IN SEVERAL AREAS: REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF FORESTRY LANDS, MANAGEMENT OF WATERSHED LANDS TO PROTECT AGAINST FLOOD AND EROSION, MANAGEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE, PROTECTION OF FOREST LANDS FOR RECREATION, PROTECTION OF FOREST LANDS AGAINST INSECTS, DISEASE, AND FIRE, UTILIZATION OF FOREST PRODUCTS, AND POLICIES FOR HARVESTING AND MARKETING FORESTRY PRODUCTS. TEXAS A<(>&<)>M AGRILIFE RESEARCH RECEIVES MCINTIRE?STENNIS FUNDS TO ENHANCE AND IMPROVE THE FOREST THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF TEXAS AND ACROSS THE US. RESEARCH IS CONDUCTED TO UNDERSTAND FORESTED WINDBREAKS, TO DEVELOP SOIL MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO INCREASE NUTRIENT AVAILABILITY, EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF INSECTS IN MANAGED FOREST LANDSCAPES, AND PROTECT TREE HEALTH, TO NAME A FEW PROJECTS. FUNDS ARE DISTRIBUTED THROUGH AN INTERNAL RFP PROCESS ANDTHE RESEARCHERS ARE EXPECTED TO PUBLISH THEIR RESULTS AND GROW THEIR RESEARCH PROGRAM THROUGH OTHER EXTERNAL SPONSORED RESEARCH PROJECTS. THE CITIZENS OF TEXAS, THE US AND THE WORLD BENEFIT FROM THE RESEARCH DONE BY THESE RESEARCHERS.

THE DEPARTMENT OF URBAN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES AT SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY AND A<(>&<)>M COLLEGE OFFERS THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE URBAN FORESTRY HIGHER EDUCATION PROGRAM IN THE NATION AND IS A LEADER IN BUILDING THE DIVERSE, TALENTED NEXT GENERATION OF URBAN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES PROFESSIONALS FOR THE COUNTRY. AS SUCH, THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PRODUCE FUTURE DIVERSE AND INCLUSIVE LEADERS FOR GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, ACADEMIA, AND PRIVATE INDUSTRIES THAT HAVE SOLID BASIC TRAINING AND APPLIED SKILLS IN AREAS CRITICAL TO THE MANAGEMENT OF THE NATION'S URBAN FOREST ECOSYSTEMS AND NATURAL RESOURCES. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) RECRUIT DIVERSE STUDENTS INCLUDING ALL ETHNIC ORIGINS AND GENDERS TO PURSUE M.S. AND PH.D. DEGREES IN URBAN FORESTRY THROUGH GRADUATE ASSISTANTSHIPS AND OTHER SUPPORT FOR GRADUATE STUDIES; (2) INTEGRATE THE RESEARCH TRAINING INTO THE GRADUATE CURRICULA; (3) TRAIN STUDENTS FOR RESEARCH PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS; (4) ENHANCE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF FACULTY AND STUDENTS THROUGH SUPPORTING TRAVEL TO SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS AS WELL AS TRAINING WORKSHOPS AND FIELD TRIPS. THE URBAN FORESTRY FACULTY WILL UTILIZE THEIR EXPERTISE TO IMPLEMENT THE STUDENTS TRAINING IN A) URBAN FOREST ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, (B) CLIMATE CHANGE, C) URBAN FOREST INFLUENCES ON UV RADIATION EXPOSURE AND TEMPERATURE, D) URBAN WETLAND MANAGEMENT, E) INVASIVE SPECIES, PEST MANAGEMENT, AND BIOSECURITY, F) TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCEMENT AND APPLICATIONS IN URBAN FOREST ECOSYSTEM AND COASTAL ZONE MANAGEMENT, BIOMASS UTILIZATION AND BIOENERGY, AND G) URBAN SOIL RESTORATION. THE PROJECT ADDRESSED ONE OF THE THREE CRITICAL GOALS IN THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM'S STRATEGIC PLAN, WHICH IS "TO CREATE THE FUTURE GENERATION OF FORESTRY EDUCATORS, SCIENTISTS, AND PRACTITIONERS THROUGH GRADUATE EDUCATION". THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF GRADUATE EDUCATION THROUGH ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROGRAM HIGH PRIORITY ISSUES: (1) SCIENCE OF INTEGRATION, (2) TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCEMENTS, PRODUCTIVITY, AND FOREST APPLICATIONS, AND (3) URBAN ECOSYSTEMS.

ADDRESSING THE NEEDS OF STAKEHOLDERS IN FORESTRY INDUSTRY IN OHIO AND US THROUGH MCINTIRE STENNIS PROGRAM AT CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY  THE MAJOR FOCUS OF THE MCINTIRE STENNIS RESEARCH PROGRAM AT CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU) IS TO: I. COLLECTIVELY MANAGE OAK-DOMINATED FORESTS ACROSS PUBLIC LANDS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS BY PROVIDING THE NECESSARY R ESEARCH-BASED SOLUTIONS II. CREATE SHARED VISIONS FOR FOREST LANDSCAPES ACROSS THE REGION, AND III. INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE LOSS OF OAKS IN SOUTHEAST OHIO FORESTS. CENTRAL STATE WILL WORK WITH THE OHIO INTERAGENCY FORESTRY TEAM WHICH COMPRISES OF EXPERTS FROM CSU, THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY, THE US FOREST SERVICE, NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS) OF USDA AND THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, DIVISION OF WILDLIFE TO ACHIEVE THESE OBJECTIVES. THE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE FOREST LANDS OWNED BY CSU IN WILBERFORCE AND THE VINTON FURNACE STATE EXPERIMENTAL FOREST (VFSEF) OF THE FOREST SERVICE- USDA NEAR NELSONVILLE, OHIO. THE M-S RESEARCHERS WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE CSU EXTENSION PROGRAM IN DEVELOPING APPROPRIATE APPLIED RESEARCH PROGRAMS AND IN DISSEMINATING FINDINGS FROM THE RESEARCH. WE PLAN TO FOCUS ON ENGAGING IN APPLIED RESEARCH RELATED TO BRINGING A MAJOR IMPROVEMENT IN THE POPULATION OF OAK IN OHIO'S FOREST IN THE APPALACHIAN AREAS THROUGH DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE SILVICULTURE TECHNIQUES AND FOREST MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES. THE RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON APPLYING NEW INFORMATION MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES USING REMOTE SENSING TECHNIQUES TO INCREASE TIMELINESS AND AT A SPATIAL RESOLUTION THAT WILL LEAD TO SOUND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. THE RESEARCH, USING THESE APPROACHES WILL ASSIST IN REDUCING THE RISK OF DECLINE IN HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF OAK AND HICKORY DUE TO UNSUSTAINABLE FOREST ACTIVITIES. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL A DDRESS ISSUES RELATED TO DECLINING WATER QUALITY AND REDUCED STORAGE CAPACITY DUE TO FOREST COVER LOSS WHICH COULD RESULT INCREASES IN WATER TREATMENT COST. THROUGH THIS PROJECT PROGRAM, CSU EXPECTS TO INTEGRATE THE FOLLOWING HIGH PRIORITY ISSUES: 1) SCIENCE OF INTEGRATION; 2) FOREST ECOSYSTEM SERVICES; 3) HUMAN ATTITUDES AND BEHAVIORS; 4) CONFLICT, UNCERTAINTY, AND DECISION-MAKING; 5) TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCEMENTS, PRODUCTIVITY, AND FOREST APPLICATIONS; AND 6) URBAN ECOSYSTEMS. ALSO, CSU WILL ADDRESS FOLLOWING CRITICAL GOALS FOR STRENGTHENING THE M-S PROGRAM: I) CREATE THE FUTURE GENERATION OF FORESTRY EDUCATORS, SCIENTISTS, AND PRACTITIONERS THROUGH EDUCATION OF UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITY POPULATIONS. II) BUILD AND SUSTAIN STRATEGIC RELATIONSHIPS THAT ENHANCE OVERALL PROGRAM EFFECTIVENESS AND SUPPORT III) COMMUNICATE AND EDUCATE THE IMPORTANCE, IMPACT, AND SUCCESSES OF THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROGRAM. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THREE MAJOR ASSOCIATED OBJECTIVES. THESE INCLUDE: I) IMPROVING OAK SILVICULTURE IN OHIO II) DEVELOPING A FORESTRY INVENTORY MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK FOR APPALACHIAN AREAS IN OHIO; AND III) ASSESSMENT OF FOREST WATERSHED CONDITIONS IN OHIO. THESE ELEMENTS ARE SEEN AS INTERDEPENDENT, AND AN INTEGRATED APPROACH WILL BE ADOPTED TO DEVELOP APPLIED PRACTICES AND MODULES FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT INCLUDING THE ECOLOGICAL ASPECTS. KEYWORDS: SILVICULTURE, OAK REGENERATION, HICKORY REGENERATION FOREST MANAGEMENT, WATER QUALITY

GIVEN THE DECLINING NUMBERS OF MINORITIES WHO ENROLLED IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROGRAMS NATIONWIDE, THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND FOOD SCIENCES (CAFS) IS IN AN OPPORTUNE POSITION TO ASSIST IN REVERSING THIS TREND BECAUSE OF ITS HISTORICAL RECORD OF RECRUITING, INSTRUCTING, AND GRADUATING MINORITY STUDENTS IN AGRICULTURAL AND RELATED SCIENCES. STRENGTHENING THE GRADUATE PROGRAM IN CAFS IS EXPECTED TO BRING ABOUT THE FOLLOWING BENEFITS: STRENGTHEN THE OVERALL TEACHING AND RESEARCH CAPACITY OF CAFS AND THE UNIVERSITY.  PROMOTE AND STIMULATE RESEARCH IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND INCREASE THE NUMBER OF GRADUATES IN THESE AREAS.  INCREASE THE POOL OF GRADUATES FOR THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (USDA) WORKFORCE DIVERSITY GOALS.  ATTRACT AND RECRUIT QUALITY STUDENTS FROM 1862 AND 1890 INSTITUTIONS FOR CAREERS IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION. STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND LINKAGES AND RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THE CAFS, THE USDA AND STAKEHOLDER GROUPS.  PROMOTE THE GOALS OF THE MCINTIRESTENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM. THE COLLEGE HAS A TRACK RECORD OF TRAINING GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE AFRICAN AMERICAN STUDENTS WHO HAVE EARNED TOP HONORS AND OUTSTANDING AWARDS IN ACADEMIA AND IN THE PROFESSIONAL ARENA AT THE STATE, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL LEVELS. THE EXISTING GRADUATE PROGRAMS HAVE BEEN FUNDED FROM A WIDE RANGE OF SOURCES, NAMELY, THE CAPACITY BUILDING GRANTS, NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE  NIFA GRANTS, NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION GRANTS, FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE VITICULTURE GRANTS, FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE  SPECIALTY CROP GRANTS, AND FAMUS GRADUATE ASSISTANTSHIPS. HOWEVER, TO SUSTAIN AND BUILD ON CURRENT EFFORTS, MORE SECURED SOURCES OF FUNDING ARE REQUIRED SUCH AS THE MCINTIRESTENNIS PROGRAM TO STRENGTHEN AND GROW THE GRADUATE PROGRAM TO ITS FULL POTENTIAL; THIS IS PARTICULARLY THE CASE FOR THE FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES AREA. THE COLLEGE, AS PREVIOUSLY STATED, IS A PARTICIPANT IN THE MCINTIRESTENNIS PROGRAM WHICH PROVIDES AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO STABILIZE, SUSTAIN AND GROW OUR EXISTING FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES RESEARCH PROGRAMS THROUGH GREATER GRADUATE STUDENT PARTICIPATION. THE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT OUTSTANDING GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WHO WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH UNDER THE MENTORSHIP AND SUPERVISION OF THE GRADUATE FACULTY. THE PROPOSED ESTABLISHMENT OF THE MCINTIRE STENNIS ASSISTANTSHIP PROGRAM (MISAP) WILL ENABLE CAFS TO RECRUIT QUALITY STUDENTS AND CANDIDATES FOR PROFESSIONAL DEGREES FROM ITS STUDENT BODY AND PREPARE THEM FOR PROFESSIONAL / DOCTORAL DEGREES AS WELL AS THE COMPETITIVE JOB MARKET. A. APPROACH AND COOPERATIVE LINKAGES 1. OBJECTIVES THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND THE GRADUATE PROGRAM IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND FOOD SCIENCES BY ESTABLISHING THE MCINTIRESTENNIS ASSISTANTSHIP PROGRAM (MISAP) THAT WILL FACILITATE THE FOLLOWING: 1. RECRUITMENT, RETENTION, AND INSTRUCTION OF OUTSTANDING UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE GRADUATE PROGRAM WITH POTENTIAL FOR ADVANCED GRADUATE STUDIES AND MORE COMPETITIVE GRADUATES. 2. PROMOTING AND STRENGTHENING MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES RELATED PROGRAMS THROUGH UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE RESEARCH PARTICIPATION. 3. AWARDS AND RECOGNITION OF OUTSTANDING ACCOMPLISHMENTS BY STUDENTS AND FACULTY. 2. METHODOLOGY AND PLAN OF WORK OBJECTIVE 1. TO RECRUIT OUTSTANDING UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE MCINTIRESTENNIS PROGRAM, WE WILL PUBLICIZE THE PROGRAM AND ENCOURAGE ACTIVE PARTICIPATION FROM THE FACULTY AND STUDENTS. WE WILL IDENTIFY GOOD STUDENTS AND ENCOURAGE THEM TO PARTICIPATE IN THE PROGRAM. STUDENTS IN THE COLLEGE WILL BE ACTIVELY RECRUITED AND ENCOURAGED TO PARTICIPATE THROUGH OUR RECRUITMENT EFFORTS. TO ENSURE A COMPETITIVE SELECTION PROCESS, THE COLLEGE WILL UNDERTAKE THE FOLLOWING:  ESTABLISH A SELECTION COMMITTEE TO REVIEW APPLICATIONS AND MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF THE GRADUATE RESEARCH PROJECTS.  MAJOR PROFESSORS AND/OR SUPERVISORS WILL BE REQUIRED TO MONITOR AND SUBMIT AN ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS OF THEIR STUDENTS ON THE MCINTIRE STENNIS ASSISTANTSHIP PROGRAM (MISAP) WHO WILL HAVE TO BE IN ACADEMIC GOOD STANDING AND MAINTAIN SATISFACTORY RESEARCH PROGRESS TO KEEP THEIR ASSISTANTSHIPS. THESE STUDENTS WILL BE REQUIRED TO SIGN A CONTRACT ACCEPTING THE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF THE AWARD.  DEVELOP BROCHURES AND PRINTED MATERIALS THAT WILL DESCRIBE THE MCINTIRESTENNIS ASSISTANTSHIP PROGRAM (MISAP) THAT WILL INCLUDE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES, SELECTION CRITERIA, AND CONDITIONS OF THE AWARD. THE INFORMATION WILL ALSO BE AVAILABLE AT THE CAFS WEBSITE WITH LINKS TO IT FROM THE UNIVERSITYS HOMEPAGE, SPONSORED PROGRAMS, AND THE OFFICE OF STUDENT AFFAIRS. THIS WILL BRING ABOUT VISIBILITY AND INTEREST FOR THE PROGRAM TO ENSURE AN INCREASED POOL OF APPLICANTS. THE PROGRAM WILL SELECT ONLY QUALIFIED STUDENTS WITH STRONG SCHOLASTIC AND A RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS ISSUES RELATING TO FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION OF CURRENT AND EMERGING IMPORTANCE OR CONCERN. EXAMPLES OF RESEARCH AREAS MAY INCLUDE BUT NOT LIMITED TO: O FUNCTIONS AND INDICATORS OF WETLAND O NUTRIENT AND CARBON CYCLING OF FORESTLAND O INTEGRATED APPROACH TO WATERSHED MANAGEMENT O AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS AND CONSERVATION OF BIODIVERSITY O FOREST CANOPY AND WETLAND MITIGATION O FOREST MANAGEMENT INFLUENCES ON STREAM WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY O NUTRIENT AND BIOAVAILABILITY IN WETLAND O URBAN FORESTRY AND SOCIOECONOMIC BENEFITS O ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE OF FOREST PRODUCTS TO LOCAL ECONOMY O CONVENTIONAL AND SELECTIVE LOGGING AND THEIR IMPACT ON FOREST ECOLOGY O MANAGEMENT AND BIOCONTROL STRATEGIES FOR CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES OF FORESTRY PESTS O MANAGEMENT OF THE REDBAY AMBROSIA BEETLES O IMPORTANT GENETIC MARKERS FOR IMPROVEMENT OF PLANT SPECIES O MOLECULAR GENOMICS OF FOREST PESTS AND INSECTS O FOREST FLOOR AND CANOPY MANAGEMENT O RIPARIAN BUFFER AND FOREST MANAGEMENT O INVENTORY OF PLANT SPECIES IN LOCAL FORESTS STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH PROJECTS AND WORK UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATORS/PROGRAM DIRECTORS. OBJECTIVE 3. THE COLLEGE WILL RECOGNIZE OUTSTANDING RESEARCH ACCOMPLISHMENTS BY STUDENTS AND FACULTY AS ONE OF THE STRATEGIES TO INCREASE INTEREST AND ENHANCE PRODUCTIVITY. ONE INCENTIVE WILL BE TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FACULTY AND STUDENTS TO ATTEND PROFESSIONAL MEETINGS AND PRESENT THEIR RESEARCH AS WELL COVER THE PAGE CHARGES FOR SUBSEQUENT MANUSCRIPTS. ANNUALLY, A MISAP REVIEW AND AWARD COMMITTEE WILL EVALUATE THE ACCEPTABILITY OF RESEARCH ACCOMPLISHMENTS FOR SPECIAL RECOGNITION. ACCOMPLISHMENTS FOUND WORTHY WILL BE RECOGNIZED WITH A SPECIAL CERTIFICATE OR PLAQUE AS A KEEP-SAKE FOR THE STUDENT AND OR FACULTY. THE AWARD, TITLED "MCINTIRE-STENNIS OUTSTANDING RESEARCH AWARD", WILL BE GIVEN DURING A SPECIAL CEREMONY OR AT ONE OF THE COLLEGE CONVOCATIONS. THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS SCHOLARS WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED WITH EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING EXPERIENCES DURING THE SUMMER TO WORK WITH OTHER RESEARCHERS IN THE COLLEGE OR OTHER INSTITUTIONS AND COLLABORATING PARTNERS. THIS APPROACH IS EXPECTED TO FURTHER IMPROVE THEIR TRAINING, PREPARATION, AND DESIRE TO ATTAIN ADDITIONAL KNOWLEDGE AND PURSUE ADVANCED DEGREES.

(A) PERSONNEL: $534,072 UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO EXPECTS TO USE APPROXIMATELY 76% OF FFY 2023 MCINTIRE STENNIS ALLOCATION ON PERSONNEL SUPPORTING APPROXIMATELY 25 FULL AND PART-TIME POSITIONS FOR FACULTY, STAFF, AND STUDENTS. THE UNIVERSITY RESERVES A PORTION OF MCINTIRE STENNIS FUNDS TO SUPPORT COMPETITIVE RESEARCH EFFORTS TO ADDRESS CRITICAL ISSUES FACING FOREST AND RANGELAND SYSTEMS OF IDAHO AND THE INLAND NORTHWEST WHICH WILL INFLUENCE THE NUMBER AND TYPE OF POSITIONS FUNDED. THESE RESEARCH PROJECTS INCLUDE BOTH BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH FOCUSED BROADLY ON THE MANAGEMENT, UTILIZATION, RESTORATION AND PROTECTION OF FORESTS AND RANGELANDS. SPECIFIC AREAS OF FOCUS INCLUDE: 1) FOREST AND RANGELAND MANAGEMENT ACROSS MULTIPLE SCALES (E.G., TREE, STAND, LANDSCAPE) FOR A VARIETY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, INCLUDING TIMBER PRODUCTION, WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY, CARBON SEQUESTRATION, WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND RECREATION; 2) REFORESTATION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS TO IMPROVE FOREST AND RANGELAND HEALTH AND SUSTAINABILITY (PARTICULARLY IN RESPONSE TO INCREASING WILDFIRES, INSECT OUTBREAKS, AND INVASIVE PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES); 3) DEVELOPMENT OF WOOD AND WOOD-BASED PRODUCTS THAT ARE RENEWABLE AND PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE COMMUNITIES AND DEVELOPMENT; AND 4) SCIENCE-BASED POLICY ANALYSIS AND FORMULATION THAT IMPROVES THE MANAGEMENT OF SUSTAINABLE FORESTS AND RANGELANDS IN RESPONSE TO THE NUMEROUS, COMPLEX CHALLENGES (E.G., INCREASED HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, INCREASING WILDFIRES, AND CLIMATE CHANGE). MOST PROJECTS FUNDED WITHIN THESE BROAD FOCUS AREAS ARE INTERDISCIPLINARY IN NATURE, BRINGING TOGETHER DIVERSE TEAMS OF FACULTY, STAFF, AND STUDENTS ACROSS THE COLLEGE OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO TO FIND SOLUTIONS TO THE COMPLEX ISSUES FACING IDAHO'S FORESTS AND RANGELANDS. ADDITIONALLY, THE TRAINING AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE NEXT GENERATION OF FOREST AND RANGELAND SCIENTISTS AND PROFESSIONALS ARE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THESE PROJECTS. (B) FRINGE BENEFITS $115,335 FRINGE BENEFITS ARE CALCULATED AT 30.1% OF SALARY FOR FACULTY AND 42.0% OF SALARY FOR STAFF, 3.6% OF SALARY FOR STUDENTS, AND 8.7% OF SALARY FOR TEMPORARY, HOURLY, WORKERS. NOTE: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO HAVE DETERMINED THE DEFINITION OF SALARY YEAR TO BE BASED ON THE CALENDAR YEAR. BENEFITS ARE ACTUAL RATES BASED ON A CONSOLIDATED FRINGE RATE BY EMPLOYEE CLASSIFICATION. FRINGE RATES ARE LISTED AS THE PROJECTED FY23 RATES THAT ARE PENDING APPROVAL FROM DHHS. MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECTS AT PURDUE UNIVERSITY'S DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES SEEK TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING AND MANAGEMENT OF FORESTS ACROSS THE CENTRAL HARDWOOD REGION. OUR OVERALL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROJECTS FOCUS ON ADVANCING HARDWOOD REGENERATION AND RESTORATION, INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL, FOREST HEALTH, NEW METHODS FOR DIGITAL MEASUREMENT OF THE REGION'S FORESTS, GENETIC IMPROVEMENT OF HIGH-VALUE HARDWOOD SPECIES, FOREST ECONOMICS AND OPTIMAL DECISION-MAKING, HARDWOOD PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT, AND WILDLIFE ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT. THE TARGET AUDIENCES FOR THIS WORK INCLUDE FORESTLAND OWNERS, FOREST MANAGERS, AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC INTERESTED IN FOREST RESOURCE ISSUES. WE DELIVER NEW INFORMATION TO THESE AUDIENCES THROUGH EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS, WORKSHOPS, FIELD COURSES, VIDEOS, AND SOCIAL MEDIA. CURRENT APPROVED PROJECTS UNDER MCINTIRE-STENNIS INCLUDE: MODIFICATION OF THE LIGNIN BIOSYNTHETIC PATHWAY IN POPULUS TO IMPROVE ITS UTILITY AS A BIOENERGY CROP; FOREST RESPONSES TO HUMAN-MEDIATED DISTURBANCE, INVASIVE SPECIES, AND RESTORATION PRESCRIPTIONS; OPTIMAL MANAGEMENT OF CENTRAL HARDWOOD FORESTS UNDER UNCERTAINTY; AND NATIONWIDE MAPPING OF TREE SPECIES DIVERSITY IN THE UNITED STATES. SPECIFIC DETAILS ABOUT THESE AND PAST PROJECTS CAN BE FOUND AT: HTTPS://AG.PURDUE.EDU/DEPARTME NT/FNR/RESEARCH/MCINTIRE-STENNIS-PROJECTS/INDEX.HTML.

PENN STATE'S COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES' OFFICE FOR RESEARCH AND GRADUATE EDUCATION WILL HOLD AN ANNUAL COMPETITION TO SEEK PROPOSALS THAT ARE COMPRISED OF BASIC AND APPLIED STUDIES RELATED TO FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES RESEARCH THAT WILL LEAD TO FUTURE LEVERAGING OF FUNDS. THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY IS OFFERED TO SUPPORT FORESTRY RESEARCH THAT INCLUDES INVESTIGATIONS RELATING TO: 1) REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST; 2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHEDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND QUALITY AND TO PROTECT WETLANDS AND ASSOCIATED AREAS AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION; 3) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE; 4) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION; 5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS; 6) UTILIZATION OFWOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS; 7) DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND THE HARVESTING AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS; AND 8) SUCH OTHER STUDIES AS MAY BE NE CESSARY TO OBTAIN THE FULLEST AND MOST EFFECTIVE USE OF FOREST RESOURCES. INTERNAL REVIEWS ENSURE THAT THE PROJECTS RECOMMENDED FOR FUNDING ARE OF SUFFICIENT QUALITY TO MERIT FUNDING AND THE PROPOSED PROJECTS MEET THE CRITERIA AS DEFINED BY USDA'S MCINTIRE-STENNIS RESEARCH PROGRAM. FINAL DECISIONS FOR FUNDING WILL BE MADE BY THE ASSOCIATE DEAN FOR RESEARCH AND ARE CONTINGENT ON A USDA APPROVAL OF A MCINTIRE-STENNIS AES PROJECT

THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL HELP OSU COLLEGE OF FORESTRY CARRY OUT RESEARCH PROJECTS IMPORTANT TO THE STATE OF OREGON. SUPPORTED PROJECTS WILL SUPPORT TRAINED FOREST SCIENTISTS IN THE FOLLOWING RESEARCH TOPICS: REFORESTATION; FOREST, WATERSHED, AND RANGELAND MANAGEMENT; FOREST RECREATION; PROTECTION AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, AND OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS; FOREST PRODUCTS UTILIZATION; AND FOREST POLICY.
