PROJECTS FUNDED BY OSU INCLUDE UNDERSTANDING CONTEXT OF, BARRIERS TO, AND IMPACTS OF ACTIVE FOREST MANAGEMENT IN THE FIRE-ADAPTED WEST, REVIEWING AND DEVELOPING SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS, HARVESTING PRACTICES, AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS, MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE WATER FLOW AND PROTECT AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION, RESEARCH ON ADVANCED WOOD PRODUCTS IN MASS TIMBER BUILDINGS, IMPROVEMENT OF SCIENTIFIC TOOLS FOR MANAGING FORESTED WATERSHEDS, USE OF REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGIES TO ESTIMATE DIMENSIONS AND DIFFERENT QUALITIES OF TREES, AND UNDERSTANDING THE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN FOREST GOVERNANCE AND LANDSCAPE PATTERN AND PROCESS, AND THE WAYS IN WHICH PUBLIC PERCEPTIONS AND VALUATIONS OF FEDERAL FOREST LANDSCAPES AND SCIENCE INFLUENCE THOSE CONNECTIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS CAPACITY FUNDS IS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH IN DEVELOPING LANDSCAPE WOODY PLANT VARIETIES THAT CAN SURVIVE IN CLIMATE AND SOILS CONDITIONS OF THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS.  THE ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BE SUPPORTED ARE THE IDENTIFICATION, PROPAGATION, AND EVALUATION OF WOODY PLANT VARIETIES FOR WINTER HARDIN ESS, SUSCEPTIBILITY TO PESTS OF THE REGION, DROUGHT RESISTANCE, AND THEIR TOLERANCE TO DESICCATING WINDS AND UNFAVORABLE SOIL CONDITIONS, ESPECIALLY ALKALINITY AND SALINITY.  IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT MORE WOODY PLANT VARIETIES WILL BE RELEASED AND MADE AVAILABLE TO COMMUNITIES IN THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS THAT PROVIDE SHELTERBELTS, WINDBREAKS, WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND MASS PLANTING FOR SOIL EROSION CONTROL. ADDITIONALLY, IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT MORE VARIETAL RELEASES WILL REDUCE MONOCULTURE PLANTINGS AND REDUCE THE OUTBREAKS OF DISEASE AND PEST INFESTATIONS.  THE PRIMARY RECIPIENTS OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WOODY PLANT VARIETAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM WILL BE LANDOWNERS, SOIL CONSERVATION SPECIALIST, CONSULTANTS, AND INDUSTRY PARTNERS WHO RELY ON HEARTY VARIETIES THAT SURVIVE IN THIS REGION OF THE UNITED STATES.

PROJECT ABSTRACT OUR PORTFOLIOS OF SOLUTIONDRIVEN, CUTTINGEDGE RESEARCH IS CREATING NEW KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY WHICH IS THEN EXTENDED TO ALL NORTH CAROLINIANS THROUGH NC COOPERATIVE EXTENSION. WE ARE TRANSFORMING SCIENCE INTO EVERYDAY SOLUTIONS THAT IMPROVE LIVES AND ALLOW NORTH CAROLINIANS TO LEAD PROSPEROUS, HEALTHY LIVES. A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF EXTENSION AGENTS SERVES AS THE CONDUIT THROUGH WHICH THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY ARE COMMUNICATED TO UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS WHO THEN CONDUCT RESEARCH AND FORMULATE SOLUTIONS. EXTENSION AGENTS THEN DELIVER ESSENTIAL INFORMATION INTO THE HANDS OF GROWERS, INDUSTRY, AND MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS AT NC STATE FOCUS ON ADDRESSING FOUR IDENTIFIED STATEWIDE CRITICAL ISSUES: IMPROVING PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; PROTECTING ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES, ENRICHING YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELLBEING; AND ENHANCING FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH. THROUGH INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS, NC STATE IS SOLVING CHALLENGES RELATED TO THE PRODUCTIVITY AND PROFITABILITY OF BOTH LARGE AND SMALL SCALE FARMS. RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION EDUCATORS ARE ALSO DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY TO IMPROVE LANDSCAPING AND GARDENING. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS IN ANIMAL SYSTEMS ARE FOCUSED ON DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING KNOWLEDGE AND METHODS FOR ANIMAL BREEDING, REPRODUCTION, NUTRITION, GENETICS AND GENOMICS, PHYSIOLOGY, ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS, PRODUCT QUALITY, AND HEALTH AND WELLBEING. THESE INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS ALSO AIM TO TACKLE THE CRITICAL ISSUES IMPACTING THE QUALITY OF OUR SOIL, WATER AND AIR BY PROVIDING SCIENTIFIC SOLUTIONS FOR ANIMAL WASTE MANAGEMENT, WASTEWATER TREATMENT, NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT, SEPTIC SYSTEMS, WETLAND MANAGEMENT, SOIL PROPERTIES, AND FISHERY AND POND MANAGEMENT. NC STATE EXTENSION CONTINUES TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES TO ENRICH YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELL BEING THROUGH THE 4H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. 4H PROGRAMS INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH TO DEVELOP LIFE SKILLS, GROW CONFIDENCE, INDEPENDENCE, RESILIENCE, AND STEM SKILLS THROUGH FUN HANDS ON LEARNING IN SAFE, HEALTHY, AND ENRICHING ENVIRONMENTS. EXTENSION PROGRAMS ALSO ADDRESS CRITICAL CHALLENGES AFFECTING CONSUMER AND FAMILY WELLBEING. IN ADDITION TO YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, OTHER FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE PARENTING, CHILDCARE, FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, AGING, HEALTHY HOMES, AND DISASTER READINESS, RESPONSE, AND RECOVERY. AT THE COMMUNITY LEVEL, EXTENSION WORKS WITH INDIVIDUALS, COMMUNITY GROUPS AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS ON LEADERSHIP SKILLS, WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT, ENTREPRENEURSHIP, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, VOLUNTEERISM, COMMUNITY PLANNING, AND DISASTER PREPAREDNESS NC STATES RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS TO ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH AND TO KEEP AMERICANS HEALTHY AND FREE FROM FOODBORNE ILLNESS NECESSITATE A FOCUS ON PREVENTING FOOD SAFETY PROBLEMS RATHER THAN TAKING A REACTIONARY APPROACH. NC STATES INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS FOCUS ON PROTECTING THE SAFETY OF FOODS ALONG THE ENTIRE SUPPLY CHAIN, FROM PRODUCTION TO CONSUMPTION. TO MEET THE GROWING NEED FOR HEALTHY FOOD, RESEARCHERS ARE DEVELOPING AND PRODUCING NEW FOOD PRODUCTS THAT PROMOTE HEALTH AND PREVENT DISEASE. AT THE SAME TIME, EXTENSION PROVIDES NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMMING TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE THEY NEED TO MAKE INFORMED CHOICES ABOUT FOOD AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLES. IMPROVING PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS: WITHIN THIS AREA, WE WILL WORK TO ADDRESS CROSSCUTTING AND EMERGING ISSUES OF ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH AND PRODUCTION. IN ANIMAL SYSTEM, RESEARCHERS WILL STUDY THE EFFICIENCY OF DIFFERENT FEEDING SOURCES TO IMPROVE ANIMAL PRODUCTIVITY AND GUT HEALTH. IN PLANT SYSTEMS, THE FOCUS WILL BE IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, ALTERNATIVE AND HIGH VALUE CROP PRODUCTION, SEASON EXTENSION, CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION, VALUE ADDED AGRICULTURE, DIGITAL AGRICULTURE, SOIL HEALTH, PEST CONTROL, AND AGRO ECONOMICS. EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND ITS WORK WITH LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS, PLACING SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON LIMITED RESOURCES, SMALL SCALE MINORITY FARMERS. THE FARM PAVILION WILL FOCUS ON SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND LOCAL AND COMMUNITY FOOD SYSTEMS, HOUSING ITS APPLIED RESEARCH AND DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS STAFF AND PROVIDING SPACE FOR MEETINGS, FORUMS AND CONFERENCES. ENHANCING FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH: WITHIN THIS AREA BOTH RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WILL WORK TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF HUMAN HEALTH, FOOD SAFETY AND HEALTHY LIVING HABITS. THE RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON WHOLE GRAIN CEREALS, HUMAN HEALTH AND HUMAN NUTRITION, PROBIOTICS STRAINS, FOOD ALLERGY, FOOD PRODUCTION PROCESS, BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS OF FOOD, POSTHARVEST TECHNOLOGY AND FOOD SECURITY. COOPERATIVE EXTENSION AND RESEARCHERS AT NCA<(>&<)>T WILL WORK TOGETHER IN A CONCERTED EFFORT TO INCREASE INFORMATION AND RESOURCES FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN FAMILIES AND CHILDREN IN RURAL COMMUNITIES WHO ARE OFTEN POOR AND DISPROPORNANCIALLY VULNERABLE ARE WELL EQUIPPED TO MAKE SOUND FINANCIAL DECISIONS FOR THEMSELVES AND THEIR FAMILIES. 4-H PROGRAMMING WILL FOCUS ON AREAS SUCH AS STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH), LEADERSHIP DEVEL OPMENT, AND AGRISCIENCE. INNOVATION STATION, THE CUTTING-EDGE MOBILE LEARNING EXPERIENCE, WILL CONTINUE TRAVELING TO COUNTIES THROUGHOUT NORTH CAROLINA, PROVIDING INTRODUCTORY AND ADVANCED STEM CURRICULA FOR CHILDREN IN GRADES K-12. ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOU RCES: IN THIS AREA WE WILL WORK TO PROTECT THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT, PROVIDE THE SOLUTION FOR WASTE MANAGEMENT AND CONVENTIONAL ENERGY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL INVESTIGATE AN ADVANCED BIOLOGICAL SYSTEM TO PRODUCE ALTERNATIVE ENERGY, TREAT THE AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL WASTE, AND PROTECT AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL BE INVOLVED IN MULTISTATE CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECT TO STUDY THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND COMMUNITY OF COLOR. RESEARCHERS WILL BE DEVELOPING THE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION SOLUTION TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND WILL BE PROPOSING POLICIES TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND CLIMATE CHANGE. EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT SMALL SCALE PRODUCERS AND LANDOWNERS IN THEIR EFFORT TO DEVELOP WOODLOT MANAGEMENT PLANS WHILE ALSO INTEGRATING TECHNIQUES AND PRACTICES SUCH AS SILVOPASTURE PRODUCTION AND RIPARIAN BUFFERS

CURRENTLY WE HAVE FIVE ACTIVE PROJECTS AND TWO PENDING PROJECTS THAT THIS WILL BE FUNDED AND TEN PROFESSORS ARE WORKING ON THESE APPROVED OR PENDING PROJECTS TO THE USDA. THESE PROJECTS HAVE ALREADY INVOLVED 14 UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND ONE GRADUATE STUDENT. THE PROJECTS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING PROJECTS: 1) EVALUATING THE ROLE OF FUNGI IN FOREST HEALTH IN LOUISIANA THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO EXAMINE AND MAP TREE MORTALITY AND CANOPY STRUCTURE USING DRONE FLEETS TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING AND BETTER DESCRIBE THE HEALTH DIFFERENTIAL OF 'HEALTHY' AND 'UNHEALTHY' FORESTS AND TREES CONSIDERING HUMAN, CLIMATIC, AND BIOTIC DRIVERS. SECONDLY, WE WILL EVALUATE THE PARAMETERS ASSOCIATED WITH DECLINE/DISEASE AND PRESENCE OF PATHOGENS, INCLUDING THE ROLE OF FUNGI IN THE FORMATION OF CANOPY OPENINGS, TREE COMPETITION, AND CANOPY STRUCTURE. FINALLY, WE WILL CONDUCT PATHOGENICITY TESTS ON SPECIES CORRELATED WITH DISEASE OUTBREAKS. A "BIG PICTURE" APPROACH WILL BE USED TO CREATE A REALISTIC AND LOGISTICALLYFEASIBLE APPROACH AS THEY RELATE TO RISK PRIORITIES FOR ANY INVOLVED AGENCIES TO DEVELOP BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND TO HELP AVOID INTRODUCTION AND MOVEMENT OF KEY PATHOGENIC FUNGAL SPECIES. A REVIEW OF ANY EXISTING BMPS CAN BE DONE TO USE AS BASELINE DOCUMENTS AND THEN BUILD AND IMPROVE FROM THERE BASED ON THE CONDITION OF EXISTING SITES, NEEDS AND PRIORITIES. IDENTIFICATION OF PATHOGENS AND POTENTIAL VECTORS WILL BE MADE, AND CORRELATED RISK ANALYSES WILL BE DONE. FIELDWORK BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES INCLUDING WEED CONTROL, REVEGETATION, WATERING, SEED COLLECTION, AND INFRASTRUCTURE (TRAILS, ROADS, AND CONSTRUCTION) AND MAINTENANCE AS APPROPRIATE WILL BE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT, DEVELOPED AND MODIFIED AS NECESSARY. PROCEDURES FOR EQUIPMENT AND MATERIALS MOVEMENT WILL ALSO BE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT, DEVELOPED, AND MODIFIED AS NECESSARY. SAMPLING AND MONITORING PROTOCOLS WILL BE OUTLINED. BASED ON EXISTING KNOWLEDGE AND INFORMATION GLEANED, DEVELOP CORRESPONDING PROTOCOLS FOR IMPROVED SITE SELECTION AND PRACTICE. THESE WILL BE MODIFIED AND ADAPTED TO MANAGE FOR THE PATHOGENS FOUND, ASSOCIATED HOSTS, AND LANDSCAPE AND ECOSYSTEM CHARACTERISTICS. 2) OPTIMIZATION OF GENETICALLY IMPROVED SEEDLINGS FOR SOUTHERN FORESTS THROUGH THIS PROJECT, I PROPOSE TO USE EXISTING KNOWLEDGE AS WELL AS TO BROADEN THE KNOWLEDGE BASE OF IMPORTANT SPECIES TO INCREASE YIELD OF DESIRED PRODUCTS. I WILL USE NEW TECHNOLOGIES IN GENOMICS AND TRADITIONAL FOREST TECHNIQUES TO DEVELOP BETTER PROTOCOLS FOR LANDOWNERS TO INCREASE FOREST CROP PRODUCTION. THE FIRST AIM IS TO USE TRADITIONAL SELECTION: WE WILL USE INFORMATION FROM PROGENY TESTS WITH NEW YEAR MEASUREMENTS TO FURTHER INFORM SELECTION OF SUPERIOR GENOTYPES. A SECOND AVENUE AIMED AT EVALUATION OF SELECTION METHODS WILL GENERALLY BE DEPENDENT ON CONTINUED MONITORING OF TREE GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT SO THAT AGE-AGE CORRELATIONS CAN BE STUDIED. TO AUGMENT TRADITIONAL SELECTION BASED ON VISUAL OR PHYSICAL MEASUREMENTS OF VOLUME, HEIGHT, OR DIAMETER, WE COULD ALSO EXPLORE USE OF QUANTITATIVE TRAIT LOCI (QTL) ANALYSIS AND OTHER MOLECULAR MARKER TECHNIQUES TO MAKE SELECTIONS AT YOUNGER AGES. PROPAGATION OF CLONAL SPECIES: DEVELOPMENT OF FIELD PROPAGATION TECHNIQUES WILL FIRST BEGIN WITH SELECTION OF SUPERIOR INDIVIDUALS. THESE WILL BE MEASURED FOR DIAMETER AND LENGTH AND TIME OF CUTTING HARVEST WILL BE RECORDED. WE WILL ALSO TRY VARIOUS TREATMENTS OF CUTTING PREPARATION INCLUDING TREATMENTS OF VARIOUS ROOTING POWDERS. FROM THIS DATA WE WILL BE ABLE TO PRODUCE MODELS THAT WILL HELP INDICATE METHODS FOR MAXIMIZING EFFICIENCY OF PLANTING THESE CUTTINGS. 3) WOOD UTILIZATION IN A CHANGING ECONOMIC ENVIRONMENT RECOGNIZING INTRICATE, AND POTENTIALLY MESSY, INTERACTIONS BETWEEN THE ENVIRONMENT, SOCIETY, AND ECONOMY IN THIS POST-RECESSIONAL ERA REQUIRES NOVEL LEVELS OF UNDERSTANDING. THIS IS CRITICAL TO TRANSFORMING CHALLENGES INTO OPPORTUNITIES. THIS WORK WILL EXPLORE THREE PRIMARY AVENUES BY WHICH PRODUCTION FORESTRY CURRENTLY CONTRIBUTES TO, AND CAN POTENTIALLY INCREASE ITS IMPACTS ON, REGIONAL ECONOMIES: 1) BY BRINGING NEW MONEY INTO THE REGION VIA EXPORTS, 2) BY DEVELOPING NEW OR SUBSTITUTING LOCALLY PRODUCED GOODS AND SERVICES FOR IMPORTED INPUTS, AND 3) BY ATTRACTING VALUE ADDED MANUFACTURING THAT CAN INCREASE REGIONAL PRODUCT. THE PRIMARY MEANS OF ASSESSING THESE CONTRIBUTIONS AND IMPACTS WILL SOCIAL ACCOUNTING MATRIXES OF VARIOUS REGIONAL ECONOMIES. THE STUDIES ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PROJECT CAN PROVIDE INTERESTED PARTIES- INDUSTRY PARTICIPANTS (LANDOWNERS, LOGGERS, MILLS), ADVOCATES (ASSOCIATIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS), AS WELL AS LAWMAKERS- NEEDED INFORMATION WHEN INVOLVED IN POLICY AND DECISION-MAKING DISCUSSIONS. THIS COULD BE PARTICULARLY TRUE IN AREAS WHERE FORESTRY'S ROLE(S) MAY NOT BE FULLY UNDERSTOOD. PROJECT INFORMATION METHODOLOGY THE PRIMARY MEANS OF ANALYSIS WILL BE VIA INPUT-OUTPUT TABLES AND SOCIAL ACCOUNTING MATRIXES. AN INPUT-OUTPUT TABLE QUANTIFIES TRANSACTIONS BY HOW MANY DOLLARS EACH SECTOR PROCESSES TOSELL AND PURCHASES FOR USE. THE TABLE SEPARATES PROCESSING SECTORS BY ROWS AND PURCHASING SECTORS BY COLUMNS; EVERY SECTOR IS CONSIDERED TO BE BOTH A PROCESSOR AND PURCHASER. SUMMING EACH ROW QUANTIFIES AN INDUSTRY'S OUTPUT, WHICH INCLUDES SALES TO OTHER PRODUCTION SECTORS ALONG WITH THOSE TO FINAL USERS. BEYOND THE INPUT-OUTPUT FRAMEWORK ARE THE NONMARKET INCOME FLOWS OCCURRING IN A REGION, SUCH AS HOUSEHOLDS RECEIVING WAGES AND BENEFITS FROM INDUSTRIES, DIVIDENDS FROM CORPORATIONS, AND/OR TRANSFER PAYMENTS FROM GOVERNMENT. A SOCIAL ACCOUNTING MATRIX DETAILS THESE ECONOMIC RELATIONSHIPS VIA CONSTRUCTION OF SUBMATRICES IN ADDITION TO THAT CHARACTERIZING THE TRADITIONAL INTER-INDUSTRY FLOWS FOUND IN AN INPUT-OUTPUT TABLE. 4) PRELIMINARY EVALUATION OF WILDLIFE RESPONSE TO CATTLE GRAZING IN A LONGLEAF PINE THE SOUTHWESTERN LOUISIANA/SOUTHEASTERN TEXAS REGION HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED BY USDA NRCS AS A PRIORITY AREA FOR LONGLEAF PINE RESTORATION, AND THERE ARE SEVERAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR IMPROVING RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE REGION BY INTEGRATING GRAZING INTO LONGLEAF PINE MANAGEMENT. THE IMPACT OF GRAZING ON WILDLIFE IN LONGLEAF PINE, HOWEVER, IS NOT KNOWN. WITH THIS STUDY, I PROPOSE TO EVALUATE THE LONGLEAF RESTORATIONS EFFECT ON CURRENT STATUS OF AVIAN AND MAMMAL POPULATIONS AT THE LOUISIANA ECOLOGICAL FORESTRY CENTER, LLC (LEAF CENTER) NEAR LEESVILLE, LOUISIANA. SPECIAL FOCUS WILL BE ON THE ENDANGERED RED-COCKADED WOODPECKER (RCW), AS WELL AS BAIRD'S POCKET GOPHER, PRIMARY PREY SPECIES OF THE THREATENED LOUISIANA PINE SNAKE. THIS STUDY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF AN ALTERNATIVE FORM OF LONGLEAF PINE ECOSYSTEM DISTURBANCE (CATTLE GRAZING), SPECIFICALLY IN REGARDS TO THE ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF LONGLEAF PINE HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE. INFORMATION GAINED FROM THIS STUDY WILL AID IN FUTURE HABITAT DECISION MAKING BY LONGLEAF PINE FOREST OWNERS AND MANAGERS, PARTICULARLY THOSE AREAS WHERE PRESCRIBED BURNING MAY NOT BE POSSIBLE. 5) HIGH-RESOLUTION DATA AND PRECISION FORESTRY APPLICATIONS IN SOUTHERN UNITED STATES FORESTS IN THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES ARE VITALLY IMPORTANT, PROVIDING A DIVERSITY OF SPECIES, HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE, AREAS FOR RECREATION, AND TIMBER RESOURCES. THE INTENDED STUDIES TO SUPPORT THIS PROJECT WILL 1) INCORPORATE READILY DEPLOYABLE TECHNOLOGY (E.G., AERIAL AND TERRESTRIAL LIDAR (LIGHT DETECTION AND RANGING) EQUIPMENT) TO ASSESS BIOMETRIC DATA; 2) COMPARE THESE METHODS - AERIAL AND TERRESTRIAL LIDAR DATA WITH HIGH-RESOLUTION IMAGERY AND FIELD-BASED MEASUREMENTS - TO UNDERSTAND POTENTIAL BIAS OF REMOTELY-SENSED MEASURES IN FOREST INVENTORY MEASUREMENTS; 3) ALLOW FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF MODELS FOR SELECT TREE SPECIES TO PREDICT VOLUMES FROM UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLE (UAV)-MEASURED VARIABLES; AND 4) AID IN THE UNDERSTANDING OF MANAGEMENT IMPLICATIONS AND DIFFERENCES WITHIN STANDS BASED ON GROWTH AND/OR ASSESSED HEALTH DIFFERENCES. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1. INCORPORATE READILY DEPLOYABLE TECHNOLOGY (E.G., AERIAL AND TERRESTRIAL LIDAR EQUIPMENT) TO ASSESS BIOMETRIC DATA; 2. COMPARE AERIAL AND TERRESTRIAL LIDAR DATA WITH HIGH-RESOLUTION IMAGERY AND FIELD-BASED MEASUREMENTS TO UNDERSTAND POTENTIAL BIAS OF REMOTELY-SENSED MEASURES IN FOREST INVENTORY MEASUREMENTS; 3. DEVELOP MODELS FOR SELECT TREE SPECIES TO PREDICT VOLUMES FROM UAV-MEASURED VARIABLES; 4. UNDERSTAND MANAGEMENT IMPLICATIONS AND DIFFERENCES WITHIN STANDS BASED ON GROWTH AND/OR ASSESSED HEALTH DIFFERENCES PROJECT INFORMATION METHODOLOGY DATA COLLECTION FOR THIS STUDY WILL INCLUDE REMOTELY-SENSED SOURCES (E.G., LIDAR AND VARIOUS RESOLUTION AERIAL AND SATELLITE DATA). FIELD DATA COLLECTION WILL TAKE PLACE ON SELECTED SITES MEASURING SINGLE TREES AND ON PLOT-BASED SAMPLES. COMMON IMAGE INDICES AND STATISTICAL ANALYSES WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR DATA ANALYSIS.

LEECH LAKE TRIBAL COLLEGE (LLTC) MENTORS STUDENTS IN INDIGENOUS SCIENCE AND SUPPORTS FOREST RESEARCH PROJECTS WITHIN LEECH LAKE NATION AND THE CHIPPEWA NATIONAL FOREST, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH AGENCIES INCLUDING THE LEECH LAKE DIVISION OF RESOURCE MANAGEMENT (DRM), THE UNITED STATES FOREST SERVICE (USFS), THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (MNDNR), AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC). LLTC'S FOREST ECOLOGY PROGRAM WILL COLLABORATE ON PROJECTS IN FOREST ECOLOGY AND RESTORATION, WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, FIRE SCIENCE AND RESTORATION, AQUATIC ECOLOGY, INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT, AND OJIBWE LANGUAGE AND CULTURE. THESE PROJECTS PROVIDE FACULTY AND STUDENTS WITH OPPORTUNITIES FOR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, RESEARCH EXPERIENCE, AND NETWORKING WITH LOCAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS. CONSIDERED TOGETHER, THESE PROJECTS HELP TO UNIFY AND STRENGTHEN LAND MANAGEMENT ON LEECH LAKE NATION AND AMONG PARTNERS IN A MULTIPLE-MANAGEMENT LANDSCAPE. ACTIVE RESEARCH EFFORTS INCLUDE: O REINTRODUCING FIRE TO AFIRE-DEPENDENT FOREST SYSTEM AND MONITORING ITS EFFECTS ON CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT RESOURCES SUCH AS MIINAN (BLUEBERRIES, OR VACCINIUM SPP.) O CATALOGING NATIVE ATAAGIB (FRESHWATER GREEN ALGAE, OR CHARA SPP.) O MONITORING AND REMOVING INVASIVE STARRY STONEWORT (NITELLOPSIS OBTUSA) O MONITORING NATIVE SPECIES OF AMOOG (BUMBLE BEES, OR BOMBUS SPP.), INCLUDING THE ENDANGERED RUSTY-PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) AND OBSERVING THEIR PREFERENCES IN PLANT SPECIES O COMPILING OJIBWE LANGUAGE, CULTURE, AND STORIES RELATED TO THE AFOREMENTIONED RESEARCH PROJECTS IN PREPARATION FOR AN UPDATED VERSION OF THE COLLEGE'S FIELD GUIDE "NANDO-GIKENIMINDWAA NINDINAWEMAAGANIDOG, GETTING TO KNOW ALL OF CREATION."  THESE PROJECTS WILL DIRECTLY SUPPORT THE OPERATIONS OF RESEARCH PROJECTS AMONG OUR PARTNERS HERE AT LEECH LAKE NATION. THE RESEARCH CONDUCTED WILL BE USED TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT OF CULTURALLY RELEVANT RESOURCES INCLUDING MIINAN, MANOOMIN (WILD RICE, OR ZIZANIA PALUSTRIS), BAPAKWANAGEMAG (RED PINE, OR PINUS RESINOSA), AND NUMEROUS WOODLAND PLANT SPECIES USED FOR MEDICINE INCLUDING WIINISIIBAG (WINTERGREEN, OR GAULTHERIA PROCUMBENS). IMPROVING THE MANAGEMENT OF ECOLOGICALLY FUNCTIONING FORESTS AND CULTURALLY RELEVANT RESOURCES SUPPORTS THE 2019 MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING BETWEEN THE LEECH LAKE BAND OF OJIBWE AND THE USFS, WHICH OUTLINES MANAGING THE FOREST IN CLOSER ALIGNMENT WITH INDIGENOUS VALUES.

THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS CAPACITY IS USED TO ASSIST STATES IN CARRYING OUT A PROGRAM OF STATE FORESTRY RESEARCH AT STATE FORESTRY SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES AND DEVELOPING A TRAINED POOL OF FOREST SCIENTISTS CAPABLE OF CONDUCTING NEEDED FORESTRY RESEARCH. RESEARCH FALLS UNDER ONE OF THE FOLLOWING TOPICS: 1.REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST 2.MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION 3.MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE 4.MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION 5.PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS 6.UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS 7.DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND THE HARVESTING AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS THE FIVE FACULTY-LED PROJECTS (DESCRIBED BELOW) ADDRESS ALL OF THE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ABOVE WITH A PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON NUMBERS 1, 2, 3, AND 5. EVALUATING CONSERVATION STRUCTURES OACTIVITIES: FARMERS, FARM LANDOWNERS, AND AGRIBUSINESS ARE UNDER PRESSURE TO ENHANCE THE DELIVERY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES FROM FARMS. THE ABILITY OF FARMS TO RETAIN NUTRIENTS AND SEDIMENT AND PROVIDE CLEAN WATER, FLOOD CONTROL, CARBON STORAGE, AND WILDLIFE HABITAT ARE OF INCREASING CONCERN TO SOCIETY, CORPORATIONS, AND POLICY MAKERS. FARMERS AND OTHER AGRICULTURAL MANAGERS NEED EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND TOOLS FOR SITING THEM TO MEET THESE NEW DEMANDS ALONGSIDE THE TRADITIONAL DEMANDS OF FOOD, FEED, AND FUEL PRODUCTION. THE PROPOSED PROJECT AIMS TO ASSIST FARMERS, FARM LANDOWNERS, AND THEIR TECHNICAL SERVICE PROVIDERS BY IMPROVING THE KNOWLEDGE BASIS FOR ADOPTING AND SITING ON-FARM CONSERVATION STRUCTURES INCLUDING PRAIRIE STRIPS, BIOREACTORS, RIPARIAN BUFFERS, SATURATED BUFFERS, AND GRASS PATCHES. EARLY WORK ESTABLISHES THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THESE CONSERVATION STRUCTURES FOR PROVIDING A RANGE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, BUT HAS BEEN CONDUCTED OVER ECOLOGICALLY SHORT-TIME PERIODS OR AT A LIMITED NUMBER OF SITES. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL EXPAND UPON THE EXISTING KNOWLEDGE THROUGH ADDITIONAL DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS TO ADDRESS THE PRODUCTION OF MULTIPLE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ASSOCIATED WITH THESE CONSERVATION STRUCTURES OVER A LONGER PERIOD OF MEASUREMENT AND A BROADER GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT. ADDITIONAL DATA AND ANALYSIS WILL ALLOW US TO QUANTIFY VARIABILITY IN TIME AND SPACE, OFFERING AN UNDERSTANDING THE GENERALIZABILITY OF EXISTING AND NEW RESULTS. SUCH UNDERSTANDING IS ESSENTIAL FOR THEIR PROPER SITING AND MANAGEMENT OF CONSERVATION STRUCTURES ACROSS A VARIETY OF ENVIRONMENTAL. ODELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES: WE REGULARLY INTERACT WITH VESTED STAKEHOLDER GROUPS TO DISSEMINATE RESULTS AND RECEIVE FEEDBACK ON USER INFORMATION NEEDS. OUTLETS HAVE INCLUDED DIRECT CONTACT WITH FARMERS AND FARMLAND OWNERS THROUGH RESEARCH BEING CONDUCTED ON THEIR FARMS; PRESENTATIONS AT FIELD DAYS, CONFERENCES, ISU EXTENSION TRAININGS, AND WEBINARS; AND THROUGH AD HOC MEETINGS AND DIRECT CONSULTATION. DURING THIS REPORTING PERIOD WE HAVE MADE 47 PRESENTATIONS TO A COMBINATION OF SCIENTIFIC, AGENCY, FARM MANAGEMENT, AND CONSERVATION GROUPS, REACHING APPROXIMATELY 1,410 PEOPLE.  BECAUSE MANY PRESENTATIONS WERE MADE THROUGH A VIRTUAL FORMAT THIS YEAR, BECAUSE OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, MOST PRESENTATIONS WERE RECORDED AND CONTINUE TO BE BROADLY AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC. INFORMATION HAS ALSO BEEN DISTRIBUTED THROUGH A VARIETY OF MEDIA OUTLETS, INCLUDING THE CEDAR RAPIDS GAZETTE, NATIONAL PUBLIC RADIO, OMAHA WORLD HERALD, SUCCESSFUL FARMING, AND WALLACE'S FARMER, AMONG OTHER OUTLETS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: FARMERS AND FARM LAND OWNERS, AGRIBUSINESS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, AND OTHER AGRICULTURAL AND FORESTRY STAKEHOLDERS ARE THE MAIN TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THIS WORK.THESE STAKEHOLDERS MAY INCLUDE PEOPLE WORKING FOR UNIVERSITIES, AGENCIES (E.G., IOWA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND LAND STEWARDSHIP, IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, US FOREST SERVICE, USDA FARM SERVICE AGENCY, USDA NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION SERVICE), NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (E.G., IOWA FARM BUREAU FEDERATION, IOWA NATURAL HERITAGE FOUNDATION, IOWA SOYBEAN ASSOCIATION, IOWA WILDLIFE FEDERATION, PRACTICAL FARMERS OF IOWA, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, TREES FOREVER), OR PRIVATE CONSULTANTS (E.G., CERTIFIED CROP ADVISORS, FARM MANAGERS, CONSULTING FORESTERS, TECHNICAL SERVICE PROVIDERS). SATELLITE-BASED FOREST STRUCTURE O ACTIVITIES: THE SUCCESS OF SPACE-BASED FOREST DEFOLIATION MONITORING BEYOND THEMATIC CLASSIFICATION HINGES ON OUR ABILITY TO LINK UNITS OF CONTINUOUS FOLIAR CHANGE WITH ASSOCIATED UNITS OF SPECTRAL CHANGE ACROSS DIFFERENT FOREST-INSECT SYSTEMS. RESEARCH DURING THIS REPORTING PERIOD USED MULTI-TEMPORAL LANDSAT SENSOR DATA AND FIELDDEFOLIATION DATA ACROSS THREE DIFFERENT FOREST SYSTEMS IN THE UNITED STATES (SPRUCE BUDWORM [SBW], JACK PINE BUDWORM [JPBW], AND SPONGY MOTH [SM]) TO COMPARE LEVELS OF DEFOLIATION WITH SATELLITE-BASED SPECTRAL RESPONSE. WE FOUND THAT FOR SIMILAR LEVELS OF DEFOLIATION ACROSS DIFFERENT FOREST SYSTEMS, SPECTRAL RESPONSE VARIED SIGNIFICANTLY BETWEEN BUDWORM AND SPONGY MOTH SYSTEMS AND, DEPENDING ON FIELD DATA USED, BETWEEN THE BUDWORM SYSTEMS (I.E., SBW <(>&<)> JPBW) AS WELL. THIS IS THE FIRST STUDY TO REPORT THAT, FOR A GIVEN QUANTITY OF DEFOLIATION, SUBSTANTIAL DIFFERENCES IN BOTH THE MAGNITUDE AND DIRECTION OF VEGETATION INDEX CHANGE EXISTS AMONG DIFFERENT DEFOLIATOR SYSTEMS, WHICH CURRENTLY PRECLUDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF A VIABLE, UNIFIED DEFOLIATION MODEL. OTHER RESEARCH FINDINGS DURING THIS REPORTING PERIOD SUGGEST THAT THERE MAY BE AN INSECT OUTBREAK FLIP MECHANISM OCCURRING BETWEEN SBW AND THE FOREST TENT CATERPILLAR (MALACOSOMA DISSTRIA, FTC) IN THE SAME REGION. OUR CONTINUED INSECT-HOST SIMULATION MODELING RESEARCH IN THE COMING YEARS AIMS TO CONFIRM THIS THEORY. O DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES: WE HAVE REACHED OUR TARGET AUDIENCES THROUGH PUBLICATIONS AND CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS. FOR THIS REPORTING PERIOD WE PUBLISHED FOUR PAPERS WITH ONE MORE PAPER IN REVIEW, HAVE AUTHORED OR CO-AUTHORED PRESENTATIONS WITH MORE PLANNED, AND RESULTS OF THIS WORK ARE ALSO AVAILABLE VIA USFS WEBSITES: HTTP://WWW.NRS.FS.FED.US/DISTURBANCE/FIRE/EXTREME_FIRE_EFFECTS_MN/ O INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE TARGET AUDIENCES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE FORESTLAND MANAGERS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, PRIVATE INDUSTRIAL FORESTS, AND OTHER FOREST OR FORESTRY STAKEHOLDERS. THESE INCLUDE THE US FOREST SERVICE, CANADIAN FOREST SERVICE, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, COUNTY LAND DEPARTMENTS, STATE DNR, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (E.G., THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, ECOFORESTRY INSTITUTE SOCIETY, AMERICAN FOREST FOUNDATION), OR PRIVATE CONSULTANTS WITH MANAGEMENT FOCUS. TERTIARY AUDIENCES INCLUDE UNIVERSITY STUDENTS. ECOLOGICAL AND SOCIAL DYNAMICS RELATED TO URBAN ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCY OACTIVITIES: WE CONTINUED TO COLLECT DATA TO DETERMINE WATER QUALITY AND WATER QUANTITY OUTCOMES ASSOCIATED WITH USE OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN URBAN WATERSHEDS IN CEDAR FALLS AND DES MOINES, IOWA. DATA ARE BEING USED TO DEVELOP STORMWATER MANAGEMENT SIMULATION MODELS TO ASSESS AND PREDICT THE POTENTIAL FOR WATERSHED IMPACTS OF CLUSTERED PRACTICES ON OUTFLOWS FROM FOUR SUBWATERSHEDS. DATA FROM SURVEYS ADMINISTERED TO RESIDENTS IN THE SAME WATERSHED AREAS HAVE BEEN ANALYZED TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF KNOWLEDGE, ATTITUDES, OPINIONS AND BELIEFS ON VOLUNTARY HOMEOWNER ADOPTION OF A SET OF RESIDENTIAL LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. WE CONTINUED TO ASSESS EFFECTS OF VEGETATION ON BUILDING ENERGY DYNAMICS THROUGH PROVIDING SHADE AND COOLING ROM EVAPOTRANSPIRATION IN NEAR-BUILDING MICROENVIRONMENTS IN DES MOINES, IOWA. WE DEVELOPED A SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS TO ASSESS THE EFFECTS OF THE URBAN HEAT ISLAND ON BUILDING ENERGY USE. WE CONTINUED TO ASSEMBLE DATASETS TO FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT OF LIFE-CYCLE ASSESSMENT, ECOHYDROLOGICAL, AND ENERGY-USE MODELS FOR AN INTEGRATED ASSESSMENT OF TABLE FOOD PRODUCTION FOR THE DES MOINES METROPOLITAN STATISTICAL AREA. MODELS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED USING HISTORICAL DATA AND WILL BE USED TO PREDICT FUTURE SYSTEM DYNAMICS UNDER SCENARIOS INCLUDING CHANGES IN CLIMATE, LAND USE AND FOOD PRODUCTION LEVELS AT VARIOUS SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL SCALES. INITIAL WORK HAS BEEN CONDUCTED TO USE SEVERAL PAIRS OF MODELS IN PRELIMINARY CO-SIMULATION APPLICATIONS. WORK WAS COMPLETED ON DEVELOPMENT OF GUIDELINES FOR PLANT MATERIAL SOURCING FOR HABITAT RE STORATION AND CONSERVATION. ODELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES: RESULTS FOR WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY ASSESSMENTS HAVE BEEN DISSEMINATED IN MEETINGS WITH WATERSHED COO RDINATORS AND TO WATERSHED RESIDENTS IN TWO NEW BROCHURES ON STORMWATER MANAGEMENT AND ONE VIRTUAL WORKSHOP FOR THESE AUDIENCES. RESULTS FOR WATERSHEDRESIDENT SURVEY RESULTS WERE ALSO SHARED IN ONE CONFERENCE PRESENTATION, AND RESULTS FOR WATER QUALITY ASSESSMENTS WERE SHARED IN ONE POPULAR-PRESS ARTICLE AND ONE SYMPOSIUM PRESENTATION. A VIRTUAL (VIDEOTAPED) FIELD TOUR FOCUSED ON URBAN STORMWATER MANAGEMENT WAS DELIVERED IN A HOSTED CONFERENCE TO A LIVE AUDIENCE OF75 PARTICIPANTS THAT INCLUDED WATERSHED IMPROVEMENT COORDINATORS AND ENGINEERS, AND WAS THEN MADE AVAILABLE ON AN IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY WEBSITE FOR SEVERAL MONTHS. RESULTS FOR INTEGRATION OF BIOPHYSICAL AND SOCIAL SYSTEM DATA HAVE BEEN SHARED IN MEETINGS WITH PROJECT STAKEHOLDERS, LOCAL SUSTAINABILITY TASK FORCES, AND IN PRESENTATIONS AT LOCAL, REGIONAL, NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCES, AS WELL AS IN THEIR PROCEEDINGS. ADDITIONAL RESULTS HAVE BEEN SHARED IN TWO PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS IN INTERNATIONAL JOURNALS. WORK ON BIODIVERSITY IN URBAN AREAS WAS INCLUDED IN TWO PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS AND AN ACCESSIBLE ONLINE WEB-BASED PRESENTATION. OINTENDED BENEFICIARIES:AUDIENCES FOR THIS WORK INCLUDE CITY RESIDENTS, LOCAL AND REGIONAL PLANNERS, WATERSHED IMPROVEMENT COORDINATORS, CIVIC OFFICIALS, CITY SUSTAINABILITY MANAGERS, CITIZEN SUSTAINABILITY TASK FORCE MEMBERS, PUBLIC WORKS PERSONNEL, STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS, FOREST MANAGERS, FORESTRY CONSULTANTS, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCY PERSONNEL, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL AGENCY PERSONNEL. RESULTS FROM WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY ASSESSMENTS HAVE BEEN SHARED AT WORKSHOPS, MEETINGS AND OUTREACH EVENTS WITH NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS AND RESIDENTS TO LEAD TO INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS OF STORMWATER ISSUES AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. SILVICULTURAL APPROACHES FOR MAINTAINING AND ENHANCING FOREST ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND HABITAT IN THE UPPER MIDWEST REGION OACTIVITIES: RESEARCH DURING THIS PERIOD ADVANCED UNDERSTANDING OF THE SHORT-TERM FOREST BIRD RESPONSE TO SUDDEN MORTALITY (FROM TREATMENT) OF INVASIVE HONEYSUCKLE IN THE MID-STORY OF UPLAND DRY MESIC OAK FORESTS. RESULTS CONFIRMED THE EFFECTIVENESS OF AERIAL HERBICIDE APPLICATION AS A TREATMENT FOR INVASIVE HONEYSUCKLE AS WELL AS THE POTENTIAL NEED FOR FOLLOW-UP TREATMENT WITHIN FIVE YEARS. RESULTS ALSO ILLUSTRATED THE IMPORTANCE OF HERBACEOUS UNDERSTORY COVER (POSITIVELY IMPACTED BY HONEYSUCKLE REMOVAL) FOR SHRUB AND GROUND-ASSOCIATED BIRDS. A GRADUATE STUDENT COMPLETED HER M.S. THESIS ON THIS PROJECT. WE ALSO PUBLISHED AN INTRODUCTION TO A SPECIAL ISSUE SHOWCASING 20-30-YEAR RESULTS FROM AN INTERNATIONAL NETWORK OF LONG-TERM STUDIES FOCUSED ON THE COMBINED IMPACTS OF BIOMASS REMOVAL AND SOIL DISTURBANCE ON FOREST ECOSYSTEM PRODUCTIVITY. VEGETATION DATA WERE COLLECTED ON A REPLICATED BEFORE AND AFTER STUDY OF THE IMPACT OF AERIAL TREATMENT OF INVASIVE HONEYSUCKLE ON UPLAND DRY-MESIC OAK FORESTS OF SOUTHERN IOWA. THIS WAS THE FIRST POST-TREATMENT GROWING SEASON AND RESULTS, ONCE ANALYZED, WILL QUANTIFY THE IMMEDIATE IMPACTS OF TREATMENT ON INVASIVE HONEYSUCKLE, OTHER WOODY SHRUBS, TREE REGENERATION, AND HERBACEOUS UNDERSTORY PLANTS. FOREST INVENTORY DATA WERE ALSO COLLECTED ACROSS STATE-OWNED LANDS IN THE DRIFTLESS AREA IN A RECONNAISSANCE EFFORT THAT LED TO THE IDENTIFICATION OF 7-10 SITES FOR INCLUSION IN A LONG-TERM (20+ YEAR) FOREST CLIMATE ADAPTATION EXPERIMENT. LASTLY, A FIELD TOUR AND ASSOCIATED WORKSHOP WAS HELD FOR FOREST AND WILDLIFE MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS IN THE TRI-STATE REGION (WISCONSIN, MINNESOTA, AND IOWA) TO BEGIN A COLLABORATIVE PROCESS FOR DEVELOPING CLIMATE ADAPTIVE SILVICULTURE FOR DRY MESIC OAK FORESTS OF THE DRIFTLESS AREA. ODELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES: RESEARCH RESULTS WERE COMMUNICATED TO FOREST AND WILDLIFE MANAGERS, SCIENTISTS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH A VARIETY OF VENUES, MOSTLY VIRTUAL DUE TO CONTINUED IMPACTS FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS INCLUDED THE ECOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA ANNUAL MEETING, THE NORTHERN HARDWOODS CONFERENCE, THE IOWA CHAPTER OF THE WILDLIFE SOCIETY ANNUAL MEETING, THE IOWA SOCIETY OF AMERICAN FORESTERS FALL MEETING, AND THE SOIL SCIENCE SOCIETY OF AMERICA ANNUAL MEETING. OUR RESEARCH, PUBLICATIONS, PRESENTATIONS, AND WORKSHOPS INCREASED THE UNDERSTANDING OF CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITIES AND OPPORTUNITIES IN MIDWESTERN FORESTS, INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL TREATMENTS AND IMPACTS, AND LONG-TERM FOREST ECOSYSTEM RESPONSE TO EXPERIMENTAL DISTURBANCE. OINTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THIS PROJECT DURING THIS PERIOD INCLUDED THE IOWA, MINNESOTA, AND WISCONSIN FORESTRY COMMUNITY (FORESTERS, WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS, OTHER LAND MANAGERS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS) AND THE FOREST SCIENCE COMMUNITY. PARTNERS INCLUDE THE USFS NORTHERN RESEARCH STATION, THE NORTHERN INSTITUTE OF APPLIED CLIMATE SCIENCE, THE ADAPTIVE SILVICULTURE FOR CLIMATE CHANGE NETWORK, IOWA DNR, MINNESOTA DNR, WISCONSIN DNR, AND NGOS. REFERENCE CONDITIONS FOR RESTORATION OF MIDWESTERN STREAMS AND RIPARIAN CORRIDORS OACTIVITIES: THIS PROJECT EXPLORES THE RECENT ENVIRONMENTAL HISTORY OF STREAMS AND THEIR RIPARIAN CORRIDORS IN IOWA AND SURROUNDING REGIONS. THIS HISTORY, COMBINED WITH EXISTING CONDITIONS, PROVIDES KEY INSIGHT THAT CAN GUIDE THE RESTORATION OF STREAM AND FLOODPLAIN ECOSYSTEMS. IN 2020 AND 2021, OUR TEAM VISITED OVER 40 STREAM REACHES AROUND THE STATE OF IOWA AND COLLECTED CHANNEL GEOMETRY AND HYDROLOGICAL DATA. SOME OF THESE SITES WERE DEGRADED, BUT SELECTED REACHES ALSO INCLUDED BIO NET REFERENCE OR CANDIDATE REFERENCE REACHES, BASED ON PAST DNR DATA INDICATING HEALTHY STREAM BIOTA. THESE DATA HAVE NOW BEEN THOROUGHLY ANALYZED TO REVEAL PATTERNS IN CHANNEL WIDTH, DEPTH, AND BANK FULL DISCHARGE AS THEY VARY WITH WATERSHED SIZE. THIS ANALYSIS LED TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF "REGIONAL CURVES", WHICH PROVIDE BASELINE DATA FOR ENGINEERS AND ECOLOGISTS DESIGNING STREAM RESTORATION PROJECTS AROUND THE STATE. ONE KEY FINDING IN THIS ANALYSIS HAS BEEN THAT STREAMS IN URBAN WATERSHEDS (WHERE URBAN LAND COVER IS MORE THAN 10% OF WATERSHED AREA) ARE SYSTEMATICALLY LARGER IN WIDTH AND DEPTH THAN THOSE IN MORE RURAL WATERSHEDS. O DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES: WE JOINED COLLEAGUES IN A SPRING 2020 SUMMIT ON FORESTRY AND WATER QUALITY IN IOWA, IN WHICH WE DISCUSSED OUR PRELIMINARY FINDINGS REGARDING THE ROLE OF RIPARIAN FOREST IN WATER QUALITY WITH SEVERAL DOZEN ACADEMIC, AGENCY, AND NGO STAFF FROM AROUND THE STATE. WE ALSO SERVED ON A PANEL ADDRESSING JOHNSON COUNTY CONSERVATION DISTRICT CONTRACTORS TO ADDRESS THE VALUE OF RIPARIAN TREES IN STREAM CHANNEL STABILITY AND STREAM HEALTH. A GRADUATE STUDENT PRESENTED PRELIMINARY REGIONAL CURVES FROM OBJECTIVE 3 AT THE UPPER MIDWEST STREAM RESTORATION SYMPOSIUM IN FEBRUARY 2020. CONTINUING COMMUNICATION WITH STAKEHOLDERS IN THE IOWA DNR RIVER PROGRAMS IS KEEPING REGIONAL CURVES UP TO DATE AND SUPPLYING ADDITIONAL SUPPORTING DATA. O INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: PRELIMINARY REGIONAL CURVES HAVE BEEN SUPPLIED TO THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WHICH MAINTAINS THE "IOWA RIVER RESTORATION TOOLBOX", WHICH IS A DECISION SUPPORT TOOL FOR STREAM RESTORATION AROUND THE STATE. REGIONAL CURVES ARE PROGRAMMED INTO THE TOOLBOX AS A WAY FOR DNR STAFF AND RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS TO IDENTIFY EXISTING CONDITIONS OR PROPOSED RESTORED CONDITIONS IN THEIR PROJECT REACH(ES) THAT ARE LIKELY TO BE UNSTABLE. THE TOOLBOX IS WIDELY USED WITHIN THE STATE OF IOWA, AS WELL AS IN SOME ADJACENT STATES. PRIOR TO OUR PROJECT, STREAM DESIGNERS IN IOWA HAD TO SELECT FROM CURVES DEVELOPED IN MINNESOTA OR NORTH CAROLINA, BOTH OF WHICH LED TO SIGNIFICANT RISK OF RESTORATION FAILURE, EITHER DUE TO OVERSIZED CHANNELS THAT WOULD PROVIDE INADEQUATE MOISTURE TO RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEMS OR UNDERSIZED CHANNELS THAT FLOOD EXCESSIVELY.

ABSTRACT INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY IS REVOLUTIONIZING INDUSTRIES AROUND THE WORLD, FROM HEALTHCARE TO MANUFACTURING. AGRICULTURE IS EXPERIENCING SIGNIFICANT GROWTH BY INCORPORATING NEW TECHNOLOGIES LIKE VARIABLE-RATE APPLICATIONS AND AUTOMATED HARVESTING. HOWEVER, FORESTRY HAS LAGGED BEHIND MOST OTHER INDUSTRIES IN THE ADOPTION OF INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY AS PROCESSES IN MOST FORESTRY PRACTICES ARE LARGELY MANUAL. WHILE A WIDE RANGE OF FORESTRY TECHNOLOGIES EXISTS, RELATIVELY FEW PRACTICAL EXAMPLES ARE UP AND RUNNING, AND FEW UNDERSTAND HOW THE TECHNOLOGIES TRANSLATE INTO REAL USE CASES. STATE FOREST OWNERS, PUBLIC FOREST OWNERS AND SMALL PRIVATE OWNERS (HOLDING LESS THAN TWO-AND-A-HALF ACRES) TEND TO BE RELATIVELY CONSERVATIVE IN THEIR MANAGEMENT STYLE AND, TO A GREATER EXTENT THAN PRIVATE ENTERPRISE. THUS, THERE IS A NEED TO BALANCE DIVERSE OBJECTIVES FOR COMMERCIAL PERFORMANCE WITH SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL GOALS. THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL USE REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGY IN THE FORM OF CAMERAS, DIGITAL ANALYZERS, UAVS (DRONE TECHNOLOGY) AND SENSORS TO MONITOR AND EVALUATE FOREST HEALTH TO IMPROVE MANAGING/DECISION-MAKING AND ADDRESS THE MCINTIRE STENNIS (MS) FORESTRY RESEARCH MANDATED AREA OF "..MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST". AS RESULTS IN THE FORM OF FOREST MAPPING, CARBON MONITORING, SOIL CONDITIONS AND COMPOSITION/FUEL ANALYSES ARE GENERATED, AWARENESS AND OUTREACH TO SMALL <(>&<)> MEDIUM-SIZED FOREST LANDOWNERS WILL TAKE PLACE IN THE FORM OF WORKSHOPS AND TECHNOLOGY TRAINING SESSIONS. BY ALIGNING WITH STRATEGIC GOAL 2 "ENSURE AMERICA'S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM IS EQUITABLE, RESILIENT, AND PROSPEROUS", THIS MS PROJECT WILL TARGET SMALL TO MEDIUM FORESTRY/LANDOWNERS IN GEORGIA WITH EFFORTS TO IMPROVE FOREST MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND EXPAND THE ADOPTION OF REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGIES IN FORESTRY.

COLORADO AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (CAES) CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES THAT SPECIFICALLY IMPACT COLORADO. CAES IS AN INTEGRAL UNIT OF COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY ALIGNED WITHIN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. CAES CONDUCTS RESEARCH IN 13 DEPARTMENTS AT THE MAIN CAMPUS IN FORT COLLINS, AT 8 OFF-CAMPUS RESEARCH CENTERS (9 SITES) THROUGHOUT COLORADO, AND WITH INDIVIDUAL COOPERATORS. CAES IS UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO AID GROWERS, PRODUCERS, FOOD ENTREPRENEURS, POLICY MAKERS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH THE STRENGTH OF ITS FACULTY, EXTENSION STAFF, FORESTRY UNIT, AND (130- YEAR) LONG LEGACY OF SCIENTIFIC ADVANCEMENT IN AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. THE CAES MANAGES THE COLORADO FUNDING PERTAINING TO MCINTIRE-STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH, WHICH SUPPORTS THE STATE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAMS THAT SPECIFICALLY IMPACT COLORADO STAKEHOLDERS. THESE FUNDS ARE PROVIDED DIRECTLY TO THE COLORADO STATE FOREST SERVICE TO PROVIDES TECHNICAL FORESTRY ASSISTANCE, WILDFIRE MITIGATION EXPERTISE AND OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO HELP LANDOWNERS AND COMMUNITIES ACHIEVE THEIR FOREST MANAGEMENT GOALS.

THE CONNECTICUT AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION RECEIVES MCINTIRE-STENNIS ACT CAPACITY FUNDING TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGES AND PRIORITY AREAS IDENTIFIED BY CONNECTICUT RESIDENTS. THE PRIORITY RESEARCH AREAS INCLUDE: (1) MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY OF FOREST RESOURCES: FOR EXAMPLE, MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECT ACCESSION NO. 1023296 AND 1012606 SUPPORTED A DISTRIBUTION SURVEY OF BEECH LEAF DISEASE IN CONNECTICUT IN ORDER TO ESTABLISH ITS EXTENT IN 2020 AND HAS SUPPORTED SUBSEQUENT ANNUAL SURVEYS TO CHART THE GEOGRAPHICAL SPREAD OF THE DISEASE ACROSS THE STATE ALONG WITH CHANGES IN FREQUENCY AND INTENSITY WITHIN STANDS ACROSS A RANGE OF STAND AGES. MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECT ACCESSION NO. 1023296 IS CURRENTLY TO DEVELOPING GENETIC TOOLS ESSENTIAL TO IMPROVING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF HOW THE CAUSAL AGENT (A NEMATODE, LITYLENCHUS CRENATAE MCCANNII) MOVES WITHIN SITES AND FROM ONE SITE TO ANOTHER. ANOTHER EXAMPLE IS MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECT ACCESSION NO. 1024391 EXPLORING THE USE OF BIOLOGICAL CONTROLS TO CONTROL HEMLOCK WOOLLY ADELGID (HWA, ADELGES TSUGAE) ALONG WITH THE INFLUENCE OF CLIMATIC FACTORS ON HWA. BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AGENTS, INCLUDING THE INTRODUCED LADYBEETLE PREDATOR (SASAJISCYMNUS TSUGAE), ARE THE ONLY VIABLE ALTERNATIVE TO MAINTAINING THIS INTEGRAL PART OF OUR FOREST ECOSYSTEMS. (2) INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS: FOR EXAMPLE, MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECT ACCESSION NO. 7001298 IS INVESTIGATING ALTERNATIVE HOST-TARGETED STRATEGIES REDUCING TICK ABUNDANCES IN RESIDENTIAL SETTINGS IN THE URBAN-RURAL INTERFACE. AS LYME DISEASE (LD) CONTINUES TO BE THE MOST COMMONLY REPORTED VECTOR-BORNE ILLNESS IN THE UNITED STATES, THIS WORK WILL BE USED TO IMPROVE PUBLIC HEALTH BY REDUCING THE NUMBER OF LYME DISEASE CASES (3) URBAN FORESTRY: FOR EXAMPLE, MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECT ACCESSION NO. 1023745 IS DEVELOPING TOOLS FOR DETECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF STRESSED URBAN TREES AND IS DEVELOPING STRATEGIES TO ENHANCE STRESS TOLERANCE IN URBAN TREES. CONNECTICUT'S URBAN AREAS HAVE THE HIGHEST TREE COVER IN THE UNITED STATES AND MAINTAINING A HEALTHY FOREST CANOPY COVER IN URBAN AREAS IS CRITICAL FOR PUBLIC HEALTH, HABITABILITY OF URBAN AREAS, AND BIODIVERSITY. RESEARCH WILL BENEFIT NOT ONLY URBAN RESIDENTS, BUT MUNICIPAL OFFICIALS AND ARBORISTS RESPONSIBLE FOR MAINTAINING TREE HEALTH. ANOTHER EXAMPLE IS MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECT ACCESSION NO. 1018306 THAT HAS BEEN EXAMINING THE MANAGEMENT OF EMERALD ASH BORER (AGRILUS PLANIPENNIS) IN URBAN, HIGH VALUE ASH TREES. THE STUDY HAS BEEN TESTING EFFECTIVE, NON-TOXIC ALTERNATIVES TO SEVERAL HIGHLY EFFECTIVE INSECTICIDES THAT WILL PROTECT INDIVIDUAL TREES, YET ALL ARE TOXIC TO NATIVE INSECTS AND POTENTIALLY POLLINATORS IN ADDITION TO THE TARGET PEST.

THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY (OSU) APPROVED PLAN OF WORK (POW) ENCOMPASSES A FIVE?YEAR PERIOD BEGINNING ON OCTOBER 1, 2022 AND REPRESENTS A JOINT EFFORT BY THE TWO CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF OSU'S COLLEGE OF FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES (CFAES): THE OHIO AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (ALSO KNOWN AS OARDC) AND OSU EXTENSION. CFAES RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS ARE CONDUCTED IN NINE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS ON OUR CAMPUSES IN COLUMBUS AND WOOSTER; ELEVEN RESEARCH STATIONS AND FIELD LABS; AND IN ALL 88 COUNTIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. FACULTY IN CFAES ENGAGE IN RESEARCH FROM VERY BASIC CELLULAR LEVEL RESPONSES TO APPLICATIONS OF DISEASE AND PEST MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS DEVELOPING NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND USES FOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS AND WASTE. WHILE THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY IS THE LARGEST INDUSTRY IN THE BUCKEYE STATE, CFAES RESEARCH REACHES BEYOND AGRICULTURE AND COVERS ENVIRONMENTAL, WATER QUALITY AND SOCIETAL ISSUES THAT RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES FACE. CFAES RECENTLYUPDATED OUR STRATEGIC PLAN, INCLUDING THE GOALS LISTED BELOW TO GUIDE OUR WORK AND ACTIONS AT ALL LEVELS AND WITH INVOLVEMENT OF RESEARCH FACULTY IN ALL AREAS. GOAL 1: STUDENT/LEARNER FIRST PHILOSOPHY ? CFAES TEACHING REACHES ACROSS THE LIFESPAN FROM YOUTH SERVED THROUGH 4?H PROGRAMS TO STUDENTS PURSUING DEGREES ON CAMPUS TO 2 MILLION PLUS LIFELONG LEARNERS IN EXTENSION PROGRAMS. GOAL 2: INNOVATIVE SCHOLARSHIP TO SUSTAIN LIFE ? CFAES RESEARCH PROJECTS AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS ADDRESS OUR CRITICAL ISSUES WHICH COVER AREAS IN HEALTH AND WELLNESS, ECONOMIC VITALITY, FOOD SECURITY AND PRODUCTION, ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND SUSTAINABILITY AS WELL AS HELPING PEOPLE THRIVE ACROSS THE LIFESPAN. GOAL 3: CAPACITY BUILDING OF OUR PEOPLE AND OUR COMMUNITIES ? PEOPLE ARE OUR GREATEST ASSET AND CFAES STRIVES TO BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF OUR PEOPLE. CHANGING WORKFORCE DYNAMICS, COVID?19 PRESSURES, MARKET COMPETITION, ECONOMIC DRIVERS, AN INCREASING DESIRE FOR A MORE BALANCED APPROACH TO HOW LIFE AND WORKINTERFACE, AND A NEED FOR DIVERSIFYING OUR TALENT. GOAL 4: PARTNER OF CHOICE ? CFAES WANTS TO ENGAGE OUR ENTIRE COMMUNITY, INCLUDING BOTH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS. GOAL 5: RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP IN A ONE?COLLEGE MODEL ? CFAES CONTINUES TO TRANSFORM AND IMPROVE OUR PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENT ACROSS OUR THREE CAMPUSES. A NEW SCIENCE BUILDING PROVIDING MODERN RESEARCH SPACE WAS RECENTLY COMPLETED ON THE WOOSTER CAMPUS AND THE NEW CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT AGRICULTURE RESEARCH COMPLEX, WILL OPEN SOON AT WATERMAN FARM ON THE COLUMBUS CAMPUS. THE JOINT POW WAS DEVELOPED AROUND THESE GOALS AS WELL AS FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES. 1) HEALTH AND WELLNESS - EXPLORING HEALTH RELATED ISSUES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO MENTAL HEALTH AWARENESS AND INITIATIVES, HEALTH INEQUITY, CHRONIC DISEASE AND OBESITY PREVENTION, COMMUNITY NUTRITION EDUCATION, AND FARM SAFETY. 2) ECONOMIC VITALITY - ISSUES RELATED TO ECONOMIC VITALITY INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO BUSINESS RETENTION AND EXPANSION, ENHANCING RURAL ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES, INCREASING BROADBAND ACCESS IN RURAL AREAS, THE EFFECTS OF TRADE POLICIES ON FOOD AND AG INDUSTRIES, AND THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT. 3) FOOD SECURITY AND PRODUCTION - WE WILL EXPLORE ISSUES RELATED TO MITIGATING FOOD INSECURITY THROUGH COMMUNITY SERVICE AND FOOD PRODUCTION EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND FOOD SYSTEM SUSTAINABILITY INCLUDING DIGITAL AGRICULTURE, CLIMATE SMART AGRICULTURE, IMPROVED FOOD ANIMAL HEALTH AND PRODUCTION, CROP IMPROVEMENT AND RESILIENCY, WEED AND PEST CONTROL, PLANT BREEDING AND DISEASE RESISTANCE, NUTRIENT DENSE FOODS, NEW FOOD PRESERVATIVES, AND ANTIMICROBIAL FOOD PACKAGING. 4) ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND SUSTAINABILITY. RESEARCH TOPICS COVER AREAS SUCH AS SOIL HEALTH AND REMEDIATION, BIOLOGICAL CONTROL AGENTS, REDUCTION OF PESTICIDE USE, SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF POLYMERS AND BIOPLASTICS, WATER QUALITY AND WASTEWATER TREATMENT, AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM HEALTH, AIR QUALITY AND SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF BIOPRODUCTS AND RENEWABLE FUELS. 5) THRIVING ACROSS THE LIFESPAN ? PROGRAMS UNDER THIS CRITICAL ISSUE ARE RELATED TO POSITIVE HUMAN DEVELOPMENT FOR ALL AGES. A MAJOR FOCUS IS YOUTH DEVELOPMENT THROUGH 4?H AND FINANCIAL LITERACY PROGRAMS.

MCINTIRE -STENNIS RESEARCH/ACTIVITIESAT ALABAMA A<(>&<)>M UNIVERSITY ALABAMA A<(>&<)>M UNIVERSITY MCINTIRE-STENNIS FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM INCLUDES SILVICULTURAL STRATEGIES FOR RESTORING MIXED PINE-HARDWOOD FOREST AND NATIVE GRASSES, DETECTING RARE AND ENDANGERED WILDLIFE SPECIES, ECOLOGICAL PATTERNS OF FOREST DYNAMICS, EFFECTS OF FOREST MANAGEMENT ON AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL BIOINDICATORS, IMPROVED FOREST OPERATIONS, AND MINORITY PARTICIPATION IN OUTDOOR RECREATION. MOST OF OUR RESEARCH IS CONDUCTED IN COLLABORATION WITH THE USDA FOREST SERVICE, SOUTHERN RESEARCH STATION, NATIONAL FORESTS IN ALABAMA, AND (FIA) FOREST INVENTORY AND ANALYSIS. WE ARE QUANTIFYING THE OCCURRENCE, CHARACTERISTICS, AND MANAGEMENT OF PINE-HARDWOOD FORESTS IN THE NORTH ALABAMA REGION, ASSESSING THEIR ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE, AND ESTABLISHING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN PRODUCTIVITY AND DIVERSITY AND THE IMPACT OF RECREATION AND OTHER HUMAN INFLUENCES ON THE TRENDS IN REGENERATION AND SPECIES COMPOSITION. OTHER OBJECTIVES INCLUDE INVESTIGATING THE BEHAVIOR, USE PATTERNS, AND PARTICIPATION LEVELS IN RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES BY VISITORS TO THE BANKHEAD NATIONAL FOREST AND IDENTIFYING THE FACTORS WHICH LIMIT THE USE OF THE WILDERNESS AREAS BY MINORITIES. ECOLOGICAL GEOMETRY IS SEARCHED IN FOREST STRUCTURES AND FUNCTIONS. THROUGH PERIODIC MONITORING OF ABUNDANCE, SPECIES OF TREE INDIVIDUALS, AND THEIR GROWTH RATES AT DIFFERENT FORESTS (INCLUDING MIXED BROADLEAVED FORESTS AND PINE PLANTATIONS) ACROSS SPATIAL SCALES BY GROUND MONITORING, REMOTE SENSING, AND GIS DATA, INDICES OF ECOLOGICAL GEOMETRY ARE DEVELOPED TO STUDY THE SPATIAL-TEMPORAL DYNAMICS IN FOREST STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONS. THE IMPLICATIONS OF ECOLOGICAL GEOMETRY IN FOREST MANAGEMENT WILL BE EXPLORED IN RESTORATION, PRESCRIBED BURNING, AND HARVESTING. SHORTLEAF PINE'S LACK OF NATURAL REGENERATION IS A FOREST CONSERVATION ISSUE THAT NEEDS PROPER ATTENTION TO RESTORE THE SPECIES. WE EXPECT THIS PROJECT TO GATHER VALUABLE DATA ON THE NATURAL REGENERATION OF SHORTLEAF PINE IN THE FORESTS WITHIN ITS GEOGRAPHIC RANGE. WE WILL DETERMINE OPTIMAL SHORTLEAF PINE DENSITY LEVELS FOR RE-ESTABLISHMENT SPECIES IN THE CENTRAL HARDWOOD REGION AND EXAMINE HOW CROP TREES AND SEED PRODUCTION IMPACT SHORTLEAF PINE NATURAL REGENERATION. OUR FOCUS IS ALSO ON FOREST RESTORATION AND THE EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT ON FISH AND WILDLIFE DOWNSTREAM FROM THINNED AND PRESCRIBED BURNED LOBLOLLY PINE FOREST SITES. SMALL MAMMALS, INCLUDING BATS, ARE CAPTURED OR HAVE ECHOLOCATION CALLS MONITORED. AQUATIC MACROINVERTEBRATES AND FISH ARE ALSO INVENTORIED QUARTERLY. WATER QUALITY AND CHANNEL MORPHOLOGY PARAMETERS ARE ALSO MEASURED. WE ALSO SURVEYED FERAL SWINE ACTIVITY IN RESPONSE TO PRESCRIBED BURNING IN UPSTREAM PINE STANDS. FERAL SWINE ROOTING ACTIVITY IS ALSO INVESTIGATED AS A SOIL DISTURBANCE FACTOR THAT COULD AFFECT STREAM WATER QUALITY AND THE PRESENCE AND ABUNDANCE OF AQUATIC SPECIES, SMALL MAMMALS, AND BATS AS BIOINDICATORS OF ENVIRONMENTAL INTEGRITY IN DOWNSTREAM COMMUNITIES. PRESCRIBED FOREST FIRES AND THINNING PRACTICES ALSO AFFECT THE AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE COMMUNITIES. WE WANT TO UNDERSTAND THE MECHANISMS AND FUNCTIONAL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN FOREST HABITAT CHANGES AND HERPETOFAUNAL DIVERSITY AND STRUCTURE, PARTICULARLY FROM LONG-TERM PERSPECTIVES. PERSONNEL (FACULTY, STAFF, GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, SECRETARIES), MATERIAL (VEHICLE PURCHASE AND MAINTENACE, SUPPLIES) AND OTHER INCIDENTALS PROVIDE THE BULK OF THE SPENDING FOR THIS GRANT.

UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY WILL USE OUR FY2023 MCINTIRE-STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM CAPACITY FUNDS, AND THE ASSOCIATED MATCHING FUNDS PROVIDED BY THE STATE OF UTAH, TO SUPPORT RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS THE FOREST RESEARCH AREAS DEFINED BY THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS LEGISLATION: (1) REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST; (2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LAND TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION; (3) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE; (4) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION; (5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASE, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS; (6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS; AND (7) DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS, AND SUCH OTHER STUDIES AS MAY BE NECESSARY TO OBTAIN THE FULLEST AND MOST EFFECTIVE USE OF FOREST RESOURCES. THESE RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ALIGN WITH ONE OF THE CRITICAL ISSUES DEFINED IN THE UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY FY2023 PLAN OF WORK, CLIMATE CHANGE AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES. FORESTS, RANGELAND, AND AGRICULTURE ARE ALL CLIMATE DEPENDENT. CONSEQUENTLY, ANY CHANGES IN THE ENVIRONMENT SUCH AS CLIMATE CHANGE WILL REQUIRE THAT PLANTS AND ANIMALS ADAPT TO OR MITIGATE CLIMATE CHANGE. THE MANAGEMENT OF FORESTS AND RANGELAND MUST BE AT THE FOREFRONT IN ADAPTING TO NEW CLIMATE REALITIES, AS WELL AS MITIGATING MANY OF THE INFLUENCES OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THE CONCEPT OF CLIMATE CHANGE IS NOT NEW TO UTAH FOREST MANAGERS. UTAHAN'S HAVE ADJUSTED TO CHANGES IN WATER AND TEMPERATURE FOR MANY YEARS. YET, THERE IS MORE THAT CAN BE DONE TO ENHANCE THE PRODUCTIVE ENVIRONMENT OF BOTH FORESTS AND ANIMALS. TREES AND OTHER PLANTS CAN BE MADE MORE RESISTANT TO DROUGHT AND SALINITY THROUGH TRADITIONAL BREEDING PRACTICES, AND THROUGH THE APPLICATION OF GENOMICS. WATER, MUCH OF WHICH ORIGINATES FROM FORESTED WATERSHEDS, WILL BECOME AN EVEN MORE CRITICAL PART OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION PROCESSES AS IT BECOMES LESS AVAILABLE AND/OR THE QUALITY BECOMES LESS SUITABLE FOR AGRICULTURE. THE IDEA OF WATER DEPENDENCY UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE CANNOT BE OVER EMPHASIZED AS POPULATIONS INCREASE, AND WATER SHIFTS FROM AGRICULTURAL TO MUNICIPAL AND INDUSTRIAL USES. PUBLIC/PRIVATE LAND INTERFACE IS ANOTHER AREA REQUIRING EXTENSIVE RESEARCH AND OUTREACH. SIXTY PERCENT OF THE TOTAL LAND AVAILABLE IN THE WEST IS PUBLIC LAND, OWNED BY EITHER THE STATE OR THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT. THIS PRESENTS UNIQUE CHALLENGES TO THE WEST THAT MOST OF THE REST OF THE COUNTRY CANNOT BEGIN TO UNDERSTAND. THE RESEARCH CONDUCTED WITH THESE FUNDS WILL RESULT IN DELIVERABLES THAT INCLUDE PRESENTATIONS AT SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS, SCIENTIFIC AND LAY PUBLICATIONS, OUTREACH ACTIVITIES INCLUDING EXTENSION EVENTS AND FACTSHEETS, AND TOOLS OR DEVICES DESIGNED TO ADDRESS SPECIFIC NEEDS. IMPACTS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE CHANGES IN KNOWLEDGE, CHANGES IN ACTIONS, AND CHANGES IN CONDITIONS. THIS RESEARCH WILL BENEFIT FOREST AND WILDLIFE MANAGERS; ENVIRONMENTALISTS; THE CITIZENS OF THE STATE OF UTAH, THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, THE COUNTRY, AND THE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY; STATE AND NATIONAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES; AND THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY.

WEST VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY MCINTIRE?STENNIS 2023 PROJECT  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE STREAM WATER QUALITY IN REFORESTED, DRASTICALLY DISTURBED WATERSHEDS IN CENTRAL APPALACHIA. A PAIRED?WATERSHED STUDY IS CONDUCTED WHERE STREAM WATER QUALITY OF PREVIOUSLY RECLAIMED SURFACE COAL MINING HEADWATER IS COMPARED TO THAT OF AN ADJACENT NON?DISTURBED HEADWATER. THE TWO HEADWATERS WERE INSTRUMENTED WITH MONITORING DEVICES TO CONTINUOUSLY RECORD METEOROLOGICAL CONDITIONS, WATER CHEMISTRY (E.G. PH, REDOX POTENTIAL, DISSOLVED OXYGEN, ETC.), AND STREAM FLOW. IN ADDITION, BIWEEKLY WATER SAMPLES ARE COLLECTED FROM THE TWO STREAMS FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS OF WATER CHEMICAL COMPOSITION (E.G. METAL CONTENT, ALKALINITY, DISSOLVED ORGANIC CARBON, MAJOR IONS, ETC.). FURTHERMORE, IN THE DISTURBED HEADWATER, SAMPLES ARE COLLECTED ALONG THE STREAM TO ASSESS BOTH TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL TRENDS AND CHANGES IN WATER QUALITY. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE QUANTITATIVE HYDROLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL ASSESSMENT, MODELING, AND BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE LONG?TERM IMPACT OF MINING ACTIVITIES AND MINE RECLAMATION PRACTICES ON OUR NATURAL RESOURCES, AND ON THE RECOVERY AND SUSTAINABILITY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. PROJECT OUTCOMES AND RESULTS WILL BE COMMUNICATED TO THE SCIENTIFIC, PROFESSIONAL, AND REGULATORY COMMUNITIES. INTENDENT BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LOCAL AND REGIONAL COMMUNITIES, THE MINING INDUSTRY, AND LOCAL AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENT AND NON?FOR?PROFIT ORGANIZATION IN DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO IMPROVE AND SUSTAIN OUR ENVIRONMENT AND NATURAL RESOURCES.

RESEARCH AND INNOVATION IS THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THE NH AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION. IN THE 2023-2027 PERIOD, THE STATION EXPECTS TO SUPPORT BETWEEN 44 AND 50 RESEARCH PROJECTS ACROSS FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES-AGRICULTURE; CLIMATE CHANGE AND SUSTAINING NATURAL RESOURCES; FOOD SAFETY; NUTRITION, HEALTH, AND WELLNESS; AND RURAL COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT-AS WELL AS PROJECTS WITHIN THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS FORESTRY SCIENCE AREAS.  WITHIN THE AGRICULTURE AREA, RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON INCREASING KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY TO SUPPORT HIGHLY DIVERSIFIED AGRICULTURAL AND FOOD SYSTEM THAT PRODUCES, PROCESSES AND DELIVERS FOOD, FIBER, AND MYRIAD ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES. EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON BIOTECHNOLOGICAL AND MANAGEMENT IMPROVEMENTS IN CROP AND DAIRY PRODUCTION TO MINIMIZE PRODUCTION AND MARKET RISKS AND CAPTURING NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES. RESEARCH HERE IS EXPECTED TO GROW WITH THE RECENT HIRING OF A CROP BREEDER FACULTY. FOCUS WILL ALSO BE PLACED ON HELPING THE STATE AND REGION CONTINUE TO EXPAND ITS SUSTAINABLE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY TO BENEFIT THE BLUE ECONOMY.  WORK WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO TARGET ISSUES RELATED TO MITIGATING AND ADAPTING TO CLIMATE CHANGE, ESPECIALLY IN THE ROLE OF AGRICULTURE AS A SOLUTION TO CLIMATE CHANGE. THROUGH BASIC AND APPLIED SCIENCE, AN EMERGING AREA OF EXCELLENCE IS IN SOIL MICROBIOLOGY, AND THESE EFFORTS WILL BE ONE OF THE CORE OF THE NHAES RESEARCH MISSION IN CLIMATE SCIENCE. A SECOND CORE AREA IS IN WATER QUANTITY AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT, ESPECIALLY AS IT RELATES TO THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN WATER AND AGRICULTURAL LAND AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. FOOD SAFETY IS AN AREA IN WHICH LESS RESEARCH IS EXPECTED THAN IN THE PAST. HOWEVER, THE RESEARCH THAT WILL CONTINUE WILL FOCUS ON SUPPORTING THE GROWING AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY, ESPECIALLY AS IT RELATES TO MANAGING PATHOGENS IN SHELLFISH. DIFFERENTIATING STRAINS OF PATHOGENS AND PREDICTING NEW STRAINS IS CRITICAL TO ENSURING THAT THE NORTHEAST AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY MAINTAINS ITS HIGH QUALITY STANDARDS. RESEARCH IS EXPECTED TO GROW IN THE NUTRITION AND HEALTH AND WELLNESS AREAS, AS EARLY-CAREER FACULTY TRANSITION INTO BEING MORE EXPERIENCED SCIENTISTS AND NEW FACULTY ARE ONBOARDED. THE FOCUS OF THE RESEARCH WILL BE ON IDENTIFYING AND DEVELOPING EFFECTIVE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ENSURING NUTRITIONAL BALANCE AND HEALTH OF UNDERREPRESENTED POPULATIONS IN NORTHERN NEW ENGLAND. THIS INCLUDES REFUGEE, IMMIGRANT, AND LATINX POPULATIONS, WHICH HAVE CONTINUED TO GROW IN SIZE IN THE REGION. CONSIDERATIONS OF THE DIFFERENCES IN THESE POPULATIONS' EATING HABITS, MICROBIOME COMPOSITIONS, AND NUTRITIONAL BEHAVIORS WILL HELP INFORM SCIENCE-BASED RECOMMENDATIONS.  LASTLY, AS NEW HAMPSHIRE'S COMMUNITIES CONTINUE TO EVOLVE DEMOGRAPHICALLY AND SOCIOECONOMICALLY, NHAES RESEARCH WILL CONTINUE TO FOCUS PART OF ITS RESEARCH PORTFOLIO ON CHARACTERIZING THOSE TRENDS, THE IMPACTS OF THOSE TRENDS, AND HOW LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS CAN BE BEST DEVELOPED TO BE SUCCESSFUL AND SUPPORT THE CHANGING DEMOGRAPHICS OF THE STATE AND REGION. USING SCIENCE-BASED, DATA-DRIVEN METHODS TO IDENTIFY KEY FACTORS STRESSING ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL WELFARE IN RURAL COMMUNITIES AND PROVIDING RESEARCH-INFORMED RECOMMENDATIONS AT THE INDIVIDUAL, FIRM, MUNICIPALITY, AND STATE LEVELS ARE CRUCIAL FOR SHORT- AND LONG-TERM COMMUNITY SUSTAINABILITY.  THE NHAES WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO GROW ITS OUTREACH AND SCIENCE COMMUNICATION PROGRAM. AFTER LAUNCHING IN WINTER 2021, A NEW PUBLICATI ON, INSPIRED, FOCUSES ON PRESENTING RESEARCH BRIEFS TO A BROAD POPULATION OF STAKEHOLDERS IN THE STATE AND REGION. THIS EFFORT WILL CONTINUE WITH ISSUES PUBLISHED AND MAILED BIANNUALLY. ADDITIONALLY, THE STATION WILL MAINTAIN ITS HIGHLY ROBUST ACTIVITY OF DISSEMINATING ITS RESEARCH  THROUGH WEEKLY NEWS BRIEFS (WHICH FOCUS ON NHAES RESEARCH), SOCIAL MEDIA PRESENCE, FIELD DAYS, AND INCREASINGLY MORE INTEGRATED COLLABORATION WITH EXTENSION.

INTRODUCTION:   THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS COOPERATIVE FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM IS FUNDED THROUGH THE USDA NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE AS A FORMULA-BASED PROGRAM FOR FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES RESEARCH AT LAND-GRANT UNIVERSITIES. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE RUBENSTEIN SCHOOL OF ENVIRONMENT AND NATURAL RESOURCES (RSENR) FOR CRITICAL STATE AND REGIONALLY FOCUSED FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES RESEARCH TO ADVANCE THE UNDERSTANDING OF FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES AND PRACTICES, AND TO MONITOR THEIR EFFECTS ON MANAGEMENT, PUBLIC POLICY, AND SOCIAL SYSTEMS. UVM'S FORESTRY PROGRAM AND HISTORY OVER 75% OF VERMONT'S LAND AREA IS COVERED BY FORESTS. THESE FORESTED LANDS PLAY A CRITICAL ROLE IN PROTECTING WATERSHEDS, MAINTAINING BIODIVERSITY, SEQUESTERING CARBON, AND SUPPORTING RURAL, WORKING LANDSCAPES. FORESTRY AS A FIELD OF STUDY HAS HAD A LONG AND DISTINGUISHED HISTORY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT WITH FORESTRY COURSES TAUGHT HERE SINCE 1888, WITH ONLY A BRIEF HIATUS DURING WORLD WAR II. THE DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1946 AND THE PROGRAM IS NOW A PART OF RSENR AND ACCREDITED BY THE SOCIETY OF AMERICAN FORESTERS. THE PROGRAM PREPARES STUDENTS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE, EXPERIENCE, AND CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS NEEDED TO HELP SOLVE THE COMPLEX PROBLEMS FACING FOREST ECOSYSTEMS, SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT, AND CONSERVATION IN THE 21ST CENTURY. MCINTIRE-STENNIS - SIGNIFICANCE AND PROGRAMS THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS FORESTRY RESEARCH PROGRAM AIMS TO INCREASE FORESTRY RESEARCH IN THE PRODUCTION, UTILIZATION, AND PROTECTION OF FORESTLAND; TRAIN FUTURE FORESTRY SCIENTISTS; INVOLVE OTHER DISCIPLINES IN FORESTRY RESEARCH; AND FACILITATE COOPERATION WITH STATE AGENCIES AND OTHER VERMONT PARTNERS IN FORESTRY RESEARCH. RSENR SOLICITS PROPOSALS FOR FIVE-YEAR PROJECTS. PROPOSALS ARE EVALUATED ON THEIR ALIGNMENT WITH THE STRATEGIC GOALS AND TARGETED RESEARCH AREAS OF THE NATIONAL MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROGRAM. CURRENT PROJECTS, BENEFICIARIES, AND OUTCOMES THE CURRENT PORTFOLIO OF MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROJECTS IN RSENR ARE INTERDISCIPLINARY PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS ECOLOGICAL, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC ASPECTS OF FOREST CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT. TWO PROJECTS IN OUR PORTFOLIO INVESTIGATE CRITICAL ASPECTS OF FOREST ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION: FOREST SOIL CARBON STORAGE AND THE FUNCTION AND STRUCTURE OF RIPARIAN FORESTS. BOTH PROJECTS BUILD ON COLLABORATIONS WITH FOREST MANAGERS, AGENCY PERSONNEL, AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO INFORM MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES THAT ENABLE INCREASED CARBON SEQUESTRATION AND FLOOD RESILIENCE. TWO ADDITIONAL PROJECTS IN OUR PORTFOLIO WORK DIRECTLY WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO ADDRESS FOREST RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT. ONE PROJECT IS WORKING WITH MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCERS TO UNDERSTAND THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN MANAGEMENT INTENSITY, FINANCIAL RETURNS, BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION, AND DELIVERY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. THE SECOND PROJECT IS WORKING WITH FOREST STAKEHOLDERS TO DETERMINE APPROACHES THAT CAN BEST GUIDE FOREST MANAGEMENT AS INCREASING DISTURBANCES ALTER ECOLOGICAL BALANCES WITHIN REGIONAL FORESTS. ALL PROJECTS EMPHASIZE RESEARCH ON FOREST PRODUCTIVITY, UTILIZATION, AND PROTECTION AND INCLUDE OPPORTUNITIES TO COLLABORATE AND SHARE FINDINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS AGENCIES, NGO'S, AND FOREST-DEPENDENT COMMUNITIES. WE PLACE A HIGH VALUE ON THE TRAINING OF FUTURE FOREST SCIENCE PROFESSIONALS BY SUPPORTING GRADUATE STUDENTS AND EARLY CAREER RESEARCHERS ACROSS PROJECTS.

FEDERAL AWARD PURPOSE: CONDUCT TRANSFORMATIONAL BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH, WHICH BLENDS CUTTING-EDGE SCIENCE AND POLICY AND IMPACTS THE FUTURE OF OUR STATE, THE NATION AND THE WORLD. OUR RESEARCH IS FOCUSED ON FOUR THEMATIC AREAS, (1) SUSTAINABLE AND RESILIENT AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS, (2) NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT, (3) HEALTH <(>&<)> HEALTHY FUTURES, AND (4) WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: ACTIVITIES UNDER EACH OF THE THEMATIC AREAS ARE LISTED BELOW. SUSTAINABLE <(>&<)> RESILIENT AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS ARE CHALLENGED BY CHANGING CLIMATE AND OTHER THREATS SUCH AS INCREASED INPUT COSTS AND INVASIVE PESTS AND DISEASES. SUSTAINABLE, CLIMATE-SMART, AND RESOURCE-EFFICIENT AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES HELP FARMERS ADAPT TO CHANGE, REMAIN RESILIENT AND ECONOMICALLY VIABLE. WE SEEK TO CONDUCT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH IN LABORATORIES, PLANT GROWTH FACILITIES AND FARMS AND RANCHES THAT ADVANCES SUSTAINABLE AND REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION PRACTICES THAT WILL IMPROVE SOIL HEALTH AND WATER USE EFFICIENCY, SUPPORT DIVERSE CROPS, PROMOTE BIODIVERSITY AND RESILIENCY, IMPROVE PLANT AND ANIMAL GENETICS, AND PROMOTE DIVERSE GRAZING SYSTEMS AND APPROACHES. NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT: MISSOURI ENJOYS THE UNIQUE DISTINCTION AS A CONSERVATION LEADER IN THE COUNTRY. WE ARE BLESSED WITH A DIVERSITY OF NATURAL RESOURCES LIKE FEW OTHER STATES IN THE NATION. THESE RESOURCES ARE ESSENTIAL TO THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC VITALITY OF OUR STATE. THE QUALITY OF LIFE OF EVERY CITIZEN ALSO DEPENDS ON THE HEALTH OF OUR STATE'S NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT, PARTICULARLY THAT OF OUR AIR, LAND AND SOIL AND WATER RESOURCES. HOWEVER, THESE RESOURCES ARE EXPERIENCING INCREASED PRESSURE AS A RESULT OF A NUMBER OF BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESSORS WHICH THREATEN THE SUSTAINABLE PROVISION OF THE GOODS (E.G. FOOD PRODUCTION, FOOD QUALITY) AND SERVICES (CLEAN AIR AND WATER) THAT ARE DEPENDENT ON THEM. WE SEEK TO INITIATE CUTTING EDGE INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH RELATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE, ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND RESTORATION, SOIL HEALTH, WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY, ENVIRONMENTAL CHEMISTRY, HABITAT EVALUATION, NATURE-BASED RECREATION, VALUING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, GREEN TECHNOLOGY INCLUDING ALTERNATIVE AND SUSTAINABLE ENERGY, SUSTAINABLE LANDSCAPES, ENVIRONMENTAL INFORMATICS AMONG OTHERS HEALTH <(>&<)> HEALTHY FUTURES: LIFE ON PLANET EARTH DEPENDS ON LIFE SUPPORTING GOODS AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVIDED BY THE COUPLED SOCIAL-ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS OR ECOSYSTEMS. THE HEALTH OF EARTH'S ECOSYSTEMS HAS DETERIORATED SO MUCH THAT THE PUBLIC IS CONCERNED ABOUT A LOSS OF LIFE SUPPORT FOR ALL ORGANISMS, INCLUDING THE HUMAN COMMUNITY. ECOSYSTEM HEALTH, AS AN INTEGRATIVE CONCEPT, INCLUDES BOTH THE BIOPHYSICAL AND SOCIOECOLOGICAL DIMENSIONS. THE BIOPHYSICAL REALM INCLUDES CLIMATE, AIR, THE ENVIRONMENT, WATER, ENERGY, WILDLIFE, FOOD, SOIL HEALTH AMONG OTHERS. THE SOCIOECONOMIC ASPECTS INCLUDE ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY, SOCIAL SERVICES, RECREATION AND HUMAN AND ANIMAL HEALTH AND WELFARE. THE LATTER IS PARTICULARLY AT RISK IN MANY PARTS OF THE WORLD NOT ONLY FROM ENVIRONMENTAL DEGRADATION BUT ALSO FROM INCREASING STRESS AND EMERGING PATHOGENS AND DISEASES. WE SEEK TO REVITALIZE AND EXPAND OUR ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND ANIMAL, AND HUMAN HEALTH RELATED PROGRAMS, STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS WITH THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND STAKEHOLDERS, AND PROVIDE A TRANSLATIONAL PLATFORM WITH FOCUS ON ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY, ANIMAL AND HUMAN WELFARE AND HEALTH, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND POLICY REFORMS. WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY: MISSOURI AN AGRARIAN STATE SUPPORTING A $93.7 BILLION AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY. OVER THE NEXT DECADE, THE AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND FORESTRY INDUSTRIES IN MISSOURI ARE PROJECTED TO GENERATE 13,000 JOB OPENINGS ANNUALLY. TECHNOLOGICAL ADVANCES, INCLUDING SMART FARMS AND BIG DATA AND DATA ANALYTICS, HAVE CREATED A NUMBER OF NEW JOB OPPORTUNITIES. HOWEVER, FINDING SKILLED LABOR CONTINUES TO BE A CHALLENGE. WE SEEK TO PROVIDE HANDS-ON TRAINING THROUGH BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH RELATED TO AGRICULTURE PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING, FOOD AND NUTRITION, NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT, AND AGRIBUSINESS AND AGRICULTURAL POLICY THAT WILL PRODUCE A WELL-TRAINED WORKFORCE FOR THE AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY OF THE PRESENT AND FUTURE AND FURTHER THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF AGRICULTURE. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL GENERATE (1) SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE THAT WILL ADVANCE AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND NATURAL RESOURCES FOR A HEALTHY FUTURE (2) BETTER CROPS AND CROPPING SYSTEMS THAT WILL BE RESILIENT TO CHANGING CLIMATE AND EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS, (3) BETTER UNDERSTANDING AND QUANTIFICATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES OF SUSTAINABLE AND REGENERATIVE CROPPING SYSTEMS (E.G. C SEQUESTRATION AS A STRATEGY FOR CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION), AND (4) ECONOMIC AND POLICY ANALYSIS THAT CAN HELP FARMERS/RANCHERS/POLICY MAKERS MAKE APPROPRIATE DECISIONS. ALL OF THE ABOVE OUTCOMES WILL ALSO GENERATE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, GRADUATE THESES AND DISSERTATIONS, PROFESSIONAL PRESENTATIONS, DEMONSTRATION TRIALS, NEW VARIETIES, INVENTION DISCLOSURES AND PATENTS AND DATA AND MATERIALS TO HELP WITH ASSOCIATED EXTENSION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: THE DIRECT INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE FARMERS AND RANCHERS IN MISSOURI PRIMARILY, BUT OVERALL IT BENEFITS THE CITIZENS OF THE STATE. THE IMPACT OF THE RESEARCH GOES BEYOND MISSOURI AND THE NATION.  SUBRECIPIENTS: N/A

THE PURPOSE OF FEDERAL MCINTIRE STENNIS FUNDING PROVIDED BY USDA/NIFA IS TO INCREASE FORESTRY RESEARCH IN THE PRODUCTION, UTILIZATION, AND PROTECTION OF FORESTLAND; TO TRAIN FUTURE FORESTRY SCIENTISTS; AND TO INVOLVE OTHER DISCIPLINES IN FORESTRY RESEARCH. THE AWARD IS USED TO ASSIST ALL STATES IN CARRYING OUT A PROGRAM OF FORESTRY RESEARCH AND IN DEVELOPING A TRAINED POOL OF FOREST SCIENTISTS CAPABLE OF CONDUCTING NEEDED FORESTRY RESEARCH UNDER THE FOLLOWING RESEARCH TOPICS: 1) REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST; 2) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION; 3) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE; 4) MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION; 5) PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS; 6) UTILIZATION OF WOOD AND OTHER FOREST PRODUCTS; 7) DEVELOPMENT OF SOUND POLICIES FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST LANDS AND THE HARVESTING AND MARKETING OF FOREST PRODUCTS. AT UMASS AMHERST, THE FUNDS ASSOCIATED WITH THE FEDERAL MCINTIRE-STENNIS AWARD ARE USED TO SUPPORT STUDENT EMPLOYMENT AND TO PROVIDE OPERATING FUNDS FOR RESEARCH RELATED EXPENDITURES (RESEARCH EQUIPMENT, MATERIALS, SUPPLIES, AND TRAVEL) BY FACULTY INVESTIGATORS WHO EMPLOY A VARIETY OF METHODS APPROPRIATE TO THEIR DISCIPLINE AND SPECIFIC PROGRAM OF RESEARCH. THE FUNDS ARE ADMINISTERED BY THE MASSACHUSETTS AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENTATION STATION, A UNIT OF THE CENTER FOR AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND THE ENVIRONMENT (CAFE), WITHIN THE UMASS COLLEGE OF NATURAL SCIENCES AND TYPICALLY USED BY FACULTY IN THE DEPARTMENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION FOR INVESTIGATIONS FOCUSED ON FOREST ECOSYSTEMS, TREE GROWTH, INVASIVE PESTS AND FOREST PRODUCTS.

THE MARYLAND AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (MAES) AND THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES (AGNR) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND WILL UTILIZE MCINTIRE-STENNIS FUNDS FOR THE FOLLOWING RESEARCH PROJECTS:  1. ASSESSING NUTRIENT CYCLING IN URBAN FOREST PATCHES TO SUPPORT STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 2. ROLE OF TREE PLANTING DIVERSITY IN DETERMINING PRODUCTIVITY, SUSCEPTIBILITY TO INSECT HERBIVORES, AND NATURAL ENEMY COMMUNITIES IN MANAGED FORESTS 3. PHOTOSYNTHETIC RESPONSES TO SHORT-TERM HIGH DAY TEMPERATURES AS A TOOL TO SELECT FOR AND ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF HEAT-TOLERANT URBAN FOREST TREES 4. CARBON CYCLING AND UNDERPLANTING IN TIDAL FRESHWATER FORESTED WETLANDS IMPACTED BY EMERALD ASH BORER 5. USING ECOLOGY AND INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT APPROACHES AGAINST INVASIVE INSECTS TO INCREASE THE SUSTAINABILITY OF NATURAL AND URBAN FORESTS 6. TESTING POLICY AND OUTREACH EFFECTIVENESS IN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT FOR MARYLAND FOREST OWNERS 7. EMPIRICAL AND ECONOMIC MODEL OF PRECISION IRRIGATION AND NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT IN INTENSIVE TREE PRODUCTION 8. CELL-BASED APPROACHES TO DECIPHER GENE FUNCTION AT THE INTERSECTION OF GROWTH AND DEFENSE IN POPLAR RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ARE CONDUCTED IN AGNR'S CAMPUS GREENHOUSES AND LABORATORIES LOCATED IN THE DEPARTMENTS OF PLANT SCIENCE AND LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE (PSLA), ENTOMOLOGY (ENTM), AGRICULTURAL AND RESOURCE ECONOMICS (AREC), AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY (ENST). SAMPLE AND DATA COLLECTION ARE CONDUCTED IN VARIOUS URBAN AND RURAL FORESTS IN MARYLAND THAT ARE PUBLIC AND PRIVATELY OWNED. THE RESEARCH PROJECTS ABOVE ALIGN WITH THE FOLLOWING MANDATED AREAS OF THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROGRAM: 1. REFORESTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF LAND FOR THE PRODUCTION OF CROPS OF TIMBER AND OTHER RELATED PRODUCTS OF THE FOREST; 2. MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED WATERSHED LANDS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS OF WATER FLOW AND TO PROTECT RESOURCES AGAINST FLOODS AND EROSION; 3. MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RELATED RANGELAND FOR PRODUCTION OF FORAGE FOR DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK AND GAME AND IMPROVEMENT OF FOOD AND HABITAT FOR WILDLIFE; AND, 4. PROTECTION OF FOREST LAND AND RESOURCES AGAINST FIRE, INSECTS, DISEASES, OR OTHER DESTRUCTIVE AGENTS.  MAES-FUNDED MCINTIRE-STENNIS RESEARCH PROJECTS ARE PEER-REVIEWED BEFORE THEY ARE APPROVED BY THE MAES DIRECTOR TO ENSURE THAT THEY ARE NOVEL, SCIENTIFICALLY-SOUND, AND ALIGN WITH THE PURPOSES OF THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROGRAM LISTED ABOVE, THE USDA STRATEGIC PLAN FY 2022-2026 (GOALS 1-4), AND OUR COLLEGE'S STRATEGIC INITIATIVES. DETAILED INFORMATION ABOUT EACH MCINTIRE- STENNIS RESEARCH PROJECT, SUCH AS THE OBJECTIVES AND METHODOLOGY, CAN BE FOUND ONLINE IN THE NIFA REPORTING SYSTEM.

THE MAINE AGRICULTURAL AND FOREST EXPERIMENT STATION HAS BEEN CONDUCTING RESEARCH FOR MAINE AND ITS PEOPLE FOR OVER 125 YEARS. ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS UNDER THE HATCH AND MCINTIRE?STENNIS ACTS, IN COMBINATION WITH UNIVERSITY OF MAINE FUNDS, PROVIDE THE BASE FUNDING FOR RESEARCH PROGRAMS OF THE STATION. THE RESEARCH CAPACITY PROVIDED BY BASE FUNDING LEVERAGES ADDITIONAL FUNDING FROM COMPETITIVE GRANTS AND CONTRACTS AND INDUSTRY SUPPORT. MCINTIRE?STENNIS FUNDS ARE USED AT THE MAINE AGRICULTURAL AND FOREST EXPERIMENT STATION TO SUPPORT RESEARCH IN FOREST RESOURCES SPANNING A RANGE OF CURRENT ISSUES IN SILVICULTURE AND FOREST MANAGEMENT, TO WOOD SCIENCE AND FOREST PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT AND MARKETING, TO WILDLIFE HABITAT, OUTDOOR RECREATION, AND LAND USE POLICY. THE MAINE AGRICULTURAL AND FOREST EXPERIMENT STATION WILL USE ADMINISTRATIVE MCINTIRE?STENNIS FUNDS TO SUPPORT THE RESEARCH PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION AND FINANCIAL RECORDKEEPING AND REPORTING ACTIVITIES REQUIRED BY THE FEDERAL REGULATIONS THAT GOVERN THE EXPENDITURE OF MCINTIRE?STENNIS FUNDS. THE STATION HAS OVER 20 RESEARCH PROJECTS IN THE MCINTIRE?STENNIS PROGRAM. TYPICALLY, EACH MCINTIRE?STENNIS PROJECT WILL HAVE SEVERAL ASSOCIATED PROJECT ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY COMPETITIVE GRANTS OR OTHER SOURCES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT RESEARCH THAT ADDRESSES FOREST HEALTH AND MANAGEMENT AND ALIGNS WITH THE MANDATED PRIORITIES FOR THE MCINTIRE-STENNIS PROGRAM. FOR FY23, THE AWARD WILL SUPPORT PROJECTS INCLUDING: O NATURAL RESOURCE ECONOMICS RESEARCH TO BUILD ECONOMIC MODELS FOR MANAGEMENT AND DECISION MAKING THAT INCLUDE THE VALUE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES FOR THE CENTRAL HARDWOOD FOREST REGION. FIELD RESEARCH ON HOW ELK REINTRODUCTION IN EASTERN KENTUCKY HAS IMPACTED THE ECOLOGY OF FORESTS IN THE REGION AND THE REFORESTATION OF RECLAIMED COAL SURFACE MINES. FOREST ENTOMOLOGY RESEARCH DEVELOPING A NEW PEST MANAGEMENT TOOL BASED ON RNA INTERFERENCE TO TARGET INVASIVE WOOD-BORING PESTS, INCLUDING THE EMERALD ASH BORER RESEARCH USING LONG-TERM ENVIRONMENTAL DATASETS FORM ROBINSON FOREST TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY ARE INFLUENCED BY MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, RESOURCE EXTRACTION, CLIMATE VARIABILITY, ETC. INVESTIGATIONS OF SILVICULTURAL PRACTICES AND GENETIC FACTORS THAT CAN CONTRIBUTE TO OAK GROWTH AND SUSTAINABILITY RESEARCH EVALUATING HOW WILDLIFE RESPONDS TO SURFACE MINE REFORESTATION EFFORTS IN CENTRAL APPALACHIA DELIVERABLES FROM THE RESEARCH PROGRAMS SUPPORTED BY MCINTIRE-STENNIS FUNDING INCLUDE NEW DATA, SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS AND PRESENTATIONS, AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TRAINED THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN THE PROJECT. TRANSLATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS WILL BE DELIVERED TO STAKEHOLDERS IN PART THROUGH THE CREATION OF DECISION-MAKING TOOLS, RECOMMENDATIONS FOR BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND EDUCATION PROGRAMMING DEVELOPED IN COLLABORATION WITH EXTENSION. EXPECTED OUTCOMES FROM THIS WORK INCLUDE BETTER INFORMED FOREST MANAGEMENT AND POLICY- DECISION- MAKING, IMPROVED CONSERVATION OF WATER RESOURCES AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN CENTRAL APPALACHIA, NEW CONTROL METHODS FOR INVASIVE FOREST PESTS, AND IMPROVED SUSTAINABILITY OF THE WHITE OAK INDUSTRY. BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE OTHER FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE SCIENTISTS, FOREST RESOURCE MANAGERS, WILDLIFE MANAGERS, WOODLAND OWNERS, THE FOREST PRODUCTS INDUSTRIES, COMMUNITIES IN CENTRAL APPALACHIA, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE UNIVERSITY OF GUAM (UOG) HAS REACHED ITS 50TH ANNIVERSARY AS A LAND-GRANT UNIVERSITY IN 2022. THE LAND-GRANT MISSION AT UOG IS C ONDUCTED MOSTLY AT THE COLLEGE OF NATURAL AND APPLIED SCIENCES (CNAS) FORMERLY THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND LIFE SCIENCES. THE WESTERN PACIFIC TROPICAL RESEARCH CENTER (WPTRC) IS THE RESEARCH BRANCH OF CNAS AND MANAGES RESEARCH PROJECTS FUNDED BY THE HATCH, MULTISTATE HATCH, AND MCINTIRE STENNIS PROGRAMS. FOR THE MCINTIRE STENNIS PROGRAM, CNAS FACULTY CONDUCT A LIMITED NUMBER OF PROJECTS BECAUSE OF SHARP FUNDING REDUCTION ON FORESTRY ISSUES RELEVANT TO GUAM. PROJECTS AT CNAS INVOLVE RESEARCH FACULTY, ASSOCIATES, AND ASSISTANTS AS WELL AS AGRICULTURE TECHNICIANS, STUDENTS, AND OTHER SUPPORT PERSONNEL. ALL PROJECTS RELATE TO FORESTRY IN ITS BROADEST SENSE. OUTPUTS FROM THE PROJECTS ARE PUBLICATIONS IN PEER-REVIEW JOURNALS, TECHNICAL REPORTS, AND INFORMATION IN WEBSITES AND OTHER OUTLETS. OUTCOMES ARE CONSERVATION AND IMPROVED SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF FOREST RESOURCES IN GUAM.

FORESTS HAVE PROVEN TO BE QUITE FLEXIBLE IN COMPARISON TO MANY OTHER LAND USE DESIGNATIONS AND CAN PROVIDE FOR A WIDE RANGE OF USES WHILE PROVIDING SOCIAL, ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS. SPECIFICALLY, FOREST WATERSHEDS PROVIDE FOR A WEALTH OF PROVISIONING, REGULATING, AND SUSTAINING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES AND ARE A NEGLIGIBLE CONTRIBUTOR OF NON-POINT SOURCE POLLUTION AND CAUSES OF STREAM IMPAIRMENT. THE  FORESTED LANDSCAPE IN THE NATION FACES IMMENSE CHALLENGES WHICH DEMAND SCIENTIFIC INVESTIGATIONS TO PROVIDE APPROPRIATE SOLUTIONS TO THE CHALLENGES. AMONG THE CHALLENGES INCLUDE CLIMATE CHANGE, SUSTAINABILITY, LAND USE PRESSURE, APPROPRIATE FOREST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, SOCIAL FACTORS AND WILDFIRES. ALABAMA IS THE FIFTH MOST FORESTED STATE IN THE UNITED STATES, WITH AN ESTIMATED 23,069,432 ACRES OF FOREST LAND, ACCOUNTING FOR 71% OF THE TOTAL LAND AREA. ALABAMA FOREST INDUSTRY JOB CONCENTRATION IS 2.57 TIMES THE NATIONAL JOB CONCENTRATION AND RANKED 3RD NATIONALLY IN THE FOREST PRODUCTS SECTOR'S CONTRIBUTION TO THE STATE ECONOMY.  FAMILY OWNERS CONTROL 71% OF THE PRIVATE FORESTLAND. MINORITY LANDOWNERS REPRESENT A RELATIVELY SMALL PROPORTION OF FOREST LANDOWNERS AND FORESTLAND (4.2% AND 1.4%, RESPECTIVELY). FORESTLAND OCCUPIES A SIGNIFICANT PART OF THE MINORITY FARMER LANDSCAPE, OFTEN REPRESENTING HALF OR MORE OF AGRICULTURAL LAND. HOWEVER, ONLY 3% OF OWNERS ACROSS THE SOUTH HAVE A MANAGEMENT PLAN. THERE IS THE NEED TO DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE AND BEST PRACTICES FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT ALTERNATIVES FOR LIMITED RESOURCE LANDOWNERS IN THE BLACK BELT REGION BY EXPLORING AND PRESENTING POTENTIAL STREAMS OF INCOME FOR THESE LANDOWNERS WHILE PROVIDING A PLATFORM FOR ENHANCED RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH FOR STUDENTS AND STAKEHOLDERS. MANAGING FOR MULTIPLE USES CAN RANGE FROM TIMBER PRODUCTION, TO MANAGING FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT AND ASSOCIATED RECREATION ACTIVITIES, E.G., WILD GAME HUNTING. THESE USES ALSO INCLUDE WATER RESOURCES, SOIL HEALTH, AND OTHERS SERVICES. FURTHER, MANAGING FOR MULTIPLE USES IN A LESS CONVENTIONAL MANNER MAY TAKE THE FORM OF AGROFORESTRY SCHEMES THAT PRODUCE HIGH QUALITY TIMBER WHILE PROVIDING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS OR OPPORTUNITIES TO FORAGE FOR NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCTS. FOREST SYSTEMS ARE MULTI-FUNCTIONAL AND CAPABLE OF SUPPLYING A WIDE ARRAY OF SERVICES AND OUTPUTS; YET, LIMITED RESOURCE LANDOWNERS TYPICALLY HAVE SCANT KNOWLEDGE OF EITHER THE OPERATIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR MAXIMIZING THESE OPPORTUNITIES OR THE FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS ASSOCIATED WITH THEIR LANDS. OUR EFFORTS ARE THEREFORE  FOCUSED ON DEVELOPING RESEARCH PROGRAMS THAT ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF THIS SEGMENT OF THE FOREST AND LANDOWNERS. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH ON: ADVANCING SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY FOR SMALL-SCALE UNDER-REPRESENTED MINORITY FORESTRY LANDOWNERS; SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT AND RECREATIONAL USE FOR LIMITED RESOURCE LANDOWNERS IN THE BLACK BELT REGION;  AND ENHANCING THE GRAZING AND FEEDING OPPORTUNITY FOR LIVESTOCK BY EXPANDING SILVOPASTURE AND WOODLAND-GRAZING PRACTICES FOR LIMITED RESOURCE FOREST LANDOWNERS IN ALABAMA BLACK BELT REGION
